reviewText:
This is a long review, so just read the bottom paragraph for a simple summary of my thoughts.

It surprises me that the general consensus for this game is worse than Risen 2: Dark Waters. To be fair, if you hated Risen 2, there likely are not enough redeeming factors about the end of the trilogy to be worth your while. But nevertheless, some substantial improvements to the overall experience have made this a promising step in the right direction for Piranha Bytes as a developer.

Risen 2: Dark Waters was ultimately a failure as an open world, engrossing RPG. It was extremely shallow, overall having one of their smallest and most lackluster world designs to date, with most of the islands consisting of winding pathways with few interesting landmarks leading between major locations. These locations were greatly devoid of life, as the characters were as dull and two-dimensional as wooden boards. The combat wasn't the worst I've ever seen in a game, but it took forever to get the necessary skills to stay on top of combat, and by then you just got used to button mashing between prayers. Beyond combat, half the skills in the game were worthless or used in only scripted situations that were easy enough to do without.

At first glance, or maybe even for the first couple hours, Risen 3 hardly seems any different. But if you put some effort into it, you'll find much more in store here. The combat system is widely criticized for the wrong reasons. To be fair, the easiest way to fail at Risen 3 was the only way to WIN in Risen 2: button mashing is heavily discouraged in Risen 3, as timing your combos poorly results in substantially slower attacks. Instead, the game encourages you to time your attacks with precision, and focus your efforts between multiple foes instead of trying to spam them to death one at a time. It also has a dodge maneuver, which Risen 2 lacked on release (and when they patched it in, it was hardly any more useful). In fact, the dodge led to quite the opposite criticism: that combat was too easy, since dodging made you invulnerable during the animation. (A patched-in Ultra" difficulty removes these invincibility frames

reviewText:
Pros
- Incredible visuals. Probably the best fire I've seen in a game.
- Goofy as usual. Piranha Bytes hasn't changed a bit, and I like it.
- Great open world gameplay. There's a lot to explore and find.
- Magic is back, and it's satisfying.

Cons
- Awkward sword combat--things just don't feel quite right, but with time, you get used to it.
- Companions aren't as helpful as they are capable.
- Story is decent, but unmemorable.
- Astral vision ability could have been a lot cooler if there were puzzles or areas where it was required. I found I never really used it.

Verdict
If you're looking for a decent, challenging RPG with a sense of humor, definitely get this game. The whole series is fun. Don't expect a Witcher game, but don't let the Metacritic score scare you off either.

(Take the Witcher comment with a grain of salt. If you don't like that series, then <insert favorite RPG here>)

reviewText:
The Risen 'series' isn't really much of a series at all.  Risen 1 was very obviously a rebranded Gothic 4 that followed the events of the 'neutral' path of Gothic 3: Xardas and the Nameless Hero banish the gods.  Given its moderate success, however, Deep Silver dangled a bag of money in front of Piranha Bytes and out pooped Risen 2 -- an abomination of a game that somehow missed all the hallmarks of what made prior PB games great.  Apparently Risen 2 sold well enough to justify a Risen 3.  Unsurprisingly there will be no Risen 4.

What did PB do right this time around?  Factions are back after their mysterious absence in Risen 2.  And while they don't quite approach the Gothic 1 and 2 levels of distinction they arguably surpass those in Risen 1 (with a very disappointing shallow difference between Warrior of the Order and Mage).  Moreover, each faction has its unique school of magic where spells have distinctive themes and are fueled by different 'currencies.'

The game is less linear with the ability to choose which island you tackle first; or, you can go back and forth and explore as you wish with little in the way of artificial barriers impeding your progress.  Unfortunately this pro feeds into one of the game's biggest cons: about a third or so of the way through no enemy presents a challenge.  Even on the harder difficulties you aren't at risk of dying save for the occasional one shot from certain creatures if your magic resistance is low.  And while there's plenty of content it eventually becomes a tedious slog through the same old monsters.  In one section on Kila in the final third or so of the game I swear I must have hacked my way through at least a hundred spiders.

The character system is much the same as it was in Risen 2 but its greatest flaw is that once you decide on the type of combat you want to focus on (melee, firearms, or magic); you can get close to maximizing it fairly early on.  Throw some points in Toughness to take some hits and that's all you need.  Dexterity is needed for lockpicking if you don't go mage (who have spells to handle locks) but the other skills are borderline worthless.  Silver Tongue is useful maybe a half dozen times and there's always an alternative to it.  Pickpocketing merely nets you a few extra items but you'll be swimming in gold soon enough.  Intimidate is equally as useless as Silver Tongue.  After 30+ hours of playing I haven't even touched alchemy or distilling.  Crafting isn't needed unless you're a completionist.  And then there's this 'second sight' ability to let you scout for gold, weapons, monsters, whatever... and I never used it a single time.  If you have a pulse and a few brain cells you will have no problems spotting the loot and the very few levers you need to pull to progress through the game.

Melee combat is as unsatisfying as it was in Risen 2.  Most monsters will go into stun-lock charges a la Gothic 3 so your best defense isn't parrying but rolling.  Risen 1 did it better and while shields were overpowered the simple introduction of a stamina mechanic to prevent you from turtling up would have been the more elegant solution.  Fortunately the magic is better so you can nuke your way through the throngs of spiders, skeletons, and hell hounds you'll get sick of by hour fifteen or so.

The story is uninteresting and largely unexplained.  Instead of the character from the first and second games you now play as the brother of Patty.  Why?  No reason, really.  Outside of the tutorial section Patty becomes largely irrelevant unless you opt to use her as one of a half dozen or so companions in combat.  You could be random Pirate Joe for all it matters.  I didn't even see a mention of the Titans or the events of the last few games until around halfway through.  All you know is: you died, you need to get your spirit back, evil demon things are attacking, and... you have to assemble a fleet to fight the ghost of a dude who died in the second game.

An unfortunate companion to the 'story' is the non-stop 'dream' sequences you have whenver you sleep.  You wake up in the spirit world and wander around until you have a brief conversation with characters from the previous games or some big monster spawns, goes BOO, and you wake up.  Similarly jarring are the awful arcade combat vignettes against sea monsters.  Three or four times as you progress the story you're forced into a ship battle where you tool around and fire at it with ONE canon.  Fun times.

Risen 3 is a game that screams 'fulfilling our contractual obligation for X number of sequels.'  And while PB puts in some effort to improve upon the turkey of Risen 2; there are still far too many flaws to justify the series continuance beyond the first game.

reviewText:
Risen 3 – Titan Lords
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
As I have not played the previous two (2) games, I really had no idea what this game would be like.

7 hours down the track, I am absolutely amazed by it. The amount of quests I am getting in one location is just unbelievable; I am literally losing count.

This RPG is set in a world of Pirates with absolutely stunning visuals. If you enjoy taking screenshots do not look further, this game will give you plenty of opportunities to snatch great screenshots from sunset to beautiful sceneries.

Great open world and apart from quests you have a fair few of other things to do like picking up clams where you can get pearls or gathering food, vegetation for potions/magic, and a must for a good pirate, rum and other distilled substances. They are great sources of health in the game. Argh...hip Argh...hip...burp...Argh!

One thing I like so far is you do not have to worry about how many objects your character is carrying, just collect them. Anyway, you will be able to trade your goods with multiple people in each destination. And, you will be able to learn many essential skills like using a monkey! Yes you will!

Along the way you meet characters and you can invite them to your party. I already have two at this stage (different skills) and they are very useful especially during combat. However, you have to choose who you want at your side when you arrive at each location.

For the combat side of the equation, it could have been smoother but it is fine. I am just being a little bit picky here. A little bit of advice, try to upgrade your character attributes as soon as possible because some foes are quiet challenging and even with a companion at your side you just might die quickly.

The audio is good and the story is sound. A good RPG all round.

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Great graphics
-	Good story
-	Massive number of quests
-	In depth character options
-	Challenging adversaries
-	Good humour
-	Achievements
-	Trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Combat system could have been better

A very solid RPG in my opinion. Thumbs up.

8/10

reviewText:
Risen 3 is Finally out and is now being hit by reviews that are up and down. Let me talk about my experience and what this game's strong point and weak points. Read first before you point that dangerous thumb at me.

As a new protaganist to the series, you are the son of steelbeard and brother of Patty who both are on the way to crab island to discover treasure from a map only to run into the army of the underworld and have your soul taken. The only thing you can do is to try to redeem it by battling against the forces of darkness

Risen 3 is a good improvement over 2 in many ways, Fans of PB's  original risen will love it, those who hated/loved 2 will also be welcomed back to the pirate theme with new improvements, and those that are new to the series will be a hit or miss. The game isn't like your typical rpg or Skyrim. It is a third person rpg with different style, rules and combat. Don't be mislead though this game isn't about sailing the open oceans or exploring a massive world but instead lets you explore certain lands of reasonable size that is filled with plenty of quests, dangers, and treasures.

The combat system itself feels more smooth this time around as as it reverts itself away from risen 2 and taps back to its root like Risen with some added tweaks and with a much more fun magic gameplay. Yes you do start this game off weak, in fact you'll have to depend on your companions which you can choose to bring one at a time during the game to help you. You'll have to count on them because enemies will swipe you, attack you from sides, dodge your attacks and even blind side you when you aren't looking and in groups. In fact hard mode can be quite a challenge during the start  game.

As you progress the game leveling the way you want you'll start realizing that your efforts will start paying off. You'll start investing in new skills to aid you in becoming stronger  even experiencing better combat which should feel a bit more fluid and much like original risen. You'll also  be able to switch weapons and spells via the bottom hotbars, while combining the use of  items and scrolls becoming more powerful in fact too powerful to the point where you're completely ridiculously almost overpowered, killing enemies in a few hits..

The game offers you a choice to join between 3 factions. Voodoo, Demon hunters, or Guardians and you can only commit to one so choose carefully. Each offering its own unique skills and spells to help you fight. Some though are similar to other faction.

The game leveling systems revolves around glory and gold. You earn glory from mostly killing and questing.The quest system in this game is well done in a way so that if you've already encountered the quest you'll be able to turn it in to the npc when it is requested eliminating that need to go back and forth. There are Plenty of quests and things to do in the game to acquire glory and gold.

The return of magic this time around is more  fun to play with depending on your faction you've picked.You'll be able to utilize spells from that faction otherwise you'll have to buy runes and scrolls.
Spells are also a completely seperate tree  and requires certain gems to purchase. When you attain spells you'll only be limited to casting by a cooldown timers. For every faction is a spell you can use as a melee spell over and over again.,You can even improve the timer and combo off more or cast faster. Yes I became a mage and I kick ♥♥♥ with a epee in my hand raining fireballs upon my enemies and stealing stuff by just reaching out my hands and did fire bending somagic this time around is  more fun.

Aside from the gameplay the sound and music is perfectly fine for this game, the graphics though a bit outdated is much better than its previous series for sure and the game feels more optimized (save for the 8 cores + situation). If you are a fan of the series you will see that it is NOT THAT BAD though could be improved much more. The voice acting is decent for  in the game  though  some are  a bit cheesy (such as bone) or bad but can be looked over because the dialogues actually get a bit better later in the game.. Sometimes you can see the devs joking around with the dialogue by adding really funny questions and phrases and isn't meant to be taken too seriously.
The quests themselves in this game contain many lore behind the world of risen 3 and will keep you wanting to do the quest. You'll have retrieval quests, kill quests, subquests, and mainquests. Not all quests are grindy at all or without purpose.

There are choice dialogues in this game and the choices affects the outcome of what happens. The choice is really up to you on how you want to play the game, maybe you'll steal, maybe you'll use your tongue and intimidate or pick another choice to accomplish your mission. maybe you rather be the bad guy and lose a bit of your humanity or gain humanity. Whatever you  choose to do in the game will either acquire your soul back or help you lose it much quicker.

anyways check the game out. This game might not be the cup of tea for everyone.
Make your own damn decision on the game. Don't be mislead  by naysayers and research it well.  I beaten the game around 25 hours and thats not doing EVERY quest there is in the game, once I became OP i went straight for the last mission. Reason is because I can save my other quests on the other islands for other playthroughs as different faction. I enjoyed the game quite a bit and hope that in the future they can improve on some of the cons I've written about the game.



+ Game starts off really slow  and difficult but gets better as you progress
+ Tons of quests, plenty of glory and gold to be found
+ Ship battle with sea monsters are challenging
+ The combat is much better than risen 2 but can feel a bit clunky at first until you progress a bit.
+ Quests systems completes if you done it already in the world so you don't have to actually grab it to do it you can turn it in as long as you've done it.
+ Magic is fun, try guardians and firebend.
+ You can be any class you want to be varying from 3 factions.
+ Plenty of gear to play around with and stats you can mix and match to your advantage. Legendary weapons included and upgraded weapons.

+- Reused map and game materials from 2
+- Subpar dialogue and lots of comedy and jokes, sometimes funny, sometimes cheesy, sometimes very bad
+- Some people will probabaly not like the way the combat is done, you get a certain amount of combo hit and you must dodge or attack your enemy.

- Armor feels more asthetic than useful sometimes, I found myself wearing adventurer armor during the entire game and barely changing to the other armors.
- weapons animation are all the same, along with fist spells, wish elements played a role against enemies more.
- combat can be repetitive after you become OP and autotarget can cause issues if you face an npcs you could accidentally hit them sometimes.
- difficulty scaling could have some improvement.t
- Voice is decent, main character sounds like Christian Bale's Batman.
- Graphics needs updated engine, decent at max
- camera can be clunky during dialogue sometimes
- The item interface can be reworked much better, hate having to hotbar everything to use it such as self cast spells, also need rework on keybindings.
-  The game could interact button instead of the attack button as interact, sometimes you accidently just talk to your companion in the fray of things or clicking to find loot because it is all one button.
- Need patch to fix 8 core limitation that is causing a blackscreen
- spells are a lackluster
- World empty after you kill everything, it doesn't respawn so no more mobs respawn.



finished on twitch.tv/kenuty on 8/13/2014

reviewText:
I normally played turn-based RPG, but decided to try Risen 3 for a change.
I totally enjoyed this game. It has a great storyline and is extremely immersive.
I spend many hours carefully picking up everything, collecting all Legendary Items, and Reforging the best Weapons in the game.

I also spend many hours trying to get all the Steam Achievements and was able to do so in a single playthough as a Demon Hunter. It seems that this is the only faction that you can get all achievements in a single playthrough. The other 2 factions, Guardian and Natives all have missing achievements.
The combat sequence was extremely fun too. The only hard part for me was the Sea Battles and the Final Boss Fight, because they both require fast interactive responses which was difficult for me. The mini-game were really fun, although the archery one is quite difficult too. However, getting Legendary Items from instances of certain mini-game were a great idea and an incentive as well.

Anyway this is really a fun game and it is wonderful to spend many hours in it.
I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Risen 3: Titan Lords is an RPG game developed by Piranha Bytes and published by Deep Silver. It’s the third game in the Risen series. The game was released in August 2014 on PC, Xbox360 and PS3, but the PS4 got a remastered version of the game is August 2015.

The game plays almost the same as the first two games in the series. An easy to use combat system which makes you counter and parry enemy sword swings whilst you weave in your own attacks. I found the combat system to be very clunky and not very responsive to your input.  Whilst in combat you are able to use your range weapon too; I found this to be a rather pointless addition as it misses the majority of the time even on much bigger targets.  You are able to freely explore the world and take on plenty of side quests. Each of the quests has different ways to solve them, which is a nice element, depending on how you resolve the quest; you may even get a different outcome.  I liked the fact you can play the game in almost any order you choose, meaning you can mould your character exactly how you want it to be.

Graphically, I wasn’t too impressed, for me it looks worse than the previous games. I was playing on 4k and it looked really poor. Texture quality was mediocre at best. The lush scenery when exploring islands does redeem itself a bit, but what’s inside that lushness is some really bad looking modelling. The animation and sound effects are so bad, they are sometimes laughable. I believe all modern games should have voice acting in, and sadly Risen 3 has some absolutely awful voice actors. Every single word that is spoken just feels out of place and does not match up with the game play at all. It almost made the cut scenes unbearable sometimes. During the first fifteen minutes of gameplay, there is almost silence. All you hear is the gun fire, no shouting, sound effects of fights, nothing. It just seems to have very poor production values.

The game is pretty easy even when playing on the hard settings. The combat system, when you get a hang of it, is easy to use, meaning you can be taking on larger groups of enemies before too long. A lot of the time throughout the game you will be accompanied by a companion which also makes the combat scenes more easily handled too. I only died a handful of times so there isn’t any major challenge to be found here.

Risen 3 does have a very good amount of content to play through. Each chapter of the game has at least 20+ side quests for you to tackle. Whilst the side quests don’t distract you too much from the main plot, they are a good addition to the game, that rewards you with money and much needed experience for completing them. I didn’t find myself wanting to complete a lot of them though; they are all very samey after you complete half a dozen; the side quests in this game are nothing when you compare it to the likes of Witcher.

The game took me almost twenty five hours to complete, with a fair few of the side missions completed. For me, since I was struggling to get through the abundance of cut scenes and dialogue, I feel that was almost a bit too much, even now I have plenty of side quests I could complete but I honestly don’t think I can put myself through any more of it. You can probably get about 40 hours of content out of this game, and you may even want to consider a second play through given the amount of choice some of the quests offer.

I didn’t have any technical problems whilst playing thankfully. I was able to play at 1440p with all of the graphical settings turned up to max and still have a steady 60 fps. I played the game with keyboard and mouse, as I found that to be best for the previous games in the series, but the game will work perfectly well with a controller since it is in the third person perspective.

To sum up, I believe Risen 3 to be the worst of the series so far. The first two games had better animation and voice acting in than this one, and to some extent, they even looked better graphically.  The game is currently retailing for £24, 99, and sadly I don’t think it’s even worth half of that. If you are a fan of RPG games and the Risen series, I would suggest you wait till it drops to the £10 mark, just so you don’t feel too let down by the poor production values on show here. Whilst the game does have a vast open world exploration feel to it, it just didn’t live up to my expectations for the third game in a really good pirate series.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here.

If you are also interested in joining a group to help you beat your backlog of Steam games, head over to this group

reviewText:
I had fun, at first.  Combat was a bit challenging and the first island I chose to explore was interesting enough.
Then I chose a faction to join.  I joined the mages faction, and then suddenly combat was quite easy.  That alone is not enough to condem this title.

As I started doing more and more quests, the quest NPCs were just annoying to listen too.  They would take thier sweet time to get to the point of what they actually wanted.  I mean, I can deal with a long winded NPC once in a while, but it seemed with just about everyone, I wanted to scream, GET TO THE ♥♥♥♥ING POINT.

Then as I explored even more, I realised everything was the same.  The same monsters, the same scenery, the same ♥♥♥♥ing loot (the difficulty of a chest to unlock has no bearing on the quality of the stuff you find inside), and for the most part, the same quests.

I played the original Risen and liked it.  I just can not get into this one.  I found myself trying to speed through quests, but then when I got to the point where I needed to do all the faction quests dealing with whatever was important to them, my will to play this game just dissolved.  It was not fun, it was a chore.  It was a repetitive chore.  Only the hope for something new had kept me playing, but I do know there isn't anything new under the sun with this game.

Unless you want to play a repetitive open world game where each area is pretty much the same as any other area, then skip this game.

reviewText:
I finished the game right now and well...I have mixed feelings about it. I give a thumbs up because I loved previous Risen games, and want to support the developer which is a semi indy european company, but I'm not sure if I can recommend this.

Ok, the things which Piranha does great in general, does great also in this game: the atmosphere, the exploration, the humor and the side quests. AND Risen 3 does a better job in those things which are generally bad in Piranha games, like it is more polished than previous Risen games, and finally has an approachable fighting system as well, but the story is horrible as usual (even if Risen 2 had a decent story anyway).

So what's the problem? The problem is that the game is not new. RIsen 1 was an interesting game, and then Risen 2 came out and was able to bring some freshness, so they were different and innovative experiences on their own.
But Risen 3 is not more than Risen 1+2 with an updated Risen 2 graphics. It is disappointing even if the game is very enjoyable.

Then for whatewer reason the devs cut the story and the lore of the previous games and introduced a new storyline and arch enemy. It was quiet a WTF?? What made the story more messy is that they made constant references to the happenings of the previous games even if the story line doesn't have any connection with Risen 1+2.
Because the story was uninteresting I felt the game a little longer than I wanted. It is a 40+ hour game, bear in mind.

So should I recommend this game? Well, if you love Piranha Bytes games and want to get all of them, you will buy it. If you enjoyed the previous games but you are not a hardcore fan don't buy it, becuase previous Risen games are better. If you hated them, you will hate also this one.

But for starters maybe this is the most accessable game. It is the most polished out of the 3 ones with the best fighting system, and becuase it has a different story you don't need to play the older games to get into it.

I personally enjoyed it, but I feel it completely skippable.

Piranha Bytes next time you need to try harder coz ppl won't buy your games!!!

reviewText:
(Updated my review below)

Now let me start off my review by saying that this isn't a game for casual players. If you want to mash some buttons and get through stuff alright you're gonna get frustrated and angry.
People who have played Gothic and previous Risen games will feel right at home here though.

The game is in many ways an improvement over Risen 2, I'll sum up all the points I think have been improved over compared to the previous game in the franchise.

+ Much bigger world
+ Tons of quests and things to do
+ Combat at sea against sea monsters (ripped from Assassins Creed Black Flag but still nice)
+ 3 different factions to join (exactly like in gothic 2, you can pick one and stuff will change according to your choice)
+ Magic is back, there are tons of spells and skills for you to learn (Voodoo is back and awesome!)
+ Treasure searching from Risen 2 is back in force and theres a lot of stuff for you to find
+ Companions have more to say and aren't just there like in Risen 2, the game feels more alive. (They give you advice and sometimes really save your life during fights)
+ Less bugs and glitches than in Risen 2 (although there are still a few minor issues)
+ Gorgeous evironments! (Seriously, look at some screenshots!)
+ Music and sound is perfect!
+ Replayablility because of the 3 different factions (You can only join one of them so you can play the game again and experience it in a different way with different skills and everything!)
+ Hilarious dialog sometimes
+ Feels a lot like gothic! (no, seriously it does. The 3 different factions you can join and the overall feel of the game when you're playing is very similar. You even get good references to gothic sometimes throughout the game. Scavengers are in the game and there's a guy called Moe asking for money in front of the tavern :D and those are just a few of them.)
+ Did a quest for a parrot, got 2200 gold and new armor! (10/10)

Unfortunately there are a few things that just aren't that good...
I love the game but in order to make this an honest game review I gotta put the negatives here too.

- Voice acting is a mixed bag (For me it was fine but other players will think it's horrible)
- Armor is really scarce throughout the game, you'll get your faction armor when you join one of them but that's about it.
(It was pretty much the same in the gothic games though)
- The game has frame rate issues
- Enemy AI is horrible sometimes
- ocasional pop in throughout the entire game
- Some graphical glitches here and there
- Clothes of npc's don't look that great sometimes (clipping)
- Combat is challenging in the gothic kind of way, in the beginning you'll have to run away from enemies sometimes. If you wander off and go to deep in some parts of the islands you'll encounter monsters that are way to strong for you. Levelling is slow at first but once you're strong the game is a lot of fun. Gothic was the same and if someone says it isn't they're lying. I've finished Gothic 1 and 2 for like 3 times so I know how the games are. I don't have a problem with this but others will, thats why I said at the beginning that this isn't for casual players.


Overall the game was and still is a lot of fun for me, I'll probably keep playing it for a while like I did with Risen 2. But players that aren't used to this kind of gameplay wont enjoy it as much as I did. I'm sure of that, so my advice to those people would be to play Gothic 2 or try out Risen 2. If you get annoyed as hell and hate the levelling and the overall gameplay of those 2 this isn't the game for you. It doesn't do anything new or inovative, it's made for the fans of those 2 franchises
(Gothic & Risen)

I give this game an 8/10




Update: Just started a new game to see if things are different when you join another faction and they are. I joined the Guardians and I have a different ship and some unique faction quests as well!. I highly recommend players to try the game out a 2nd or even 3rd time to see the changes for themselves.
I know I gave this game an 8/10 but there's just so many good things that i'm seeing that I'm very tempted to raise it to 9 :D

reviewText:
As a fan of the first two games (more so the first) I am very disappointed in this game after waiting a long time for it. I was so happy to hear that the game would be going back to the medieval roots and abandoning the pirate theme but apparently that was scrapped and they stuck with pirates despite keeping the medieval theme on the game cover and the title Titan Lords".

I lked the combat improvement between the first two games where you unlocked abilities that made fighting easier as opposed to being a master at dodging. The combat in this game is the most simple yet the most frustrating to the point I would even prefer to have to dodge every swing to survive.

Right off the bat the game gets too spread out trying to send you to 5 different areas and every other person you meet sends you out of your way to help them. I appreciate the openesss of the story and having options but it feels they tried to drown you in quests just for the purpose of prolonging the time to finish everything.

To top it off
date: the voice acting is terrible compared to any other game I've played and the graphics just don't feel right at all. This is the first game that I felt obligated to give a negative review and hopefully it will be the last."

reviewText:
Risen 3 - Titan Lords
Risen 3 - Titan Lords is a fantastic RPG focused on story, and nothing else. If you are really into it, its brought to the perfetion, almost every detail, dozens of characters, hundreds of quests and thousands of conversation lines. You can get really deep into almost every NPC story, find out what happened to them, what they think, need or want. I really appreciate this system and especially that these lines are not repetitive. Very often you have got more options how to solve a task or proceed through conversation tree. Mixing pirates, mages, natives, demon hunters and underworld was really nicely done in this game, making it much more interesting than previous title.

On the other side fighting and talent systems are really bad and boring, with time you just walk and kill using only the same few clicks, after a few hours skills are developed enough that you needn't to improve them,  but if you pass over this fact the game is really exciting.


7/10

reviewText:
I've had played Gothic 1, 2 and 3 (multiple times) + Risen 1 & 2, so I am pretty familiar with Piranha Byte games

TL;DR;
PB ♥♥♥♥ed up again.
This game isn't worth 50€
25€ would have been appropriate.
I lost hope in PB, won't buy anything from PB for now.


This game is even worse than Risen 2. I would even call it Risen 2.5.

The game pretty much feels like Risen 2 with factions. The fighting system is again pretty flawed and boring.
I wish the developers would just take the one from Gothic 2 ... It was challenging and got never boring at all.
This fighting system is a left click spamming fest to be honest.

The story feels like it was made one week before release.
The quests are boring and dull.
The voice acting (German) is pretty bad and unimaginative. The jokes are also lame and cringe-making.


The graphics are the same from Risen 2 and aren't even decent. Many textures are blurry and everything looks unfinished.


PB used to make great games with a great stories, a believable world and interesting and challenging quests.
This game however feels like it was made quickly just to make money without any love.

PB, please just make games like Gothic 1 and 2 again. I know you can do it.
voteText: 357 of 603 people (59%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Once again a traditional Piranha Bytes title with all its flaws, rough around the edges, feels unfinished sometimes, very very bad beginning and end, almost only tedious fetch/kill quests, ancient facial animations and many more.
I hate almost all new mechanics like the sea fights and especially the whole underworld/ghost parts.
Just finished the game in about 40h and already forgot most of the weak story.
The different factions you can join almost make no difference as you will travel around a game world that is 90% accessible right after the prologue and you will do almost all quests of all the factions anyway.

Balancing is abysmal, I would say even worse than the early Gothic 3.
The game starts extremely hard, you will probably die most of your deaths in the forst 5 hours.

At some point when you master the combat mechanics, got some decent equipment and learned nice skills, the gameplay is actually pretty good. Sadly, it wears off after only a few hours. Most combats are the same, you will probably take the same companion with you 95% of the time and the only interesting situations will arise from glitches.

The second half of the game will be one long grind towards completing most quests, looting and killing everything there is, because skilling and learning the important stuff from trainers gets extremely expensive.
You will not see a single new creature/enemy in the second half of the game.
But you will have to suffer through the worst boss fights in the history of all PB games, which is ridiculous, because they somehow built up a reputation for having the worst end fights with Risen 1 & 2 already.

I could go on ranting about many other things, some of which were certainly designed by the Devs on purpose because they are sadists and we the fans are certainly a bit masochistic in return.

Nevertheless, once again it is somehow a good game in many aspects as well. For me mostly because the world that has been created is amongst the most atmospheric and credible game worlds I ever experienced. The factions are interesting, the islands are astonishing, the level design with the incredible attention to detail is still one of a kind.
The music is beautiful and the voice actors are solid, with a few brilliant exceptions.

While many of the main characters are boring and bland, a few save the day, for me these are the gnomes and bones.

I'm happy that I decided to give the game a few second chances when I felt like quitting and after all finished the game.
My only regret is that I wasted a lot of time collectiong stuff I never needed.

TLDR:
If you liked any other Piranha Bytes Game, get Risen 3, it is better than Risen 2 and the most impressive in regards to the game world.
If you are new and curious about this rough little gem, get it in a sale and read some beginners guides.

reviewText:
I've really enjoyed all of the Risen games so far. Lots of freedom, very little hand-holding, lots of toys, interesting characters and locations. On the down side this is the easiest in the series so far. The strong challenge and lack of world-levelling - where the enemies get more powerful as you progress - was my favorite thing about the earlier games. It makes things VERY satisfying when you get that new spell or item and finally crack a previously almost invincible enemy.

I blame those negative reviewers who haven't really understood the earlier Risen games for the dramatic drop in difficulty here..

It's very much a marmite game - you will love it or hate it.

voteText: 234 of 401 people (58%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Full Video Review here - http://youtu.be/fQLQ3mlkeuM

Hello once again I'm Cosmic and welcome to the latest addition to the Risen franchise, Risen 3 Titan Lords. Risen 3 was developed by German developer Piranha bites who are well known for their previous titles including the Gothic franchise as well as the previous two Risen titles. Published by Deep Silver, Risen 3 was touted to be a throwback to the first Risen title by once again boasting more open world and exploration based game play.

Risen 3 takes a break from the unnamed hero of the first two games. Instead you start the game as the son of the famous pirate Captain Steelbeard thus being brother to Patty a familiar face from the last two games who also features once again in this instalment. Searching for treasure on the mysterious crab coast you soon come across a skull cave that has 'Risen' from the ground, get it? Within the cave itself a skull lord appears and steals the soul of the pirate who seemingly dies. Upon regaining is life thanks too a strange shaman doctor known as Bones, another typical cheesy risen joke. The pirate begins a quest around the southern isles to reclaim his soul and ultimately stop this new threat.

Moving away from the more linear and heavily pirate themed second instalment. Risen 3 has gone back to the multi-factional open world style of the first. In Risen 3 you are able to travel throughout the southern isles to visit and explore islands such as Antigua, Taranis,Calador and other familiar places from the previous games. One thing I do really like so far is that exploration really does reap rewards as you can find loot, quests and secret areas in a variety of ways. One new gameplay feature in particular is the ability to swim, while it sounds a little silly it actually becomes a great exploration tool as you can swim offshore to discover secret islands full of loot.

One of the positive traits about Risen 3 in terms of travel is in its free-form design. You can just head off in a direction and explore, with the only thing stopping you in your tracks being enemies that you are not ready for. Once you finish the starting section you can go to any island that is available to you at that time. You don't have to do the islands in a specific sequence which adds replay ability particularly when you take the factions into account. While on an Island you can travel on foot or fast travel to the various portals once activated. One useful mode of transport is a magic spell that transforms you into a flying parrot, while you cant stay in this mode for long its great if you've just travelled up a mountain and want a quick route down. It's especially useful for those of us with kleptomania as the parrot flight allows you to fly into locations otherwise inaccessible by foot.

The games combat has always been notoriously difficult throughout the series. One click attacking combined with clunky movement can become very tedious and outright frustrating. The start of the game is particularly tedious as your character has next to know abilities other than basic attacks and basic melee blocking. It can end up meaning that those who like to play on the harder difficulty settings will spend hours upon frustrated hours dying against relatively minor enemies especially in group situations. As you progress in the game, improving your stats and acquiring new abilities from trainers, combat becomes a hell of a lot easier. The combat system overall is massively improved from Risen 2 however it still suffers from fundamental flaws that have plagued the series since conception. Clunky movement, issues with focusing on enemies and of course pistol shots missing from point blank range are all back once again.

The major redeeming feature about combat this time round is the return of crystal magic. The developers took out magic in Risen 2 something which was largely complained about upon its release. Thankfully magic is back in force this time and I would argue it is the best way to deal with the majority of enemies as not only does it pack a hell of a punch but its the less frustrating option for group encounters. Luckily which ever faction you decide to join, all offer various forms of magical abilities so no matter how you build your character you will have some form of magic to fall back on.

Those familiar with the previous titles won't find much different when it comes to character progression. To improve your characters array of stats you must accumulate glory points. Glory is earned for the completion of quests as well as killing enemies. On top of this to improve particular stats and gain new abilities you must find trainers which are dotted throughout the world. However to learn from trainers costs gold and depending on what you are trying to learn you must be prepared to part with a substantial amount. There are also special items hidden throughout the world which you can recover which add a permanent boost to stats these can be gain via exploration or through reading books to acquire the specific quests.

While character progression is solid, I've never liked the way the developers have insisted on putting trainers in the game. The main reason behind this is because you really need the abilities they offer and having to pay gold for them, especially early on when large amounts of gold is not easy to come by is a massive frustration. One thing annoys me even further is particularly when it comes to the sword fighting if your a melee focused character. The ability to riposte is essential against some tougher enemies and a life saver in group encounters. Yet even though your playing as a pirate captain you don't have this ability from the start. You must go to find a trainer and then pay gold to get it which is ridiculous.

As I've mentioned there are factions in the game to which you can join one. The three factions include the mages, demon hunters and a voodoo tribe. Each faction offers an array of faction specific abilities and quests. Once you join a faction your able to then gain better ranks within that faction which unlocks better gear, quests and abilities. However once you join a faction you cannot join another so choose carefully. Thanks to the freedom that the game allows you can travel and complete the majority of quests on each factions island before making your decision of which to join. I ended up join the mages faction known as the guardians, one for the magical abilities and two for the cool eye piece.

Graphically the game is good but not great. On the PC specifically I would have liked to see a lot higher texture resolutions as much of it looks very last generation console. The world however does look good and immersive. There are some glitches and bugs to be found throughout but these tend to be minor. Sadly once again Risen 3 follows suit in the terrible lip syncing animations as well as poor facial animations as a whole. Similar to the previous games the voice acting and scripting is full of off colour humour and outright cheese. Some of the voice acting isn't terrible but some is just cringe worthily bad.

Overall those familiar with the Risen and Gothic series will be right at home with Risen 3. Any avid RPG player will be able to sink their teeth into Risen 3 and find a good amount of enjoyment from it. However I wonder if many people will not be able to get past the difficulty of the combat at the start, it does require a certain amount of perseverance that I think will send more casual players running for the hills. Risen 3 is certainly a large improvement on the second and there’s a good degree of enjoyable content in the game. At the end of the day, if you enjoy a decent RPG then Risen 3 will be for you however those looking for a more streamlined RPG experience may wish to look to more mainstream titles.

reviewText: The first few hours of Risen 3 feels similar to its predecessor, with slightly dated graphics and a shortage of polish. However, patience is a virtue, and as you progress, a fun and addicting longing for adventure prevails. Piranha Bytes is known for its imagination in the genre of RPGs, and Risen 3 is yet another fine example.\n\nThis game is full of charms, and will keep you entertained for many hours. The voice acting is good, quests feel authentic and give you a sense of importance, and the overall objectives are virtually always clear. There is room for improvement in graphics and final polishing, but I'd give Risen 3 a solid 8 out of 10. It doesn't quite rival the brilliance of Skyrim, but for RPG fans, it's still a no brainer.

reviewText:
I think that the decision whether or not to recommend this game was quite a close one for me because while the game does have allot going against it on paper it was still fun to play I just think that it got held back because unfortunately no one area of the game stood out as having been particularly well executed throughout.

On the one hand the levels are quite well done and there is allot to do in the game, plus you have a wide variety of choices when deciding on how to build your character so you don’t have to decide what play style you want to employ up front. There are also a wide variety of side quests to pursue which provide quite a few hours of entertainment. The crew of your ship which you will build up over time are interesting as they will make comments as you travel with them, some of which are fairly amusing. Another thing that I liked was the skill system, to many games have long complex skill trees that don’t feel like they contribute to much more than the player stats. In risen 3 you can learn any skill you want and allot of the spells are interesting to play with, from being able to blink around the field to turning yourself into a parrot to more aggressive combat spells there is allot to play and experiment with. While I know that some people have had stability issues I’ve yet to crash once and fps drops are small and few so I personally think that the game is fairly stable.

On the other hand this game does disappoint particularly as you progress, this is due to your character becoming overpowered and there being no real counter balance making combat a chore as the enemies don’t become notably stronger or varied also meaning that there is little incentive to mix things up. Another damming issue is that you don’t have to get too far into the game to have seen every enemy except the bosses. Graphics were another issue, while the environment may be appealing the rest is fairly sub-standard and broken graphics and clipping are a common issue. It’s also fairly easy to glitch a quest with issues ranging from broken markers through to the quest being impossible to finish effectively breaking the game forcing you to either load an earlier save or start a new game. while the game does have some replay value from joining different factions and completing different quests it could do with some incentive to start a new game such as unlocking (significantly) harder difficulties or additional content. I think that the straw that broke the horses back though was the highly anti-climactic endgame. The last few quests and the final cut scene were extremely disappointing because allot of what you had done to that point seemed to fizzle out leaving you asking the question “what, is that it! What the (inset preferred term to express outrage)!”

pros:
.interesting environment
.the story was great up until the last chapter
.fully voiced (though it’s kind of expected in this sort of game these days)
.interesting characters not the best ever but still ok
.stable

cons:
.not challenging after a point + various balancing issues
.anti-climactic ending and no closer
.can bug out on you either quest markers or in a breaking way
.poor graphics

In conclusion I felt that while the game was fun to play it doesn’t feel finished and while I can accept that not all games are going to be polished to a mirror shine they need to pick up the slack in some regard whether that be through the story or the gameplay mechanics and risen 3 ultimately just didn’t do that.

reviewText:
Firstly, although my game time says 4 hours, my save file says 6. 6 hours of gameplay might not be enough to properly review this game, it seems to be improving, but is all the time I am willing spend here for now. I bought this game based on the various reviews here swearing that the game will get better, but honestly, who wants to go through 5 or 6 hours of gameplay before having fun?

The combat is clunky. The attacks are not responsive, the characters go through pirouettes, leaps and lunges to deliver a single blow. At the beginning of the game the delay between the strikes in your 3-hit combo are long enough to allow the enemy to interrupt you every single time. You will be reduced to using the same hit and roll tactic for next 3 hours, whittling away at the enemy's health while your companion does most of the heavy lifting... Unless the companion AI suddenly decides to stop attacking or has gotten stuck somewhere, in that case whittle away.

On the other hand, as you progress you acquire new types of weapons and skills that really add up to the combat. It can still be frustrating, but after 5 hours or so (your mileage might vary depending on the places you visit first and how you develop your character) you start to see where the combat is trying to go. I do not if it eventually gets there, I will update this review when I revisit the game.

This might be surprising, but the combat isn't what finally pushed me away from the game. It is the conversation that did it for me, and that is quite sad because they went through the effort of voicing pretty much everything. The problem is that the conversations meander so much, there are so many exchanges in one conversation branch that hold no value, they don't develop the characters, they don't introduce lore, nor do they mimic normal conversation. It is really, baffling how much extra effort went where it needed to.

I understand that a complaint for the previous game was the lack of voiced acting or how little voice acting there was, I am not too sure about this, but regardless, there is just too much useless and pointless dialogue in this game, but I might have been able to take if it wasn't for the horrible voice acting.  That's right, there is awkward writing being voiced very badly. This is the first time that this has affected my gameplay so much that I have stopped playing.

All that said, the game has the potential to improve plenty, perhaps by the 15th hour everything else would be sufficiently enjoyable that you can look past the scrip and voice acting, but if that is the case, it would be better to wait for this game to go on sale, currently it isn't worth the asking price.

reviewText: Always a little worried what kind of game you might be getting from Pirahna Bytes after the Gothic 3 debacle.  While Risen 3 was marketed as a return to a more medieval traditions of the Gothic series and Risen 1, it still is very close with the pirate theme seen in Risen 2, something that put some players off but was a plus to me, as a person who gets tired of seeing the same setting in every fantasy RPG to be released.  What does return though, is a more open world, literally tons of quests with branching options and the return of joinable factions.  The combat is more refined than Risen 2, it flows a lot better.  The main story is typical save the world that is seen in most RPGs but the path to get there through the faction stories is more unique.  I really enjoyed Risen 3 and hope it is not the final installment of the series.  Pirahna Bytes really hit the nail on the head with this one.

reviewText:
beautiful. just finished what i'm hoping is not the last pirahna bytes game. and even though i don't really write reviews and am new to steam i figured the newest edition to my favorite series deserves a shout out. i discovered risen 1 a couple years ago in a bargain bin and didnt expect much... just a no name company with what looked like a simplistic, guided rpg.... i was surprised at the little details put into it that i had never seen before and a friend told me about gothic.  my next was gothic 3 which to this day is my favorite game right up there with skyrim, fallout 3, kotor.

their games seem to get a lot of flack, and i think that is mostly for the combat system... which i always thought was fine. no this isn't a world where you start off hacking through hoards of enemies seamlessly, if you want an action game... get an action game.

if you want a role-playing experience where you are put into the shoes of a character and asked to build them and guide them through a process than all of their games are great(though don't get the steam version of gothic 2 one of the steam patches broke it and it stopped booting in the fifth chapter for me..... all my disc versions have been fine though)

first off, all their games are 'deceptively' open world. meaning, you look at a mini map( in the later ones) and see roads and mountains and assume you are supposed to take those roads. one of the things i find so wonderful about their games is: yes, they offer a road.... but if you don't follow it they reward you.

risen 3 doesn't have the greatest feeling of accomplishment and i think that may be do to making teleporting easier. teleportation stones used to be a big prize and this feels more similar to arcania.... too many stones means you aren't excited about it any more. though that could just be compared to gothic 3 which had the biggest moment of score!" of any game i had ever played with finding all 6 druid stones when people online would all swear their were only 5 and the mentioning of the 6th was a bug. finding something that the internet hadn't found for years... that makes a game stick with you.

this one didn't have as many of those moments

reviewText:
I love Risen 3 in its current form. Through the 30 or more hours it’ll take you to complete the game, you’ll encounter so many locations, characters and situations that it takes far too much time to talk about in detail. Little things, like the two loonies with Anatidaephobia, or bouncer at the tavern on Calador who has the same name as the bouncer in Gothic 2. Risen 3 won’t do anything to win you over if you hated the previous instalments of the series. But then again, that really just means this series isn’t for you. Risen 3 is no huge leap forward, but instead focuses on small but considerable improvements and additions to the formula. It’s not perfect, and you might not feel there’s enough new for your liking, but for me it was just enough. I was never bored throughout my adventure, there was always something new to do, someplace new to discover. The seemingly small environments were teeming with enough life that it felt a lot bigger than it might look on a map. It might not be the proper sequel to Gothic 2 we’ve all been waiting for, but it does its job well enough for me to accept it into the collection.

4/5

reviewText:
Risen 3 promises to bring back the best features from the previous titles in the series as well as features from the Gothic series. In the next installment of the Risen franchise, you are a new hero who must fight the oncoming Titan attack. The world is crumbling, island by island and you must build up a resistance to fight against the horde of Titans. Your soul has also been stolen and you must figure out how to regain it back, claiming it as yours as it once was.

Risen 3 is quite an improvement from its predecessor: Risen 2 in all the right places. The animations, skills, exploration, and graphics have all been upgraded. One of the reasons the Risen series is not enjoyable for gamers is due to its frustrating combat. I can attest to being very frustrated with the combat in Risen 2. The combat in Risen 3 has not been improved very dramatically. The combat system is mostly the same except for a few tweaks. You will still get frustrated at one point or another, but continuing through the story definitely has its benefits.

The animations during fighting battles have vastly improved, easily having the best animation work out of the Risen series to date. Skills also pour into the combat system more than ever. Yes, you still have to use money to purchase skills. Yes, you still have to use glory to purchase skills. But, the skills you learn in Risen 3 are more beneficial than any other skills in the Risen series. The skills provide players a somewhat easier time in each fight because they are learning extra skills that will help in combat, providing for quicker and more efficient kills.

Where Risen 3 really shines is its exploration and its storyline. You are a new hero in the Risen universe who has his soul ripped out from a Titan Lord and must get it back. Simple premise, but its a little more complicated. When you wake up, a war between the Titans and humans is going on and your hero is caught in the middle of it. He is then sent to destroy Titan portals, to keep Titans from entering the world as well as forming an alliance between the remaining island factions to ensure humans are victorious. The storyline provides hundreds of quests that people can give you to do in exchange for money, items, or even glory. The quests can range anywhere from Kill x Amount of Bloodhounds" to recovering stolen items. Factions and exploration are a few main features of Risen 3. You can join three factions: Demon Hunters
recommended: or the Guardians. Joining one over the other reaps different benefits than another. You may also only be able to learn skills if you are a specific faction

The storyline provides anywhere from 10-50 hours of gameplay; depending on how many hours you spend on exploring and how many hours you spend on doing the wide variety of quests.\n\nSomething came back to the Risen franchise. Magic. There is still Voodoo magic

reviewText:
I've played and finished Risen and Risen 2, and as a fan, I think that this game is even better then my spectations. In Risen 3 they brought back the elements most missed from the first game, in addition to the things that already had in the second game. If you played Risen 1 and Risen 2 you must think already that the change of the charaters appearance is kinda common from game to game. But I don't want to discuss about that.

Well, risen 3 showed a big advance on the mechanics of the plot for two reasons: In the previous games there were only 2 factions to choose (Risen: Monastery and Bandit Camp| Risen 2: Inquisition and the Natives) and in Risen 3 you'll have 3 factions (guardians, demon hunters and voodoo warriors) and also you can choose the side that you will be (of the humans or of the demons) that is decided according to what you do to people. And the second is that the faction and the side that you choose will interfere on the main story of the game.

The game brought back also the crystal and rune magic from the first game, without letting away the voodoo magic. It also has new kinds of weapons based on the first game.

With so many things that are based on the first and second game, we can say that Risen 3 is the sum of the others, with some things more.

reviewText:
Tired of open-world exploration? Confused by multiple dialouge options? Baffled by combat with more than two options? Have we got the game for you! Standard Third-Person RPG: Pirate Flavor is right up your alley! Follow along with Gravelvoice McNeverShave and his sister ♥♥♥♥ McNoArmor as they do vaugely pirate-themed things! This game includes such jaw-dropping innovations as:

-Invisible Walls! No more will you have to dread the freedom of exploration! With our patented Invisible Corner system, you won't go anywhere we don't want you to! And sometimes you won't go places we do want you to!

-Combat! With light, heavy AND ranged* attacks you no longer have to devote any thought to strategy! Simply push the attack button until the enemy dies! And with our No-Gain HP system, even trival combat with early-game eneimes will be delightfully treacherous as 3-4 hits will always kill you! Combined with unblockable enemy attacks and unbreakable enemy guard, you will worry about literally every fight! And there's thousands of them!

-Talking! Enjoy choosing from up to TWO dialouge options when talking to characters with the personality of wet cardboard WHILE listening to a character voice so real you'll swear you were talking to a man with a twleve pack-a-day habit!

-Moral Choices! When confronted with a burning orphanage, you can choose to either help the orphans trapped inside OR roast hot dogs over their buring flesh! Sometimes, you won't even know you're making a choice!

-Graphics! With our dynamic light system , you'll be hard-pressed to differentiate rocks from enemy models until they attack! And then it's too late! Plus, NPC's come in up to THREE different models!**

-Useless Minigame! Since doing literally everything other than combat is based off of skills (which involves finding trainers, spending gold, and solving Fermat's last Theorem) you'll be presented with literally pointless lock-picking, arm-wrestling, knife-throwing, and many more!

-Exploration! Never again will you have to worry about trying to find the right hallway! All you have to do is keep going forward! Don't even worry about venturing to outlying areas! If a quest doesn't send you there, we've ensured that it's not worth your time!

-AND SO MUCH MORE! Order now, operators are standing by!

Side effets may include swearing, sweating, rage-quitting, game-breaking bugs, lack of autosave, lack of character growth, lack of character development, and questioning of life decisions. Do not mix with other RPG's. Ask your doctor if Standard Third-Person RPG: Pirate Flavor is right for you.

*Ranged attacks not actually ranged.
**Excluding female models. Those are limited to sexy and sexier.

reviewText:
Good game, but still same problems.

PB will never learn apparently..either they are incredibly stupid or stubborn.  They make a good game, with a very detailed believable game world, a workable leveling system, an all around solid open world RPG BUT the combat is horrible, the fighting is just always the weakest link with PB.

If you have ever played a PB RPG before you know exactly what to expect.  I am bewildered as to whats up with PB and the fighting in thier games.

In this iteration, the guy does overly elaborate second...two second long animations twirling around flipping the sword behind his back before just friggin attacking...Its awkward, badly paced and not very good.  You just spam the dodge key doing acrobatics to get out of harm, then do some long stupid overly fancy attack move when all you want to do is friggin swing your sword at the monster standing infront of you...no need to twirl all over the place...And what ever happened to shields sheesh...
voteText: 134 of 241 people (56%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I like all the Piranha Bytes games. They have their own atmosphere, hand-crafted environment and rough dialogues. Exploration is written in capital letters.

This is the third in the Risen series but it's its own fun world. You can explore various very distinct islands, from northern Calador to the tropical island Kila. I don't know any other games that are so much fun just exploring. You run/climb/swim to your next treasure. The NPCs alll have their stories to tell in a lot of quests. The main story is nothing to write home about but I found myself enjoying everything else the game has (like parrot flights and monkey training).

A little balancing would have gone a long way: The game is too easy after one third of it.

But don't let the Angry Joe Army and metacritic score scare you. If you like exploring and RPGs, this game has it.

reviewText:
+ I like the story, freedom of movement  and the ability to choose which order you do everything.

- Mob difficulty, it seems to be flat across the board meaning stuff is hard at the beginning but later in the game you are practically immortal unless you step off a high ledge.

- Itemization, you mostly run around in the same gear and use 2 maybe 3 weapons throughout the game. Merchants sell the same stuff all over and there isnt much difference, I like to continually build up a character but felt like 90% was the same old crap or same stats.

Still think it's worth playing through but could be better.
voteText: 29 of 47 people (62%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It is what Risen 2 should have been in some ways while still making partly the same mistakes and also introducing new stuff that mostly isn't needed.

The world is much more interesting than the world in Risen 2 and the factions are nice but QTE, cutscenes and stuff like moral system and astral vision don't need to be in this game.
The game tries to hard to pander to everyone: Gothicfans, Risenfans, Risen2fans.
And so it only does a half-decent job.

It's still a good game and definitely an upgrade to Risen 2 but for the next game Piranha Bytes definitely need to listen to their own community even more.

reviewText: I do not understand why people complain so much about bad voice acting and combat system. All PB games have that problem. I believe it would be appropriate to say that PB games offer specific experience which one will love or hate, if you didn’t like previous ones you will most definitely hate this one. My problem with this game is different, it is ridiculously short and after 25h I have done nearly everything I could. Game feels shorter and smaller then Risen 2. I was expecting that using the same engine etc will allow them to make bigger world, and more quests. I enjoyed time spent with it but I cannot recommend spending GBP40 for game which simply doesn’t deserve it, Adding 30h (I assume that this is how much you need to do everything) to existing game is worth GBP20 at best.
voteText: 63 of 111 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
If u loved Risen 1 and 2 u will love this.

Bit easier than Risen 1 and 2 for these reasons:

1. more beginner friendly
2. Interface is easier to understand
3. Having an ally all the time to tank is great
4. Quests are easier to track and are a bit TOO helpful that sometimes i choose not to track for a challenge
5. Easier to lvl up

What I like about this game:

1. Lots of factions to join
2. Open world to look around and explore from very early on in the game
3. Lvling up makes u feel stronger and makes it worthwhile

Some things that are not so good:

1. Not as polished as a AAA title
2. Some game breaking bugs which need fixing
3. Simplification from Risen 1 and 2 makes the game less immersive than its predecessors

Overall, if you liked the Gothic series and the Risen series I recommend this game to you.
But if you are looking for a AAA experience such as ES then perhaps look a bit deeper before you purchase

reviewText:
(The game took me 35-40 hours to complete, Steam failed to record some of them, so the displayed amount is missing at least 8 hours) If you know Piranha Bytes and their history, you know what you're getting yourself into: A unique and memorable adventure with quirks both major and minor. Virtually everyone would like to see another proper Gothic game, but PB is keeping in mind what the market lacks at any given time and what the publisher may be willing to shell out money for. Back in 2012, it made sense for them to try out a different setting for Risen 2. After all, it had to compete with the likes of Skyrim, and a small studio such as PB has to pick its battles. Risen 2 was a sequel developed from scratch (content-wise) – no easy task, I imagine. They probably could not afford to ditch it all again for Risen 3 and instead opted for a more iterative approach, applying a thin layer of Gothic in the meantime to please the impatient fans. Thus, it feels more like a very large content update to Risen 2 than a true sequel, and PB have not quite delivered on their promise to go back to their roots. I'm not going to talk about story and graphics, as those elements are just solid, do the job and do not stand out to me. What does stand out, is the world.


The world:

The islands can be visited in any order this time around. They have been lovingly crafted, with many small highlights and cheekily placed treasures waiting to be uncovered. Carefully placed objects tell stories without using words, such as skeletons surrounded by bottles of rum in a secluded spot or a monkey messing around among bananas, voodoo dolls and corpses. There were countless occasions of these enriching little things that never failed to make me smile or ask myself WTF happened here?". The world is teeming with quests (300+ of them) that mostly revolve around fetching and killing stuff. Their presentation through funny and witty dialogue (which does have its cheesy moments) makes them rewarding to complete beyond the glory and loot you get. Swearing is indeed overused
date: which is a trademark and a welcome recurring theme in the German version
recommended: but probably superfluous in the eyes of the English audience. The world and the characters that populate it can suck you in for countless hours at a time. What bothers me is the use of recycled locations from Risen 2 (such as Antigua and Tacarigua)

retain their Carribean atmosphere.

reviewText:
Great game. I Loved Risen and Risen 2 before this. the aliasing was a bit disappointing when first started up, but using Nvidia's 4K DSR makes the graphics very good indeed - and I'm a stickler for good visuals. Risen is a feel good RPG with great (although remade at times from Risen 2) locations, quests and characters along the way, each having a distict personality. Repeating a location isn't all that bad, it adds familiarity and adds continuity from the previous storylines.

The Combat, for me, is great, not clunky at all, very simple but the amount of weapons and options you have for defeating foes is plentiful. Do you really want to have a long, drawn out fight with one of the hundred Scavengers in the game, or just get it out of the way quickly and move around and explore, loot chests and complete quests? For me RPG's like Risen 3 (and the first two) are built for exploring, not getting into 5 minute fights at every turn.

The DLCs are worth getting too, adds hours of extra gameplay and great bonus items, more great quest storylines too! Sad to have completed it! Though maybe I'll find the time to get some replay value by playing as another faction...

For me, an easy 8/10 all things considered.  Personally, a 9/10 - playing games is about enjoyment, right?
voteText: 15 of 22 people (68%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
It's not a bad game. It's like a mix of Risen and Gothic 3 and Two Worlds II. You get to play as Captain Steelbeard's son who is your typical hotheaded pirate that loves adventure and treasure hunting. And man his sister is hot. xD

The detail in the world is amazing. You have to take the time to just look at everything. Explore and find hidden paths and secrets and LOOT LOOT LOOT. You will be looting your a$$ off in this game.

The controls need work though, I found the controls when fighting to be a little clunky but damn if that Dark Souls type dodge roll button didn't save my a$$ several times when I got caught up in an ambush. I was spamming that button like mad. And there was a nice bit of satisfaction when in a sword fight and finishing off the threat by blasting it with my pistol.
Oh and speaking of finishing off. I like that sometimes you will see a finishing animation after a fight. It's not shown often like in other games where you get tired of seeing the same finishing animations over and over, but you will see them here and there and it mixes up pretty well by offering different types of finishing animations and camera views like when ramming your sword in a guys stomach or catching him from behind in a struggle to cut his neck open with your sword for example. Badass! :D

I was pretty impressed with the detail and animation of the beasts. Wait until you run into that damn alligator. It scared the heck out of me the first time, chasing my a$$ all over the place, the damn thing was relentless. But the detail and its animation was nice.

The NPCs that join up with you actually help you out. I had left an NPC behind and I wandered off, and next thing I know I was caught up in an ambush. I thought I was dead for sure, Dark Souls dodge rolling all over the place for my life. Next thing I see the NPC running to save my a$$ and he casts a heal spell on me almost immediately and starts kicking the sh!# out the threat. I was like O.O

One more thing I have to mention. Even though the voice acting is... terrible, you will laugh at the dialogue. There is some serious humor and cursing in this game. LOL. Try wandering off in the beginning and your sister will ask you. Hey
date: where you going? Do you even know what your doing? Are you Fu#%ing lost?" And you can choose to hide behind your pride and answer back
recommended: "No I'm not Fu#%ing lost! I know exactly what I'm doing!" Knowing damn well you don't. xD\n\nAnyway
hoursPlayed: I can say I am happy with this game. It is fun and very satisfying. :)\nI will keep you guys posted with whatever awesome stuff I find throughout the game. ^ ^"

reviewText: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RW0bFgjnNiQ\n\nRisen 3 provides an interesting romp  through its fictitious locales with an overflowing amount of things to do , comprehensive character progression, and the chance to do things differently depending on the choices made. Despite a few negatives here and there with things like getting stuck in the scenery, not enough variety with the combat and the view being obscured by foliage when in battle, the game runs smoothly and plays well. Considering its price point, gamers will get their monies worth in terms of hours, and there’s enough intrigue to keep battling on to see what happens next despite some dodgy dialogue and shallow performances.  If you’re a fan of action role playing games, then there’s a lot to like about Risen 3 which offers some pleasant and open ended adventuring.

reviewText:
Much bad has been said about R3. Is it really that bad?
No. Not at all. Except you hated R2 or R1, then you won't find anything good here too.

Don't like that pirate-setting? It's just the tutorialmap, afterwards there is not very much of that left.

Personally i liked it, even though it often feels less mature than Gothic1,2,3. But hey, it's not that you're drowning in major quality RPGs to be picky, is it? :)

It does many things better than R2 (combat, feats, size of world) and it does many things equally good/bad (quite shallow story, ocasionally repetitive fights, etc.) but in the end it's still funny to explore, find the secrets, discover things, visit new islands, fight sea monsters, have sea battles, take different companions with you, etc.

Biggest plus is that the companions (of which there are some to choose) now respond more to the world you are and to the things you do. Sadly their commentary in battles start getting repetitive and annoying pretty soon.

Although the Gnomes are not nearly as funny as Borderland's Claptrap, they're quite cute and often good for a smile.

One plus to mention is the balancing. I'm the explorer type and discovered nearly everything so the final island (which is not really small) i could master in well earned god-mode :)
So if you're just rushing through it, it could be a bit more challenging.

tl;dr: Recommended if you liked Gothic1,2,3 or Risen1&2. If you didn't like them, keep miles away!

reviewText: If you play RPG's for immersion and exploration (ala Skyrim, Fallout 3), you should probably ignore the negative reviews and give Risen 3 a shot. The world is large and incredibly detailed with many sizeable islands each with their own unique look, feel and questlines. The combat is not frustrating like in previous Risen games, its a bit on the easy side but quite enjoyable once you learn some skills and spells. The game looks good and the economy is well balanced so you always have reason to just head off into the wilderness in search of loot to sell or hidden quests.\n\nWhile previous Risen games had slow, difficult starts that confined you to a small area, once you get past the opening sequence which lasts about an hour Risen 3 opens up entirely. The main storyline is not good at all, but there are lots of interesting side quests and colourul characters to talk to. If you have been curious about trying a Pirhana Bytes game but are worried about a slow start or a long learning curve, Risen 3 is a great entry point into one of the most underrated series of the last five or so years.
