reviewText:
If I had to describe this game in one sentence it would be this:
This game is like that really bad B movie on the syfy channel at 2'o clock in the morning that you just cant help but watch even though you have to get up at 6am to get to that meeting you didn't prepare for because you like to procrastinate.

The voice acting is wonderfully bad, the camera is like a mini game all in itself, and the combat will have you're character constantly somersaulting all over the place like an old circus performer trying to show the new boss he's still got it, usually rolling into more enemies you couldn't see while battling the camera, but it embraces the pirate theme with unashamed glee, using every opportunity to drop the f-bomb and preach the many miraculous powers of booze.

And god help me if I don't love this game.

If you want a good pirate rpg this is it. The only thing really holding it back from being great, in my opinion, is the lack of ship management/travel and far too few ship combat segments.

My advice: plug in a controller, flip it on easy, somersault like no one's watching, and let the terrible B movie magic take you away.


*no you don't need to play 1 or 2 to enjoy this. In fact, you'll probably like it more if you didn't play the first 2.

reviewText: Practically the same game that Risen 2 was; same levels, same characters, same quest types and so on. Horrible voice acting and plain ugliness don't help much either. reviewText:
Risen 3 offers great entertainment value. It was designed to be fun and enjoyable to play for a more casual gamer, or a gamer that enjoys some pleasant and relaxed gameplay once in a while.

What sets this game apart from other action-rpgs is the beautiful handcrafted world that is a joy to explore, no other developer can compete with Piranha Bytes in this respect.

The game offers a light-hearted story that is well told, and a lot of side quests.
You eventually get a good ship and start building your crew of companions, each with their own stories, personalities and side quests.
The assortment of skills and spells is very nice and varies somewhat depending on what faction you chose to join.
The character progression is fairly fast compared to previous games.

The one thing that is most important about the combat is to NOT tap the attack button repeatedly. Tap once, wait for the move to reach its peak then tap again, with a bit of practice you will get the timing which is very forgiving. You can also tap by listening to the sound. The dodge move has 100% invincibility window, making it very efficient when you want to get away from a tough spot.

If you are looking for pleasant gameplay and good entertainment this is the best game you can get.

reviewText:
The Combat is sadly still like Risen 2's and not as good as the first Risen's, wich had the best combat of PB's games, Gothic series included.

Though it seems that PB doesn't even WANT you to use melee combat since every class gets the option to use powerful magic that is superior to melee in every conceivable way.

Like Risen 2, I ended up not hating this game simply through picking the most fun class/playstyle there was (back then it was the gunslinger, this time its the mage.) Though as I said, every class can do everything, which sadly means your decision of who to join in the first half of the game is just fluff, especially when you take into consideration that even the few spells that only a certain faction teaches are still abundantly available as scrolls. This also means that the game doesn't lend itself well to multiple playthroughs.

Now, all that sounds pretty negative, but everything else here is at least solid. I liked most of the quests and NPCs, the dialogue and interactions are fun, the magic is satisfying to use (though that is partially by virtue of being overpowered) and the presentation, while not amazing, still works in creating distinct and cool looking environments.

All in all, while I still cant wholeheartedly recommend this game to people that are - understandably- still sour about Risen 2, its a step in the right direction and I want to see where PB takes the series.

reviewText:
I just finished Risen 3 - Titan Lords for the second time, so I feel comfortable writing a review.

Risen 3 is a vast improvement over Risen 2, although I did like Risen 2 myself as well, but what can I say, I've loved PB's games ever since Gothic 2. While I do admit Risen series has been a lot worse than the original Gothic trilogy, they are still great games in their own sense. At first Risen 3 feels more like an expansion of Risen 2. Lots of assets have been recycled and even a few areas have been brought over from Risen 2. Luckily, however, that feeling vanishes pretty fast when you notice that the recycled areas aren't really that important and all the main areas are brand new, and then you notice how much better Risen 3 does everything. So it ends up feeling like Risen 2 but only less ♥♥♥♥. Risen 3 is a lot bigger than Risen 2, and more refined in almost every aspect. The combat is great, the exploration is awesome and the world is actually open this time around.

It isn't without its problems however. My biggest problem with the game is that it is WAY -WAY- ---WWWAAAAYY--- too easy! It's alright in the beginning if you play without a companion, but it becomes faceroll in the end. Even on hard. On my second playthrough as a voodoo pirate, I managed to max out all my stats. All 8 stats! Maxed! Why is this even possible?

So the balance is ♥♥♥♥ed. It doesn't ruin the game, but it takes away all the tension from the last quarter of the game. Possibly even earlier if you use companions, or something else than melee. In order to get a satisfying challenge out of the game, you pretty much have to shoot yourself in the foot, by not using alchemy or companions. Alchemy is probably the biggest criminal here. It is so ridiculously overpowered it's insane.

Economy balance however, is amazingly well made. There's never enough money if you really want to get the most out of skills. If you're fine with a few skills here and there, you might end up with some extra pocket change, but that wasn't the case for me. The moment I got 10k money, I used them right away, and there were so much more I wanted.

Graphically there's a lot to say as well. The graphics are all over the place. The game looks dated and runs like ♥♥♥♥. I got it running on reasonable fps only after tweaking a lot of the ConfigDefault.xml file. The level design which PB has always been amazing at, is also bit of a let down. Some places are extremely gorgeous, but some places are hideous. There's also a few narrow canyon paths too many for my taste.

The story is.... Well... The story is. It just is. It exists, but isn't important on any level. I have never cared much about PB's storylines, but I've always loved the world, and the history of it. And here it's interesting enough to keep exploring. But the storyline itself is completely irrelevant and forgettable. Combine that with a pointless ending and that's it. But it isn't the meat of the game anyway so who cares?

Some of you guys played the DLCs of Risen 2? Remember how ♥♥♥♥ they were? Well, the DLC of Risen 3 was a massive positive surprise to me, because both Fog Island and Uprising of the Little Guys are awesome. I enjoyed both of them thoroughly. So those are recommended if you don't have them. Nothing to say about Adventure Garb. It's a pile of gear that I don't use because it's too good for the beginning of the game. As if the game wasn't easy enough.

So all in all, it's better than Risen 2, but the difficulty holds it down. I loved it. If you're a PB fan, chances are you'll love it too. If you're not a PB fan however, you probably won't like it. I hate to see people bashing the game when they've never liked PBs games. Why do you expect this one to change your mind? The mistakes" people claim PB makes
date: are all things that have always been around
recommended: and if they were magically fixed
hoursPlayed:
I doubt it would be the same thing anymore. Which would make the old fans disappointed. Even moreso than they already are.

So yeah. I love it.

Sinathor out."

reviewText: first of all I think this game is great, it looks great, in terms of visually it is very polished, i havent seen any flashing textures even far in the distance like you do in skyrim, colors are vibrant, and nothing looks out of place the art style is attractive.\ni dont know why alot of people are complaining about combat, sure its not the best combat system ever created, but its not boring and hopefully it will get some tweaking, think the witcher 2 when it first came out. the voice acting is great, only very rarely do i think that the script detracts from immersion, I did have some trouble with the game at launch, the game would not save, so i had to restart it like 10 times before i finnally figured out how to fix it, add me as a friend if u have this same trouble and i will tel u how to fix it. but olther than that, the world is vast, offering many choices of where to start your journey once u pass the first chapter, YES this game does take a while before you start to feeel even a little powerful, to get magic and abilities takes a while, but that is all in good fun, lets u explore first and doesnt hand you victory very easily. there is as plethora of people to talk to that can teach you different things, and they are located everywhere, not in just one place like in most rpgs. tho the important combat stuff is mostly close by the faction you choose. This game is not a rushed cheap experience like many think. I think this is the best effort of this franchise and while i havent come close to finishing it, I am having fun and not regretting the money spent.

reviewText: Patty getting herself a ѕlutty costume should have make me understand there is something wrong with this game. See for yourself — she had more style and dignity even in the first instalment of the series, where no female characters got good 3D models.\n\nIt is tolerable that the game brings nothing new to game mechanics compared to “Risen 2”, though first one’s and of course “Gothic” I or II’s one would be much better preferred. The bigger problem is that prologue and chapter one take 80% of game time to complete, while the rest of the game offers very little new content. So the problem is the game got open world game’s curse: as I could go anywhere any time, I did, there were no enemies strong enough to stop me, and locations that opened after choosing the factions simply were not large enough, and no new quests were added. Taking “Gothic II” or “Risen” as reference models, the picture there was absolutely different, every new chapter urged you to re-explore the locations, find what happened to NPC, what new problems appeared, how maps changed. Here we have nothing like that, and replay value is negligible, too.

reviewText:
*NEW REVIEW UP
-New Review after 20+ hours in the game-
I'm going to write this review from a Gothica/Risen fans PoV. You will have to understand PB games to appreciate this game. it is a niche game for players who like hard combat Action RPG's like Dark Souls.
-For returning players from the Gothica/Risen universe, PB made a solid game in Risen 3. The engine is a more efficient less buggy redo of Risen 2, so the graphics and physics are techinaly the same but have now been recoded for less bugs, locked high frame rates, and less stress on your hardware. So if you're looking for a new top of the lin graphics engine on par with a PS4 game don't expect much. The Game was released on 360/ps3/WinPC, so it's made for last gens hardware.


You play a new hero, you are not the nameless figure from Risen 1 and 2, but instead you are one of the sons of Captain Steelbeard, your sister is Patty and you start off the game together.

==FOR NEW PLAYERS==
Pirahna Bytes, aka PB, is known for making EXTREMELY STORY driven RPG's with DIFFICULT COMBAT mechanics. Not combat thats clunky, but combat that reflects starting off as a new character, as you gain skills in combat training you will notice the improvement and growth of your character. If you're new to this kind of game, then the start of the game (first 4 hours) will be a pain in the butt for you. But you will feel your character grow and get a real sense of accomplishment as you gain more skills and stats. It's one of the staples of PB games and it makes it a very niche genre not unlike Dark Souls is a niche genre. I highly suggest purchasing Risen 1 since it's dirt cheap and has no DLC to get a feel for PB games. if this is your first PB game and you don't like the game style you will feel ripped off, but I don't feel ripped off, I love it.
==COMBAT==
Combat will be more in line with Risen 1, then in Risen 2. More emphasis on dodging, and reading opponents ques, understanding when they combo attacks and when what they do when you dodge, moving in combat to avoid getting ganged up on, and choosing when to attack is key. Unlike Risen 2 you will not be able to move from Parry to Attack seamlessly, lending a step of difficulty more in line with traditional PB games. Which for PB fans is great, Risen 2 had hard reviews from PB veterans for making the game more cupcake and less hardcore. So Risen 3 is a step in the right direction.
==CRAFTING==
Unlike Risen 1 and 2, weapon crafting actually has a USE in this game. A new feature is that you take some of the misc items and combine them with weapons to make a better weapon (Thrusting sword + 2 silver plates+6 iron ore) gets you a Disked Epee, with better stats of couse, it is very money effecient. This is also in line with Guns, Muskets, and all melee weapons, even with the unqiue weapons that require difficult to find parts can be upgraded with lots of rare mats to make superior verions or to change it's damage type. Example the Crest Wave SLASHING sword 55-85 Damage +10 Slashing can be changed to the Lightning" 55-85 Piercing +10 Piercing *and it has electric particle skin and can partialy pierces blocks*
Potion crafting is back along with the rare + perm stat potions made from the perm stat ingredients
recommended: the potions give +5\nMore emphasis on temp buff potions is used since there are more skills to allocate your Glory(XP) too. So expect to use buff potions often to surpass early Lockpicks
hoursPlayed: Persuade

reviewText:
Risen 3: Titan Lords is a solid RPG with awesome (but cheesy) dialogues, pretty nice story and large world that rewards exploration.
Every other system in the game is somewhat basic:
- Leveling? Yep, just put your XP into your stats.
- Combat? Yep, just 3 buttons - evade, attack and block. You can do riposte by blocking at right time and you can do heavy strikes by holding attack, but that about it. Oh, yeah, there are spells that make combat a bit more enjoyable, but you get them only after ~10h into the game.
- Crafting? Yep, just gather mats and click craft" to get the item
date: no random stats or minigames.\n- Lockpicking? Yep
recommended: no fail state though. Just a lot of annoyance with complex locks >_>\n- Naval battles? Yep
hoursPlayed: but so arcadey that you can actually tell the ship to go forward...\n- Other mini-games? Yep

reviewText:
Game is an improvement over Risen 2. Without Making this review overly complicated, I enjoyed the gameplay elements so much, but I do have some nitpicks on it. Positive first, the world to me was very expansive and for the most part you could go multiple ways to reach your destination. Also the skill based system for bonus objectives is spot on what I want in a game. The fluidness of combat and movement has improved so much from what it was in Risen 2.

Now for the negative: main characters voice acting I feel was not normal and felt just plain wrong to me. Cutscenes and ending felt thrown in and out of place. The implementation of hunting for additional ingredients, while something I like, doesn't seem fit in without a reliable respawn system for monsters. The implementation of how much glory it takes to raise a skill should be balanced so that it doesn't take into account permanent potion bonuses.

7/10

*very minor min/max character spoiler below*

Only reason I mention the last item under negative is because I like to min/max my characters, but you have to raise your skills in a way where you drink the permanent potions at the end so you spend as little glory as possible leveling skills.

reviewText:
Risen 3 marks off the end of an era in the Risen-series. As far as I'm aware, there won't be another one. However, that doesn't matter since this final game finishes the series close to perfectly. From the first moment of playing Risen to this last moment of Risen 3, the series has made me replay the games several times, that's how good they are.

There are a few noticeable differences between Risen 3 and Risen/Risen 2, apart from improved graphics of coure. In Risen 3, the combat is slightly different, as many people before me has noticed aswell. While the combat in itself is very cool and not very hard, your character is pretty weak and your NPC companion has to help you quite a bit. At least in the beginning.

In Risen 3, you don't play as the character from the previous games. You play as Patty's brother, who I hadn't heard about before playing Risen 3. But that doesn't matter too much since you get to know him during the game and there's a little surprise somewhere in the game if you've played the other games...

I highly recommend playing this game if you've played the former Risen games first, if you haven't. you risk losing out on a lot of the precious story. The combat gets better and better the more you play and it's the kind of game you just want to keep playing, even after finishing it. Even more so since there are different factions that you can join, changing the gameplay for every playthrough (to a certain point).

reviewText:
Even though I'm a huge Pyranha Bytes fanboy and I can forgive them a lot....I just can't recommend this game. Gothic 1, Gothic 2, Gothic 3 and Risen 1 are all absolutely amazing games and I recommend wholeheartedly every one of them. I can even recommend Risen 2 even though it's nowhere near as good as the previous games. But Risen 3 is just too a blatant attempt to extract some more money from the Risen 2 engine and assets without too much effort.

This game still retains some of PB's trademark systems and there IS some enjoyment to be found if you look hard enough. On the other hand it just exudes an uninterested, glassy, dreary atmosphere. The story is a complete joke, the writing lacks the spark and wit of Risen 2, NPCs are vapid and long winded, quests are boring, character models and entire areas are cynically rehashed and reused and the combat, the greatest strength of PB games, isn't very satisfying either. There's way too much of it and it stops being challenging or interesting very quickly, especially if you go for the mage build. You're just blasting hordes of trash mobs again and again into oblivion. Sometimes it feels like a 3rd person Diablo which is the complete opposite of what PB games traditionaly strived for.

Many fans claimed Risen 2 marked the end of true Pyranha Bytes but Risen 2, even though a significant decline, is still worth playing. Risen 3 is not. It's cynical, disinterested, boring and routine rehash of Risen 2, nothing more.

reviewText:
Basically It boils down to this. A good role playing game rewards fastidious exploration. The Risen franchise is no exception.The more you explore the more loot you get, the more loot you get, the more money you get, the more money you get, the more skills/items/equipment you get. To me, this is the attraction of the Risen franchise. Exploration=reward, pure and simple. This is a very important element in any pure single player RPG. This particular element is handled well in the  Risen series of games.

However the Risen franchise is still struggling to find a solid identity. The first Risen was very ambiguous, the second chapter, the developers, despite giving the franchise a more polished pirate themed aspect,  were still experimenting with the combat system. This 3rd chapter is wonderful to the hardcore RPG'er, the pirate element still remains but the combat remains slightly clunky and experimental if you will.

However, the exploration vs. reward idea remains solid in all 3 games. Risen 3 is a more finely polished example of where the franchise could go.

Exploration and completionism is the key in the Risen franchise.

However to be perfect the Risen franchise could do well with a lot more polishing.  Some examples being, keep working on the combat system, the combat system in Risen, being the core of the game still feels slighty clunky. I figured out the obvious pattern in the combat system early on. And there is a definite pattern still. This pattern in the obvious timed moves still hinders the combat system from feeling fluid and natural. If you attack at the wrong time, you get hit, if you attack at the right time you strike. There is no fluid inbetween. The combat feels timed" more so than natural.

Another aspect the developers could benefit from working on.  Make the skill earning system more complex. The skill system in this game is OKAY but not perfect. It still feels slightly limited. You spend cash on new skills
date: and you add power points to existing skills to "level them up". However there is no complex skill tree per se. You don't get to master a whole entire set of skills in any one combat style. This all lends to a slightly limited combat system. You can get BETTER at guns...but all you'll notice if you do so is that you do more damage with ranged weapons. To be blunt
recommended: the leveling/skill system needs a serious overhaul to feel more rewarding.\n\nAlso very importan to the hardcore RPG'er is
hoursPlayed: reward all the hard work put into the game with a beautiful well thought out ending. I notice the Risen titles in this franchise have lackluster endings. I realize the games themselves tell a story. But a moving
voteText: rewarding ending for a role playing game like this
helpfulPercent: where hard work and exploration should lend to the game's ending  is needed to complete the immersion process.\n\nI hope they continue this franchise
votesHelpful: and fine tune the understandable flaws until they release a game that surpasses all other RPGS.\n\nIn short
votesTotal: this RPG does exemplary on the exploration verses reward aspect. The more you explore
votesFunny: the more you benefit. However this franchise still continues to fall short on the combat system
commentsCount: skill system and endings for the games. This game will tickle the fancy of any die-hard fan of single player RPGs
column16: but there is still a ways to go if the developers want to perfect this franchise."

reviewText: If you're a fan of the Risen games, this iteration won't dissappoint.  The character levelling/RPG elements are unique and as entertaining as always.  The writing and voice acting are extremely rough.  If you're a fan of exploration, there are hundreds of secret nooks and crannies if you're willing to spend the time to look around.  Unlike the previous games, the melee combat in this one is actually enjoyable.\nThe game does one particularly interesting thing - it opens up pretty much the entire world to you immediately, and the enemies do not scale with your level.  This has advantages and disadvantages.  The beginning of the game is quite hard, but as your character develops, you really feel yourself becoming powerful.  It's very satisfying.  However, by the end of the game, you feel like an unstoppable god and just plow through the same enemies that you've been fighting for the last 30 hours.

reviewText:
5/5

Gameplay:
+ Oriented on Gothic 1&2 and Risen 1
+ Same humor as ever
+ Very much atmosphere, in terms of quests and the game/level/island design.
+ I can not! confirm, that the quests are generic or anything like that. Also every character has it's own personality and position in this game, there are only very few unnamed characters with no kind of background in this world. But this does not only to npcs, but to all items and locations aswell, truly handcrafted!
+ I love the way magic got implemented in this game! No exhausting mana-potion collection or brewing which I always disliked, but just a cooldown-based system. Some critisize that, I love it and think a lot of games should go that direction!
+ I do not find the story boring and do not agree with (most) reviewers.
+ I love flying or gliding around like a parrot.
- Sometimes there's not enough feedback whether a quest is completed, failed or still pending in status, e.g. before being promoted to a guardian you have to talk to your pirate admiral. He then tells you to kill the undead dogs, swirling around the city. Although this is not hard to accomplish, one may still miss out on some dogs and ask him-/herself, why one can't get promoted. Another example would be the di fuego" related quests.
- Sometimes npcs can't follow you and get stuck
date:
however if you wait long enough they will eventually be back at your position (Teleporting and/or going back to your ship or another island helps in this case).

reviewText:
RISEN/GOTHIC fans will LOVE this game.
Quite simply it is the ultimate amalgam of this type of TRUE open world RPG.
A fun mix of both adult and light hearted storyline/dialogue/voice acting with lots of bad language thrown in the mix as usual, this game doesn't take itself as seriously as other RPGS and is more fun because of it.
Good combat with lots of different styles, sword, piercing, muskets, shotguns, pistols, and many different kinds of combat magic.
The best crafting in a RISEN game to date, and also, perhaps my favourite part of the game is the incredible exploration, all sorts of secrets and easter eggs await in some very hard to reach and unusual locations!
Highly reccommended to all RPG fans, especially if on a good sale.
Just remember Treasure you take : Suffer the fate!""

Depending on which faction you choose to represent, your magic usage changes a lot which is  a nice touch. reviewText:
This is a great game and a worthy successor to the Risen series.
The atmosphere is very immersive: the environment is spectacular and varies a lot compared to Risen 2, the game comes with great music and video sequences and the quests and dialogues are as entertaining as usual.
There is a lot of collectibles and treasures to be found and a lot to explore!
Free exploration - If you finish a quest related task it will count even if you don't currently have that quest, meaning you can't ruin your games progression by accident, which is great!
You can fight your enemies with meele and ranged weapons or magic attacks.
You can have henchmen, summons and your own ship's crew! Your ship will hold your henchmen, it can be used for traveling, naval battle against sea monsters and to board enemy ships! There are mini-games (arm wrestling, drinking game, knife throwing game) where you can wager gold to make profit or to win a few rare collectibles.
This is at least" 60 hours of fun gameplay (with dlc's even more) - enjoy the game!"
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I didn't like Risen, and I skipped Risen 2. Risen 3 came out when no other big games are around, so I picked it up to kill some time. And it turned out to be very enjoyable experience. Very few games give you that feeling of being in the game. Like first Fable, all Mass Effects. And Risen 3. If immersive world is what you like in games — definitely check out this game. And actually it becomes better and better as you play. More skills, magic, more weapons and armor. You really feel that you've become stronger, but battles are still challenging and fun. Everything in this game is really simple and nothing new. But it works well.

reviewText: This game is worth a try, in the very beginning game may be boring because you are strong and  game may seem very easy, after the first island you are so weak without companion ( because i didn't like to play with them ) that you may not like it, but in the middle of the game you will definetly like it you will need to make hard decisions like which faction to join ( i joined Guardians, because magic was returned ). I very liked how my character uses magic and in the start i didn't like those slow motion power hits, but ofcorse i got used to it. You can finally swim in the game. Music in game was very inspiring. I also liked sea battles, they were very interesting but i couldn't skip them or go to them later which wasn't the best thing but in total they where worth it. What i didn't like was ending island i can't say really why, but it was bad in my opinion. Ending scene was horrible it should be remade and longer like i could talk to my teammates in the end after last fight like in risen 2. Very good game. I could give to it 8/10 because i enjoyed it and really didn't encounter any horrible bugs because i completed every single quest which i found in the game!\nEdit: I also saw peaople saying that game was too short, i wil disagree with that i completed every singe sidequest i found and main quest in 52 hours and it is enough in my view!

reviewText:
I'll keep it short:

Pros:

- Nice graphics

- Decent base story line

- Innovative levelling system (You don't level up, you just up your stats with glory)

- Overall good voice acting (the main player is an exception, bad voice acting!)

Cons:

- It has animations that remind you of the PlayStation 1 era.

- A lot of the sidequests are the same, and can become quite lame

- personal one: looks of characters. I mean, the way Patty looks ;_;

It's worth playing, but wait for it to go into a sale! :)

reviewText:
Just to sum up in a few remarks for those consider buying the game:

-The combat is clunky and frustrating, yet you get used to it once you play enough, and start to enjoy it bit by bit just for the sake of roaming around the beautiful vistas, looting hither and thither.
-Exploration in the game is what makes Risen 3 stand out from its mediocrity.
-Even though the graphics are raw when you hit the ultra settings, you still appreciate the splashy vividness sparkling in the forests, ruins and seas alike.

It's really good to have RPGs like this. Diversity is all that matters. Give it a chance, if you did like the games like Bound by Flame, or other Risen games.

reviewText:
So far so good, started out rather hard, but getting the hang of the combat more and more and finally now that I understood where I was supposed to go for spells and such (as I aimed to be a mage with all of my points were put into a mix of influence, toughness and magic).

The story so far seems nice, the openworld feel of it all is marvelous, spent 2 hours just running along the beach by the Citadel stabbin' them Iron Golems, my god was I surprised.
I do feel that I should probably up the difficulty a bit, but for now I'm satisfied with how things are.
The story might be a bit lacking but the game is incredibly beautiful, running it all on max without any issues at all..

The only complaint that I really have is that the camera bugs out sometimes, and that I wish there was a lockon system.. :C


Edit: Almost 20 hours into the game now, the quests might be a bit lacking but I am overall enjoying it. Mage seems to be rather OP as I just throw out Rain of Fire and then shoot a few lightning bolts here and there.
Will be nice to see how Demon Hunter is after this playthrough is done!

reviewText:
This is pretty much a middle of the line RPG, with a particularly weak combat system, but with an interesting, mediocre storyline that seemed to keep me intrigued. I put approx 32 hours into this game, and I didnt feel forced to finish it. The voiceacting of the NPC characters was quite good IMO, although the main character was a dullard with poor voiceacting. The combat system, as I mentioned, is very clunky, and using melee weapons will be a bore due to the simplicity and frustration of the slow movements.
That being said, this game is of no improvement over RISEN 2, and if you enjoyed Risen 2, then I would recommend this game, as it is nearly identical, without anything new.
Would recommend if:
#1. You liked Risen 2.
#2. You can score it for less than 20 dollars.
#3. You are looking to put 30 hours into a decent RPG.

reviewText:
Great game.  Loved the pirate setting.  Much like Skyrim your character in the beginning plays as though they were crippled but by end game I had improved my skills and was a nimble wrecking machine.  The Thieves Den Island I could have done without.  It was a filler throw in and the game ending battle was annoying not challenging.  Froze up about 5 times in my play through forcing me to close and restart but other than that it ran pretty smooth.

Two weird drawbacks were the fact that you couldn't add map markers which were absolutely necessary.  No map markers in a buried treasure pirate game?  It came across like a bad joke.  Second was the inability to save a game with your own heading.  It would have been nice to have saved my game just prior to choosing a faction so I could go back and replay as the other two classes but it literally doesn't let you name your save which I've never seen before so it eventually just got over-written which will prevent me from ever going back to this game.  A real shame quite frankly.

Great price(publisher sale), good graphics, fun skill progression and interesting characters.  They kept it simple as well so you didn't get bogged down with carrying encumbrance and the like.  Just straight forward fun.  Looking forward to a Risen 4.

reviewText:
Why? Why Piranha Bytes, why must you hurt me like this?
It's like you've taken the good parts of their older games and thrown them all out, while at best not doing anything about the bad parts, and at worst magnifying them, or even shoehorning new ones from other games in.

The NPC Hubs, unlike the ones from about every Gothic game they made, seem empty and dead. The liveliest one is the Guardians big hold, but it's a single one, compared to the countless other ones that simply seem...barren. The inter NPC banter which made the towns in Gothic and Risen seem especially lively is almost completely missing, as is the ambiance that came with it. Most of the NPCs become completely meaningless, after you've done a sweep through their area and finished whatever quest they were involved in. Unlike the previous games, there are almost no quests that become available at a later point, making the gameworld seem even more devoid of life. Because apparently nothing happens while you're away.

Choosing a faction also has almost no impact. There is only a handfull of faction-dependant perks, most of which carry little weight. Apart from that, faction dictates which set of spells becomes permanently available to you, but during one playthrough I found a sufficient amount of scrolls to make that meaningless as well. After that, the only thing left are AFAIK about 2 quests per faction that wouldn't be available without joining. There are almost no other reactions or consequences to your choice in faction. Though that might be rooted in the choice to have no conflict between the factions, which I think is a rather boring design choice.

Along with the factions comes the comparable tiny variety of equipment. There is a miniscule selection of 3 sets of armor per faction and they don't have that much impact on gameplay, as the values of armor seem laughable (150 points of damage mitigation, of which about 115 are from character attributes and perks at the end of my playthrough).  Though there are a bit more weapons available, a good part of those are already useless at the point one can optain them.

All special abilities and perks no longer cost any learning points. All that is left is an amount of gold one has to pay for them, which undoubtably enables players to get anything they want without any need for choice. And with the Potion Brewing Perk, which costs 2000 gold pieces, the upper half of the attribute scale becomes meaningless as well. Why invest experience points into enhancing an attribute past a value of 50, if one can instead do it with not that hard to get potions?

The Sea-Battle minigame they implemented seems like a sloppy attempt of copying Assassins Creed's sea battles, but with only 3 instances happening, none of which are avoidable, I couldn't familiarize with it's mechanics enough to be particularily good. It thus simply became a chore, each one taking about 20 minutes of gametime, while not being any kind of fun or adding anything to the story. The other three minigames were less of a chore, but also weren't required at any point, which is a good thing I guess. Why the hell they decided to implement the seabattles, and do so the way they did still is beyond me.

The other, more puzzely" possiblities of the game were mostly ignored. The "trained monkey" sequences were few in number and rarely provided anything of value (only 2 times IIRC). Same goes with the "transform into Parrot" sequences. There was only a hand full of them
date: and most of them only provided mediocre loot. None of them were in any part needed for any quests
recommended: neither main nor side. In fact
hoursPlayed:
there weren't even meaningful possiblities to use them during the mainquest.

The final battle was (again) only a "whack the damage sponge" with the occasional "follow the damage sponge" which felt kinda anti-climatic.

While you get seven possible followers

reviewText: As a long time Gothic fan, if you've played and enjoyed those games, I would get this without a doubt.\n\nTheres loads of exploring ( it's a PB game), querky characters (stale humor), loot everywhere (without annoying cap limits), and no respawning monsters (thank you jesus).

reviewText:
Nice game, pretty faithful to old Gothic style and lots of pirates and what not.

On the plus side, it got a nice environment, varied ways to play, lots of hidden things to find and some interesting characters. For the most part the story is enjoyable and fast paced and the leveling up style make you have to plan ahead.

The downside, story can be a little 2D in places. The game is fairly challenging at the beginging, but if you complete all the quests you get pretty over powered by the end and things get a bit repetative - the last island really could have done with a whole new set of monsters. Likewise weapons/equipment could have done with a lot more variation.

It's not perfect by any means, but if you enjoy an fun RPG where you wander round exploring it's pretty good.

reviewText:
This is a good Action RPG. It stands on it's own even if you've never played any of the Gothic/Risen series.

It's an RPG meaning that if the player tries to melee a golem without putting any points into combat related skills, it will likely end rather badly for that player. Or rather, the player won't do much damage and the fight will be really long and boring. With high skills in Melee, Magic or even Toughness the game is quite easy even on the hardest setting. However, if the player feels the urge for punishing fights, all he/she has to do is not level up.

So it has everything one would expect. It has lots of monsters to kill. It has lots of skills to level that help kill monsters in better and more fun ways. It has skills that help manipulate the world and the people in it, such as lock picking and silver tongue. It even has multiple options to succeed in combat with guns or magic or swords as well as several factions that add combat flair. There is even enough potions to max every single attribute if you're that type of player.

I had fun with it and it was well worth the price tag to me. Buy it if you enjoy RPGs.

reviewText: I would like to start off that im a huge fan of the first 3 gothic games and so far ive gotta say the same for the risen series. Although this game does have its flaws so far the voice acting is sub par but the dialoge is good (ive only meet a few main charcters though so far, but the main charcater is really the worst compared to all the other pb games, imo. But then again im a mel blanc fan, so im a kinda snob for good voice acting) the movement is very stiff of your character, and take some feeling out at first. Ive gotten used to the melee... and the magic from all the differnt factions looks crazy sick! (as in awesome, which pb has always been good at mage combat, again imo) ... and once you get used to attacking only when you need too, and same with dodgeing, it turns into a game of patience, kinda dark souls style but not necessarily as difficult, but still fun and rewarding (btw, i really like the dodgeing system, where you double tap the move keys in the direction you want to go compared to the camera angle rather than where your character facing.) ive been playing 3 and a half hours now and ive still only been to one island and im nowhere near explored all the lush forsest full of beast and minions, and the cliffs (conveniently staircase-like so you can climb it up and up and up, lol, I guess it gives me an old school nostalgia;) I really enjoy Risen 3 and after I got past the beginning, it started feeling like a world i wanted to explore. (reminds me most of gothic 1 & 2 quest-wise where you've got your three factions, and gameplay handleing/movement, its very much like its predecessors. To me the movement could be less clunky, (which makes it hard for me to play it with a controller) I cant wait to get my magic going though, itll be a whole new game after that! Two thumbs up from me (was a bit pricey but like i said ive been a fan since gothic 1.) No regrets here...

reviewText:
If you liked the Gothic series and Risen, and can stomach the pirate theme of Risen 2, this game is for you.It was, as usual for PB, made for the audience that enjoyed their previous work.


Positives
The game is beatiful in my opinion, shaders and reflections are some of the best I've seen in a long time. Game runs mostly solid 60fps on my system (660ti and a first gen i7), dips rarely went lower than to 50fps, max settings.
Combat system really did see improvements, even though many reviewers fail to see them.
The new islands are much larger (at least 2 times the space and 3 times the quest density) than the two taken from Risen 2, ( the islands many criticized for being copy pasted, which is only really half-true, they have been noticably reworked and don't play as of a role in the story, I spent as much time on both of them as I did doing one half of one of the three main islands)
The UI has never worked this well; instant response times and logical structure make necessary UI navigation easy

Negatives

The sea battles are half baked at best, luckily they didn't take up more than 5-10 minutes at a time for me. Shame one of them starts off the game, so you see shoddy scripted animations and QTE's as a first impression, when either are rather rare throughout the entire game
While most of the UI is very snappy and responsive, the Inventory system is on a list basis, so scrolling is necessary. I prefered the Risen 1 system of a big open square based inventory, but I did get used to it easily.
The overarching story is, as usual, quite cheesy and uninspired. That said: Obligatory hero looses his abilities" we come to expect from PB games twist is probably better executed than in most previous iterations. Nice set pieces
date: areas and generally diverse side quests though.\nEnglish voice acting is mediocre to 'meh'

reviewText: All the guys saying that this game is crap is not really Gothic series or Risen fans, this game is great and i enjoy it, reminds me of Gothic 3, i like the way how you get stronger and see the difference when you fight. Lots of missions to do with multiple ways to solve it. Again if your a Gothic or Risen fan you will be right at home but if this is the first time playing their games then it takes some getting used to, especially on the combat. The story is nice. Magic looks nice as well. You have 3 factions to choose from but once chosen you cannot join the others (same as Gothic series). I have chosen Guardians (mages) and enjoying it a lot. I recommend this game and for new comers just give it a chance and get used to the combat and you will enjoy it how you evolve and get stronger. It might feel crap in the beginning but thats just it, you must get stronger and stronger and your combat skills will improve and you will notice how your changing and getting stronger in the game, you will then see what you worked for. I loved Piranha Bytes Gothic series and Risen and love this game.

reviewText:
Overall a decent, but not great, game.

If you played and enjoyed Risen or Risen 2 (or any of the Gothic games, for that matter), this game will feel immediately familiar. It continues with the pirate-y themes from the second, which I wasn't crazy about, but it didn't take away from the game too much for me.

The gameplay mechanics are solid enough, and the graphics are decent. The voice acting and dialogue is almost all hilariously terrible, and the story is pretty poor, but I still found myself enjoying playing it.

Honestly, there are better games out there. There are better games trying to do this exact same thing that you could play instead. I tend to have a soft spot for wonky European RPG games though, so take this recommendation with that in mind.

In the end, should you play this? Maybe. Did you play and like the other ones, and did you want more of that? If yes, get this. You know what you're getting in to. Do you just want an open world RPG and haven't played one before? You can probably find better options. If you're looking for deep character customization or a great story, you'd be better off looking elsewhere.

Still, not bad. I enjoyed it and it's lengthy enough.

reviewText:
Great game with some flaws if your a fan of Piranha Bytes past work you will probably enjoy this game

Pros
+ large world with loads of quest to do
+ your free to do anything you want when you want how you want
+ the combat is better then it was in Risen 2 but still isnt that great but gets better when you learn new skills
+ lots of skills everything from magic to voodoo to guns to melee and many more
+ feels like the first Risen and the first 3 gothic games in many ways
+ soundtrack is very well done but nothing that will get stuck in your head for years to come
+ the graphics are great i dont know why some people are saying they suck

Cons
- the game is fairly hard at first thats what i liked but half way into the game i was almost a god and rarely did i die
- the story is alright i guess nothing that bad it was just kinda there
- voice acting is alright i didnt mind it but a hear a lot of people cant stand it
- it takes a while to get to the real meat of the game i didnt mind this at all cause the gothic games were like that but i have a feeling many wont like this

so to sum up i do recommend this game but its not a RPG for everyone but if your a fan of the first Risen and first 3 gothic game you should most definitely get this game

reviewText:
I usually never write a review for anything unless it is extremely warranted but here we go. This is a more regrettable purchase than WarZ. Boom! You get screwed by the developers here. They know it, you will know it. It is absolutely disgusting that they come out with something like this.

*EDIT* I came back to the review and figured I should add that when you play this game, just don't expect anything spectacular. I concluded its made to be bad. I can understand that, but not for $50 can a game be that intentionally bad.

Oh, its pretty? So what?! It doesn't even preform well and is a mockery of a game that should come out in this day and age.

I feel like I have been pretty ripped off by the quality of this game for the price of $50. I think I have been made fun of for purchasing this game due to the extreme lack of quality and substance. I cannot believe this is even on Steam's market right now to be absolutely honest. For $50 you expect a game to actually be polished and work well and play well. Risen 3 does nothing of the sort. This is the type of game I would have expected to come out in 2003, not 2014 and certainly not for that price tag. It was advertised as an improvement from Risen 2 in every way and offering a new experience in ways of storytelling and combat that will be relished. That is completely false. Actually the biggest load of crap I have fallen for.

The combat system is the same with no redeeming qualities. Here is how it goes: you strike twice, maybe 3 times, most of which the enemy blocks if they are a humanoid, then the enemy strikes where you hold down the RMB until you get to throw a strike of your own. You can try and dodge, but guess what? The enemy will probably come at you with his strike nearly teleporting to hit you. This is the entirety of the combat system. Nothing built on and certainly nothing improved. Nothing tactical or even trying with this system. It literally consists of just waiting and waiting and waiting. COMBAT SHOULDN'T BE BORING, THIS MANAGES TO BE SO. They should be ashamed for trying to get this game out on the market. The creation of this combat system actually makes me feel sick. Thinking you can slap something that bad together and be happy with it is ridiculous and is part of why this game was just a cash grab.

The voice acting actually feels like they were joking while making this in the studio. With the main character sounding like he just got out of bed the entire time and Bones (your kool companion) trying to sound interesting and mystical, you can tell nothing was seriously done with this trash. At first I thought it was funny, now its just getting on my nerves and feels like a repeated kick in my junk for falling for this horrid game.

I will keep trying to play this game again but heavily discourage it to ANYONE else because it is in all sense of the word, a cheat to the gamer. I really do feel screwed by it in every way.

reviewText:
Buy this game if you love RPG's, and don't mind if a game is a bit rough around the edges, people who played the previous gothic and risen games know. You will get a good amount playtime for your money, and the game becomes alot of fun as soon you figured out the combat system. As the gothic series and the previous risen games, one of the biggest appeals of the game is the exploration. You will always find some hidden treasure and secrets, if you just look for them


This game gets a bad rap for being not as streamlined and polished as some other AAA rpg's, quite undeserved if you ask me. And i'm not a blinded fanboy of the franchise who desperately wants to defend it. I started playing this game after Witcher 3, and the transition was more than rough, since Witcher 3 was  doing everything right that matters in a good RPG.  Going over to risen was very difficult, since the clunky animations, odd combat system, and campy dialogue made it very appaling after Witcher 3. I even stopped playing entirely until i got back into it much later. But if you're willing to put some effort in the game you can get alot of entertainment out of it. Especially if you love exploring, this game will be for you. While the seperate Islands that you will visit throughout the game are not as huge as for example Skyrim, there are still tons of areas to discover that are completely optional, but will always reward you for exploring them.

In conclusion, i'd recommend this game to every rpg fan, although if you only want to play perfectly balanced and polished games, this one might not be for you as it comes with a series of issues coming from the sometimes faulty game design. If you played and like the previous Gothic and Risen games, you can't do anything wrong with this one.

reviewText: Piranha Bytes has done it again! They are behind the Gothic franchise - in my oponion - simply the best Action RPG ever made. Now they've completed Risen with a 3. installment and i have to say, what a game! Ever since Gothic (expect Gothic 4, which wasnt made by Piranha Bytes, explains the failure..) I've never felt the same atmosphere in another RPG. Never the feel, the sense of detail and intriguement... But oh boy, have they made a huge succes with Risen 3! From the combat system, crafting, the thirst for exploring, to combat magic and fun characters!\nEverywhere you go everything has a purpose and nothing is random. I love it. Risen 3 is difenitly the best of the 3 games, its like they have found the perfect balance from the other games and made it awesome. Try it, if you love a good Action RPG and you find the other blockbuster RPG tedious, lack of feel and soul - buy Risen 3, you wont regret it. Support Piranha, so they will keep on making awesome Action RPG's. Long live Piranha Bytes - and im not even german! :)

reviewText:
Forget Risen 2. Let it not bias you. Risen 3 is all you'd want from the Risens and the Gothics, too.

Graphics
The game is gorgeous. Sunlight/Godrays crash through the canopies of the trees; distant mountains cast their shadow on distant land realistically; fire never looked as good; water makes you want to jump right in; distant ruins beckon you to explore them; higher tier armour -- the cloth properly dancing as you move, the steel reflecting the light -- makes you drool as you stare at your hero. The physics engine is also fluid and realistic, enemies falling back after having received their killing blow will tumble over objects or droop down from them.

Gameplay
It's still what you expect from any Risen or Gothic game: The HUD is simple, and that's perfectly fine. In fact, I wouldn't have it any other way. You can now also change into a parrot with scrolls that you'll find everywhere -- specifically in high places! -- the devs silently begging you to use them as turning into a parrot makes you glide however long you want. There's a little energybar nonetheless which will slowly empty whenever you want to fly upward. It's fun! And as for the combat...

Combat
It has improved SO MUCH! If you time your attacks properly, you can swing with heavy attacks almost as fast as you would with normal attacks. This needs some practise, but once you get a feel for it, it becomes easy. For some too easy, though many players still think combat is hard. As you gain enough experience (or Glory) you'll be able to gain the Riposte skill, which, if you time it right, your parry will execute a sweet animation of your hero evading a strike and counter-attacking with a strike of his own. You can also still dodge, which is an ability that can be exploited since there's no stamina bar. I say exploited, because during a dodge you're practically invincible. A fantastic addition to the combat is the finishing move on humanoids. When you kill the last enemy in an encounter, you watch your character execute him. There are multiple finishers. Your hero pushes an enemy against a wall, rams his weapon's hilt into the face multiple times before running him through; your hero turns the enemy around and slits his throat, etc. etc. etc. My most favorite finisher is where the enemy runs toward the hero and the hero steps aside at the last moment, leaving his weapon stretched horizontally in the enemy's path... the enemy runs into the blade, stumbles past the hero and eventually drops on the ground a few strides further, quite dead. Imagine stuff like this with a perfect physics engine. Yes, if there's a ledge a few strides behind your hero in said finisher, the enemy will stumble and drop down the edge instead. Deader than dead. So awesome.

Exploration
There's so much to see and do and find in this game! Almost every NPC with a name (which is almost every NPC) has a quest or more quests. When you climb up a mountain and see these mysterious places in the far, far distance... well, that telltale feeling rushes through every RPG player -- the feeling that says: I NEED to go there and explore every nook and cranny! And I can guarantee: You WILL be rewarded for it.

Final verdict
I love this game. I am not kidding. It's the best thing in the gaming world that has happened to me in YEARS. And that's coming from a guy who fell in LOVE with Gothic 1 & 2, Risen 1 and very much disliked Risen 2. I catch myself playing this game with a content smile on my face. It's crazy. This game is phenomenal!

reviewText:
It's a Pyranna Bytes open world RPG. It's got factions, day an night cycles and FLYING. (albeit as a Parrot). I went through my first run through as a Voodoo Pirate due to having the unlimited flying spell. This was one of my favorite features of the Might and Magic series and they included it in Risen 3. I hope PB keeps it for its upcoming games.

The game does have its issues however. The number one being an over relience on arcadey sequences with its boss monsters. While not as bad as the Risen 1, they are still annoying having them in my RPGs. Why did they feel their games would be improved with that addtion. The game also had some irratating video sequences. They use the same brutal combat sequence for killing baddies as they do challanging an ally. It makes no sense for an ally to get up after you slit his throat . . .

It make me ask the question, If your original template is the superior Gothic, what direction would you take to make the game better?

The game world is fairly large but needed a wider diversity of monsters. And it needed more regular human monsters/bad guys. (Remember the bandit caves in Gothic 2)  The bullet shield was wortlhess becasue there simply aren't many baddies with guns. The cities needed more people and way way way more women. And while the game was mostly set in a carribean setting, I would have preferred a couple different climates. ( I admit a preference to snow)

The UI is horrible. It needs more tabs. Some of the screen inforamation has to be scrolled when there is no need to such a thing. And some of the Voodoo Pirate magic is stored as a weapon and not as a spell. Those items should have been sold as wands not spells.

Powergamers can easily have godly avatars by the mid game if they smartly allocate but since my avatars are usually well rounded (I allocate dumbly) I didn't achieve the near invulnerable status until the end game. Many powergames who achieved that early power, looked at the game as super easy. However that is never" a problem with me because my main enjoyment of open world RPGS is exploration.  And this game does have it. And couple open world exploration with flying and this game many times had me in RPG nirvana.

The moronic video combat sequences
date: the horrible UI and the far too many arcade sequences knock this game down a few notches. But the nicely implemented open world
recommended: the over all great voice acting
hoursPlayed: superior music all coupled with flying take away many of the flaws. I would rate this game 7.8 to 8.5."

reviewText: Having played 14 hours of ther game, I've had to revise my opinion downwards.  Still a recommended deal if you can get it 75% off, but it's not worth full whack. It's a few steps improved over Risen 2, but sadly still suffers from jerky movement and scrolling control -- easy enough for the programmers to fix by upping the screen refresh, but they don't seem to take such suggestions on board, despite just about every review of earlier games going on about it.  As you progress through the learning curve, and get used to the awkward klunky combat control, you wait in constant expectation of the game getting better -- but it doesn't.  It's island hopping and running chores for NPCs who can't do simple tasks themselves.  Rough round the edges"

reviewText:
Before releasing this game, Piranha Bytes said they're going back to the roots with this game, they didn't exactly mean Gothic I / II here but more like Risen 1 but even so, it has a lot of things from the old Gothic series that makes me love this game very much.
Now, don't expect to see a top notch fluid AAA game here because it's not. It's more...classic to say but even so it's freaking great.
When I first launched this game I was a little bit disappointed (and even to this day I am a bit) about the fact that they just changed the main hero like that, no back story on what happened, nothing. Patty got more plastified (meaning her rack got incredibly huge) and well, it just jumps forward without really looking back on what happened in the past game and well, consequences and so. It gets explained a bit later on but still.
The main character has a pretty annoying voice at first but later on you get used to it and begin to love it.
Now, I'm not very good with reviews, I'm just pointing out some stuff that really touched me about the game and also some things that quite annoyed me so don't expect to see some kind of mlg 3valid5me IGN rating here.

I'll just say this. I recommend this game, it's ♥♥♥♥ing great, get it if you're into classic RPGs.

reviewText:
Don't let all the bad reviews led you astray. If you like the charm of all the Gothic/Risen games, this is a great RPG for under $10-15

There are some bugs and minor unpolished, but hey, that is part of the charm this series provides in my opinion. Textures, shaders and the level design are great quality as always - but of course, the animations are awkward like all games in the series. The story is meh, but the exploration is simply amazing. Nice free-roam options compared to past games.

I started back in the day with Gothic I+ and this game hits the right spot.

FYI. Just never play Arcania: Gothic 4.

reviewText:
I have played a lot of Pirahna Bytes games, including every Gothic game and Risen 2.  This game is an excellent addition to their catalogue.

First, you'll love this game if you're like me and enjoy the following things:

1.  A large amount of side quests, some of which have multiple possible solutions.

2.  A fairly large world to explore, and many secrets hidden by camera perspective, geography, and whether or not you can turn into a parrot right now.

3.  Being rewarded well for such exploring.

4.  The ability to chose a faction that affects the gameplay.

5.  A challenging fighting system (at least until you max out toughness and nothing can hurt you any more).

Although I very much enjoyed my playthrough, here are some things that could be improved.

1.  The moral choices seem to have only small impacts on the game.

2.  The factions aren't developed enough, you max out your rank in no time with just a little concentrated effort.

3.  There aren't as many puzzles as I remember in Risen 2.  Exploring ruins as a pirate necessitates more puzzles and traps.

4.  The majority of the quests are the same regardless of whether or not you joined a faction.

Lastly, a piece of advice from an avid off the main path player, join a faction right away.  You get special abilities for doing so that if you wait until you've done everything else, you won't have long to enjoy.  Also, it can save you some back and forth from traveling.

reviewText:
It's not Gothic I or II by any stretch of the imagination, and in many ways it's slightly inferior to Risen 1, which suffered from many problems itself.

The plot has its moments, but overall it's fairly straightforward, with no memorable characters and mediocre writing at best. As expected from other Piranha titles, it's in the exploration the game really shines. The environments are sizeable and detailed, begging to be discovered. While clearly not a triple A. it's still a pretty game. Few studios do atmosphere so well like Piranha Bytes.

The combat is not terrible as in earlier titles, but it does get old and does not scale well. The last hours will drag on for the lack of challenge, new mechanics and interesting places to visit. It doesn't help that the last location to be visited is also the least appealing.

Still, it's an enjoyable adventure and worth the purchase, especially if picked on a sale.

It's a few steps improved over Risen 2, but sadly still suffers from jerky movement and scrolling control -- easy enough for the programmers to fix by upping the screen refresh, but they don't seem to take such suggestions on board, despite just about every review of earlier games going on about it.  As you progress through the learning curve, and get used to the awkward klunky combat control, you wait in constant expectation of the game getting better -- but it doesn't.  It's island hopping and running chores for NPCs who can't do simple tasks themselves.  Rough round the edges"
recommended: it's a steal.  Dialogue has clearly been recorded at different studio sittings rather than sequentially and often doesn't flow smoothly
hoursPlayed: or share environmental reverb effects
voteText: or even mesh sensibly.\n\nThere's some minor humour in this dry game when Mud joins the team

reviewText:
Before releasing this game, Piranha Bytes said they're going back to the roots with this game, they didn't exactly mean Gothic I / II here but more like Risen 1 but even so, it has a lot of things from the old Gothic series that makes me love this game very much.
Now, don't expect to see a top notch fluid AAA game here because it's not. It's more...classic to say but even so it's freaking great.
When I first launched this game I was a little bit disappointed (and even to this day I am a bit) about the fact that they just changed the main hero like that, no back story on what happened, nothing. Patty got more plastified (meaning her rack got incredibly huge) and well, it just jumps forward without really looking back on what happened in the past game and well, consequences and so. It gets explained a bit later on but still.
The main character has a pretty annoying voice at first but later on you get used to it and begin to love it.
Now, I'm not very good with reviews, I'm just pointing out some stuff that really touched me about the game and also some things that quite annoyed me so don't expect to see some kind of mlg 3valid5me IGN rating here.

I'll just say this. I recommend this game, it's ♥♥♥♥ing great, get it if you're into classic RPGs.

reviewText: Risen 3 is an amazing game, just plain amazing. One of the only interesting tittles to come out in 2014 in my oppinion. I payed full price for it, and i personallly don't regret it at all. The world looks beautiful, The variety of enemies is very well handled, and the story is quite interesting. reviewText: Avid Gothic series fan here - wanted to give Risen 3 a try thinking that it would be the culmination of the respective series. This game lacks souls. It is linear, with poor voice acting and a slugish gothic-esque remake of a combat system. You are honestly better off trying old school RPGs and/or modding them.
voteText: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Fantastic game! I will admit, I am a sucker for fantasy rpgs and pirate games but I loved it. I was a fan from the Risen series from the get go and I enjoyed this game thoroughly. I know, It is easy, way easy, super easy. For me, that didn't detract from the game. So the gameplay was easy, the rest of the game is amazing. I love how beautiful and big the islands are to explore, I liked the story and the game content involved. The character's batman voice was a bit hard at first but you grow on it. I have so many hours in this game, you can't believe it, I really enjoy long games. I love the risen series and this one was great. If you like rpgs with amazing worlds and tons to do then this is for you even if it is easy. I can't wait to see what Piranha byte does next and I might play their old stuff in Gothica. RPG's are my thing, and this series was everything I like from RPGs and more. Risen 1 was a good world and very hard. The second one was a great pirate game with a good story and something I could get behind. Risen 3 had beautiful world, funny characters, and a perfect length. I think you would all enjoy the Risen series, and I'm sad to see it end.

reviewText:
I have not played through all areas of the game, but for the majority that I have seen:
Human NPCs have are either white or black (native), with a single type of seemingly cretinous gnome-like nonhuman speaking only in broken english.
Women are (aside from Patty, the protagonist's sister) extremely scarce, but what few there are seem to fall cleanly into 'witch' 'housewife' and [loose woman] stereotypes (the filter system does not let one use the normal english word for this.)
NPC and protagonist dialog includes numerous misogynistic remarks and 'jokes', with a few racist and homophobic ones thrown in as well.
This is a change from previous games, so I can only assume the the developers made a conscious effort to be more negative towards women and other minorities.
As this is a high-fantasy game with monsters, powerful mages, etc... any 'historical accuracy' excuse is mooted without consideration.
As a developer I find this sort of behaviour from a game designer unprofessional, cowardly, offensive, incompetent and embarrassing - at best. Because this is a change for the developers from previous games,  I cannot help but wonder if they have not made some serious internal errors in management allowing angry feelings in their staff develop into such such near-hateful content.
Development is hard - sometimes one ships a buggy, incomplete, and/or less than fun turd.  This is different as it was intentional; they published text, quests and, dialog, etc... expressing these sentiments. Ultimately the senior management of the firm is responsible for the sentiments expressed in their software, and holding them to this responsibitly for me requires not supporting the firm with my purchases again.

reviewText:
Definition of clunky
Is this the worst RPG ever? Well, maybe it‘s not the worst. I heard about Raven‘s cry and it‘s re-release Vendetta which now is taken from steam too, but because of awful user feedback i did not even consider to support that scam of a game. This one on the other hand has plenty of good reviews and feedback. But how? Probably from the people who only played Piranha Bytes  games?

Since the Gothic 3 Piranha Bytes are making horrible games. I remember Gothic 3, it was beautiful looking game at the time, but it had worst combat ever and messed up quest system, i just stopped playing that crap after a few hours.
I did not play Risen and only tried Risen 2 for an hour or so and uninstalled it. Risen 3 titan lords is a very strong contender for the worst combat in an RPG game. It‘s like Piranha Bytes do this intentionally, just to irritate people.

The combat makes this game unplayable. It‘s absolutely broken. Your moves are so slow that you just can‘t hit anything, you slowly swing your sword and get interrupted by the enemies attack. If you try to block them and attack after blocking, the enemy just jumps away in a speed of lightning and you miss, then immediately you get attacked again. Blocking does not always work, i‘d say you can‘t block 1/3 of attacks. You/enemies getting stuck on a rock, or camera rotating randomly to the angle where you can‘t see anything is nothing compared to awful combat. The controls are unresponsive and clunky, your character is very slow. In addition to the sword you can shoot a gun which again is so slow that you get attacked by an enemy which moves and react too fast before you shoot the gun. And if you get lucky to use your gun without interruption it misses most of the time even if the enemy is 2 meters away.

But there are things which will make you laugh instead of being angry. The voice acting, it‘s hilarious, i don‘t know if it‘s intentional but it‘s so bad that it‘s making you laugh. Generic NPC‘s have better voice acting than main characters.

Dialogues are boring and uninteresting. Same as quests. It is generic as it can be. Also quest tracking doesn‘t work most of the time. The map is pointless, NPC's or shops aren't marked on it, but gladly you don‘t need to search for shops long in those cities with 3 traders and other 2 random people giving you generic quests.

Game imitates the feeling of open world. Similar to Age of reckoning. But Risen 3 does it much worse. The locations are much much smaller. It‘s not an open world game!

The graphics probably is the best thing in this game. It‘s average but at least it‘s not ugly. Character models is another thing, they‘re ugly and generic, with poor animations and almost no face animations.

Avoid this game. Avoid it even if on sale at 75%. I regret my decision buying it for that price. It‘s not worth your time, unless you feel obliged to play it because you paid for it, there‘s no reason to play it. Just stay away and stop supporting Piranha Bytes.

Pros:

Patty

Cons:

Graphics
Voice acting
Generic quests
Poor combat
Small generic maps
Clunky unresponsive controls

reviewText: This really isn't good enough to justify being 50+ hours long, but it's okay.  Risen 2 is clearly the best of these three games, but if you liked Risen 2, this is probably worth playing.  In Risen 1, the last quarter of the game is a miserable slog through overpowered creatures that can take half your health in one shot if you don't time the block exactly right.  Risen 3 I was never close to being in any danger at any point after about half way through.  You can do the combat without even watching, just keep pressing left mouse while watching TV works.  You really don't even need to bother spending much time leveling up, just let the glory pile up and every once in a while maybe add to something.  PB needs to find a better middle ground in their combat.  The story in this one takes a really long time to get properly going, like 15-20 hours in, but once it does it's engaging.

reviewText:
Risen 3 is a game that I found disapointing and fustrating. The main reaons I didn't like this game is because it isn't anything like Risen and a lot like Risen 2.

There isn't anything about Risen 3 that I could say was great and at the same time there isn't anything about Risen 3 that I could say was awful. Risen 3 is this average game, annoyingly so because you often see moments of greatness, but it's never quite there.

After thirteen hours play time I've been unable to find a reason to continue with the game.  It feels like Piranha bytes are happy with okay and that pushing to make something great isn't quite within their grasp.

Piranha bytes can make amazing games, Gothic 1 and 2, Risen 1, but for some reason prequels are not quite their domain.

The game seems to still suffer from crashing, on a newly built pc with a new OS, which is above the recommend settings.


If it's in the sale and you liked Risen 2, buy, if not, stay away!

reviewText:
This is one of my first reviews for a game on steam, so I will try my best to cover the pros and cons of Risen 3. I will bring the conclusion at first, so that people searching for an indicator may find my judgment without reading the whole text.

IMPORTANT: This games has problems with some CPUs or system configurations! - It won't work in some cases!! - Therefore, consult the PB forum for more information!

Conclusion: This game is not worth 50 €/$. Let me be me ore specific: For fans of Risen it may be a must have, but for all others that are looking for a good/excellent rpg game which provides you with tons of quests, variety, a good combat system, polished gameplay and game engine, Risen 3 should not be your choice. The graphics engine is really old, textures are not provided in a high resolution, and even the world design (even if it is really good) cannot hide the shortcomings of the really old engine. The designers tried their best but the engine does not provide enough features to create a fully living world and this is experienced in the very first moments you enter the jungle in Risen 3. This fact is reflected if you take a closer look at the scene. The models are, how shall I say, really really bad; no (face) gestures at all, animations are choppy.  Another very important aspect of an RPG is the combat system. This is the biggest shortcoming of Risen 3. First, it is completely unbalanced. In the early stages of the game each creatures might be your death, later on you feel like god and nothing can really kill (except you head for a coffee and it takes you 5 minutes until you come back ...). Second, the factions are more or less a nice to have but after you have learned the most skills" the spells earned by the factions are just for fun and do not seriously influence the combat.


Detailed Review:

Impressions/Opinion:
I have to admit
date: I am a very big fan of Gothic 1 & 2. One reason that I bought the game were the reviews that are provided by computer magazines. In fact it was the "open world" which disappointed me already in the beginning of the game. I felt somehow cheated because the game has not the freedom as a Gothic 1 or 2. It still fells like Risen 2. NO
recommended: there is no "open world" or freedom in the game
hoursPlayed: except the selection of the so-called factions. The game follows a strict chapter system and islands are quite linear. The world does not feel like its living. If you have cleared/killed all creatures on an island
voteText: you are done
helpfulPercent: there is nothing left to kill and there will nothing respawn (that’s it). Sure
votesHelpful: there are a lot of side quests but there is no real difference between the main story and the side quests. I have played many RPGs but I seldom come across such a bad story telling. The "quests" are very generic like
votesTotal: "kill x"
votesFunny: "bring me xyz". It feels like playing an really old RPG in 2014. If you have seen the 5 (including the first one where you start and are brought back to "life") main islands
commentsCount: which are not that big as it looks like in the beginning
column16: there won't come any more (SPOILER: a sixth island at the end for the very last fight/quests). The combat system is useless at its best. In the early game it feels like every creature may be the last creature you will face and after the first 4 hours you get so strong that fights become just a necessity and does not feel like an epic fight. I won't talk about boss fights because they are not really any better but writing about them may spoiler one or two things. But
column17: bosses are just like events
column18:
nice to watch. A real challenge is the gameplay and that you do not fall off some shores or edges if you are hunting for hidden places...

Technical discussion:
There is not much positive to say. As already mentioned in the conclusion the engine is old and the models are far from state-of-the-art
column19: such as in Witcher 2 or BioShock Infinite. The models are definitely missing vertices
column20: such as the terrain and everything in this game. The textures have a really low resolution and sometimes they look awkward and misplaced. Furthermore
column21:
the game crashes from time to time (if it even decides to run on your system).  The animations of the models are really choppy and are not that smooth as someone may expect for a game that was released mid 2014.

Last words:
I am just curious why this game got such good review from computer magazines. This game is just a refresh of Risen 2 with some really MINOR improvements. In fact
