reviewText:
So ive beaten the game. My end cutscene went to play and the character starts walking to the camp on skull island. It looked like Bones was going to say something but before he could it cut to the ship sailing out of the island. So if i want that end sequence ive got to kill the end boss again which is ok i never got anything from the story in this game so I will wait for someone to upload it on youtube.

So complaints.

1) Combat starts off very slow, this is the only game ive ever played where you absolutely rely on your companion to kill things when you first start.

2) Combat requires no skill. You can cheese almost every fight effortlessly there is little to no reward to killing anything except for the 3rd Kraken which is the only truely frustrating part of the game.

3) Glitches, Oh my god glitches i felt like I was playing an Alpha of Risen 3 mind you none of these glitches caused a blue screen, full system crash, or crash of game.

4) Guidance at times is at an absolute bare minimum. I consider myself an Intelligent person and I found myself frustrated more then a few times even after listening to all dialog options. My most annoyed moment would be the Books of Evil quest from the Demon hunters for your first promotion.

5) Dialog was often incredibly annoying and no I am not talking about the Gnomes their dialog was intended to be absolutely annoying. Thankfully right clicking cured this for me just dont do it during a quest giver.

6) Cutscenes throughtout the game are soooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo excessive and not in a good way like Metal Gear Solid 4's 7 or 8 hours of cutscenes, Most cutscenes in this game are clearly rushed everything from key speakers faces blurring out to horrible choices of background music which most of the time sounded incredibly close to the fight music.

7) Enemy Diversity is bleh. I also took note of the spiders working with the shadows on skull island. Was mostly confused by that considering the Oracle was using them to attack both humans and shadows from what that whole ♥♥♥♥ty story explained.

8) Most points of the game I would complete quests like allying with the Inqusition and it had a moment to do a cutscene or give dialog options and it wouldnt. So when you kill Sebastion it just cutscenes to your boat pulling into its destination and your character saying well they will fight for us. There felt like a lot of information was just skipped over it felt like listening to an average 5th graders explination of their family vacation. There were holes all throughout leaving you wanting much more. I just wanted a Hey thanks for saving us from that crazy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ i thought he was going to kill me next.".

9) Some skills pop up as weapons in your equipment page whereas some skills like Monkey Trainer pop up as an Item in your inventory so you have to dig and find them. I for instance forgot I had monkey trainer which actually would have been helpful much earlier on in the game but when you buy skills theres no hey idiot your skill is right here when its not going to be in the normal place.

So in closure I still will not recommend this game until it goes on sale. This game is like Aliens Collonial Marines half made garbage which is only good for killing time when absolutely bored. Regardless of my complaints I did find myself having fun with Demon Hunter skills stacked with blade dancer and how OP they make you if you are melee built. That build literally makes you 2 shot a Shadow Lord in about 1/8th of a second. The game was waaaaaay too easy. I barely died at all with all of them being in the same spot the 3rd Kraken.

This is one of the few games Ive played and gotton bored while playing...
I had literally more fun in Aliens Colonial Marines then this and that was a flaming POS with a much better written story.

5/10 its very "Meh""

reviewText: If you like the Fable series you'll probably like this game. It's the same kind of thing, you play as a generic fantasy adventurer who has to defeat a great evil and restore the land to normal. There are your usual swords and maces as well as pistols and muskets and ♥♥♥♥ for a more piratey feel.\n\nIt's quite a fun romp through a series of west-indies looking islands complete with ruins, treasure, and demonic undead creatures. The story and dialogue can be kind of silly sometimes but the voice acting isn't horrible and most of the quests aren't just the cliche kill 10 rats" type. The combat is solid
date: some of the player animations appear to have been recycled from Assassin's Creed and the graphics are nice enough to keep you interested as you trek through the jungles in search of quest objectives.\n\nI rate 7.5/10
recommended: this game is cheesier than margarita pizza but makes me want to keep playing it which in an RPG is a pretty important thing."

reviewText: Pirahna bytes makes some awesome rpgs, i think they deserve more $$ from the gaming community in general. Im pretty sure this game has been on sale for $1-$3 a few times. Kind of depressing to see companies like this not making that much money. reviewText:
not as good as the previous 2 games, this one starts you in a cutscene-filled tutorial, then kills you by cutscene, as a way to then drop your stats and gear to a 'starting' point.

i had to drop my screen resolution to get it to run smoothly, it has a very bad habit of taking control away from the player repeatadely. while previous games did this as well on occasion, it is more pronounced and annoying with this one.

patty (from games 1 and 2) and bones(from game 2) make an early appearance. the voice acting quality feels worse overall.

reviewText:
Just to say a few words for Gothic fans (and those who read somewhere Gothic is better series).
I'm also Gothic series #1 fan.

Risen 3 is not Gothic but a completely different setting. If you wanted Gothic 5 (and we all want it), don't buy Risen 3 thinking that's it. It's not.

Risen 3 is a different openworld from Gothic games. Here you can go just about anywhere since the start. In Gothics... Well... You can't or if you try, you'll die miserably. In Gothics you have to build your character before trying to survive the desert or mountains part. Sadly, because of Risen 2 reviews, mobs got too easy to kill in Risen 3.

Risen 3, apart from nasty CPU cores problem, has almost no bug at all. Gothic 3 had more bugs than patched Skyrim which sounds like a lie but it's not (Skyrim final version still has more than 500 bugs unpatched, Gothic 3 when released had just a few more).

In Gothics no mobs respawn endlessly (except wild dogs in desert). In Risen 3, some mobs seem to respawn (wildbirds, bigrats).



Risen 3 is the best exploration game out there. You don't know what's behind a corner and you want to know it. If you're adventurous type of a person, buy this game, it's worth every penny.

reviewText:
I find Risen 3 to be a very atmospheric experience. Pirahna Bytes seem to have a knack with created well thought out land masses that you can remember and recall, long after leaving.

I have played Gothic, Gothic II, Risen and Risen 2 to completion multiple times.
The Gothic series is one of those gems that just never gets old, no matter how long time goes by.

But, to Risen 3.
10 hours in, Risen 3 is definitely the best of the Risen franchise. Combining multiple islands and quests seamlessly, without much interuption. Including the old Faction based quests and pursuits. Creating the well known atmosphere of past PB games.
I was scepticle, once I saw the piratey beginning. Felt exactly like Risen 2, which I did like, but not as much as I wanted to. Then after a short introduction on an island, things change and open up incredibly. Like, choose anywhere, and go. And you can swim between many points on each island, yes!  Each island holds a different feel and attitude. With different characters and ideologies.

Characters have there own agendas and ideas, which I am enjoying. They have added many dialogue sequences dependant on the character that is following you, or location you have entered, or who you're talking to. I have replayed dialogues with diffferent characters, with some interesting dialogue responses, that can change the way the charater interacts with you. Makes them feel more believable.

Combat has it's flaws, but is ultimately enjoyable. Some (me) may find it easier then traditional Gothic combat, but animations and cues are properly executed this time around. No more countering, and finding nothing happens, even though you were perfectly timing the counter. It just works. And crystal magic. GREAT. Really fun stuff.

Although fetch quests are prominent, I enjoyed walking between points, as to me, the game looks great.
I have read many reviews stating that this game looks like a PS2 game, or that it is downright horrible.
I think it has a very unique style and artistic flow, that combines many new systems that enhance the overall aesthetic.
Also, the lighting, looks incredible. Some scenes are truly breathtaking. Yes, there is certain instances, where the game looks kind of funky, but to base the entire graphical experience on these minor flaws is downright stupid.

Anyway, I feel this game is a step in the right direction for Pirahna Bytes.

Though, I would love to see a brand new series, more akin to the Gothic series pop up.

Anyway, great job team! Thank you! :D

reviewText:
ว่าจะหา RPG เล่นขำๆ แม่มกลายเป็นเล่นยาว ฝอยซะเลย
ตัวเกมส์มีเควสโครตเยอะ พูดตรงๆกดข้ามลูกเดียว คือมันมีประมาณ 500 เควสเลยมั้ง (=_=)
เพราะรู้ตัวอีกทีก็ปลดล็อค Achievement ทำเควส 300 ไปแล้ว
แถมมีบทพูดทุกเควส บางคนขนาดกดข้ามยังคุยยาว ถ้านับบทพูดคงเป็น 100 ชั่วโมงเข้าไปแล้ว คือโครตเทพเลยจริงๆ  สำหรับคนบ้าเควส
.... นึกว่าเล่นสกายริม

ระบบคอมแบท ทำออกมาได้ค่อนข้างดี ระบบสกิลของเกมส์ที่ต้องอัพสเตตัส เป็นสกิลประเภทติดตัว
มีสามสาย คือ เวทย์มนต์ วูดู แล้วก็ เดม่อนฮันเตอร์ อาวุธ ก็ดาบ เวทย์ ปิน

- AI ศัตรูค่อนข้างเดิมๆ และค่อนข้างมีน้อย นับรูปแบบได้เลย

ระบบไอเท็ม อันนี้ก็โครตเทพอีกเหมือนกัน มีระบบ Recipt ผสมของ คราฟปืน คราฟดาบ ไอเท็มยานี่ไม่ต้องพูดถึง โครตเยอะ
(แต่แทบไม่ค่อยได้ใช้หรอก เยอะเกิน)

ระบบเสริม ก็มีพวกฟาสทราเวล คือ เปิดจุดวาป การแปลงเป็นนกเพื่อบิน แต่ที่ไม่เข้าใจว่าจะใส่มาทำไมคือฝึกลิง เพราะไม่มีเควสให้ลิงไปทำจริงจัง

ที่ต้องมาพูด คือช่วงหลัง อารมณ์อยากเล่นให้จบ เวนกำมาก ปวดหัว กับเกมส์เควสเยอะไปอีกนานเลย แต่เนื้อเรื่องก็ถือว่าโอเค

เอาไป 7.5/10 เฉลี่ยกันไป

reviewText:
Made an awful first impression on me (maybe because I haven't played Risen), but then turned out to be pretty good.
It took me a while to figure out the combat system, but once I've bought myself a better sword and added some skill points, it became quite decent (although dodging all day long seems to be the way).

All in all, misjudged the game terribly at first, and now, a few months later, I'm actually enjoying it. If you decide to get it, brace yourself for the cringeworthy first 15 minutes, and keep in mind that what you're experiencing is by far the worst part of an otherwise decent RPG.

reviewText:
First of all, let me emphasize that this is a Piranha Game in all aspects. Which is good for me, but apparently does not fit well with some people.

I started playing Piranha Games with Gothic 1 and played every game since, so I knew what to expect and am happy to report that the NPCs talk at length about trivial things and have to be forced to get to the point, you only get a fixed set of useful Armor that is restricted to your Group etc.

A lot of people apparently don't like this, but for me that's a Piranha Game. If you liked the first two Gothics, this game is for you.

Warning: From here on there might be Spoilers

As a long-time fan, here's what I think about Risen 3 compared to the Gothic series and the other two Risens:
I loved it. It reminded my why I fell in love with Gothic and I am going to play it again to see the way the game goes if you choose to be something else then a Voodoo-Pirate.
In comparison to Risen 2 I think it's much better. Which is great, as I thought Risen 2 was way better then Risen 1, so this seems to be a trend.
Even the usually sucking Piranha Final Boss Battle was bearable. As a reminder, in Risen 1 the final Boss Battle neglected all your life choices" and stuck you into magic Armor and Weaponry that made you a great fighter
date: even if you had gone the Mage way and put you into some kind of Arcade-Battle against a Big-Boss. Ugh.\nRisen 2 had Mara
recommended: but I only remember from that fight that I didn't like it.\nThis time
hoursPlayed: it had sucking moments
voteText: sure. But I could play to my strengths I acquired during the game and at one point Bones jumped in to save the day
helpfulPercent: which I assume was a bug
votesHelpful: but I liked it.\n\nCompared to the Gothic Series I dare say this is the game I was hoping for when Gothic 3 came out. It had all the charm
votesTotal: wits and anecdotes that made the first two Gothic Parts great and none of the empty world and hastily crafted Quests. Playing Risen 3 I couldn't but think of how great a game Gothic 3 could have been if it came out a year later. Even half a year.\n\nSo all good? Of cause not. There are a lot of things they can do better and I hope they will for Risen 4. But none of the following "bad stuff" really impacted my great experience

reviewText:
The game is okay, but I still would not recommend it (maybe during a sale)

Pro:
+ The atmosphere of the game is quite good. The pirate/island setting is authentic.
+ The graphics are good enough for me.
+ Many locations to explore and a lot of secrets to discover.
+ The music was okay.
+ Many customization options (melee, range or magic skills. accessoires, armor and weapons.)
+ The combat is a bit more interesting than the combat in the second game.
+ No bugs discovered
+ You can choose one of three different factions. You can choose to be good or evil.
+ I liked the references to the Gothic series.

Con:
- The main reason why i cannot recommend the game is because IT IS BORING! The actual main quest that should keep me playing took me about 3 hours. Doing all side quests and explore all the unimportant stuff took me about 48 hours (DLCs included). I have to say that I was not entertained by all this useless exploring and sidequesting.
- It is better than the second risen game but it is still a bad sequel to the first game. I have no idea why in the world this game takes place in the southern sea while the actual action takes place on the mainland. The story has no real direction and is totally disappointing. I would expect something magnificent from the third part of a storyline. Until now I am not even sure who or what Titan Lords/Ladies are.
- I finished the game 5 days ago and I cannot remember 99% of the characters. They are all faceless, boring and unimportant.
- The boss battles are boring and some take a lot of patience because they hide often. (Minor spoiler now: The final boss battle is frustrating as hell if you do not own an AOE attack.)
- The overall voice acting is terrible. The main character sounds like he has lung cancer.
- The jokes are mediocre.
- All choices you make have no real effect on the story or anything else.
- The game is too easy (even on hard) and monotonous. I became a melee warrior and was just bashing the left mouse button and killed everthing.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm no pro when it comes to reviewing games so I will make this quick. This game at first glance seemed as a rip-off, appearing rather as an expansion pack to Risen 2, same world, inventory, skill-system, graphics, etc. The game however changed my mind once I really delved into some of the quests. They were great. I can't complain, they were fun, sometimes challenging, and for the most part unique. That's what really made the game for me. That and combat. At first I was upset about the weakness of the character in the beginning but as you learn and become more skillfull, not as a character but as a player, I becomes great. Upgrading weapons and skills really pays off, and in the end, you are unstoppable. Overall I recommend this game not because it was incredibly impressive or original, but because it was incredibly fun.

Pros:                                                          Cons:
-Great combat                                           -Much of recycled Risen 2 material
-Lots of fun quests                                    -Graphics haven't changed
-Great selection of playing style                -Voice acting could be better

reviewText:
If there is one game that does not deserve the bad critics its gotten, it is this one! A cannot for the life of me understand why people bash it so much.

I have spent 50+ hours so far and I keep comming back for more. For fans of the old Piranha Bytes games this is a must buy!

Don't believe the bad hype about bad combat system and reuse of content from Risen 2! It's simply not true... People that claim that this is Risen 2.5 are lying!
Granted the combat system could have been better, but it is functional and a big improvement compared to the abysmal combat system in Risen 2.

Regarding reuse of contant... Yes some of the islands from Risen 2 is still there, but they have been redone from scratch and there are also 2 islands that are completly new and those are more medieval in apperance.

The story is cliche, and the voice acting are typical Piranha as is the case with all of their games. But after the total miss that was Risen 2 I am glad to see that they once again deliver an entertaining and fun game that will keep your interest for weeks.

reviewText: I recently purchased Risen 3 - Titan Lords and the addon Fog Island.  After figuring out how to minimize the bobbing of the camera, I played for a while and was starting to enjoy the game.  Then this morning after only 68 minutes into the game, I went in and received an error message saying that to continue I must install downloadable content.  After checking out the web, I found that if I wanted to play the must purchase extra content.  Huh?  I thought I bought a complete and playable game.   How was I to know that at 10 hours or 20 hours, I would be required to purchase more downloadable content.  I might be nickled and dimed until my pocket book was dry.  Though the content wasn't expensive, I did not like this.  I got a refund under Steam's generous refund policy.  Sorry, but I can't recommend this game.\nMike

reviewText:
Risen 3 is a amazing open world RPG  with unique memorable characters .  Following the events of the 1st and 2nd game this time you arent playing as the Nameless hero from the  1st and 2nd Game but rather a character that was mentioned previously you now play The Heir  to  the great pirate Steelbeard , Steelbeard's Son .

Following events at the crab coast  where you lost your Soul you are tasked with ridding the world from an attack from the underworld  shadows and demons are lurking around every corner and the world is in chaos you are to forge alliances between factions while also joining a faction to fend the world from all the chaos . every  choice and exploration you will do is rewarded with different rewards  wether you join the Natives and regain your old  ship back  or the Mages with their Crystal magic or the Demon Hunters with their Demon hunting Runes and summons .

There are Alot of Choices and every choice you make will help you on your quest .
Risen 3 takes from the 1st two games in the series and expand the world even more  with much more mechanics and expanding the available skills  combos.
The  Main factions you can Join  will Offer  Way Different styles of gameplay from each other choose wisely .
This game is an Amzing open world  Adventure RPG game there are alot of things to do .
The 2 DLC Islands offer Unique Storyline to their  islands  with hours of gameplay .

I Recommend This game to be played Especially by those Who have played the First two games

reviewText:
I would recommend this game for players who like an old fashioned gothic RPG. It is not a game for everybody as they don't try to please all players and that makes their games valuable.

I was struggling through the first part of the game because since Risen 2 they changed for some strange reason basic movement and melee combat to worse - it feels heavy, always some milisecond later then camera, and in combat the character does some random combos that cannot be stopped (in Risen 1 you had complete control over combos and you had to learn every step in 1-9 ranks) so it could be frustrating even on easy mode...
But as someone promised in his review, the game starts to be interesting after joining one of the faction. I would recommend Demon Hunters as this is the new faction there and it has the gothic feel as Mages had in Risen 1. I would advice to play for Mages later, because in Risen 3 they are a bit old and senile, which is good, that it is not the same as in the previous series. Actually nothing is the same. I was surprised how well it was remade, how funny and original was every character I met in the game. That is better from Risen 2, which looks similar, but there wasn't enough of mystic or funny features that would keep me interested.

So I wish they would release another DLC made for fans of Risen 1 combat where they would implement the old movement system even with funny animations, but smooth, and combat ranks with the advices from trainers, where you would have to learn every new step in combat system.

Add:
after the last patch that was upgrading graphic the camera seems to be more smooth.

I have to say this game would get 10/10 from me and it is GOTTY of 2014 for me.
It is because a lot of new varied content that is added in 2nd part of the game and visible progresssion of the main character, how every chapter adds new skills and challenges, it would deserve that.

Also I have to say I love the voice acting of the main character, so I guess it is subjective if some players dislike that.

reviewText:
I might recommend this game if the camera weren't so bad.

It's very hard to play thanks to the way your view jumps all over the place during combat.

Trying to parry a hit that will kill you?

Nah, the camera is going to jump behind the monster you're fighting with impeccable timing to ensure that you miss that parry. Woe be unto you if you're fighting in a cave because it's even worse when there's no room for you to even hope the view spasm will settle on an angle where you can still see what you're doing.

I liked the first two so, despite this one not being released where I bought the rest of them, I saw it on sale and picked it up. Unfortunately, between all the forum searching for fixes like editing the config file and Googling for a way to make it work, I've played" beyond the return window for getting my $10 back.

I really hope they release a fix for this because
recommended: if the game were actually playable (in any way other than reloading saves and hoping it doesn't go crazy for long enough that I can progress a bit) I think that probably would've been a great deal."

reviewText:

pro:

- PB-style dialogues and story, if you are into it

cons:
- REALLY ANNOYING combat system. I appreciate that they tried something new other than the mindless click-to-death"-system of earlier games
date: but this time they just failed.\nInstead of attack-spamming you have to keep spamming evasion rolls
recommended: the combat often feels random and parrying is a game of chance
hoursPlayed: even the most basic critters attack really fast and without a telltale sign. The melee targeting system does'nt work out at all: When you fight more than two enemies simultaneously

votesHelpful:
or the focus stays on a recently killed enemy.
- Balancing is crap. Some boss fights are extremely unfair if you do not posess certain skills or magic spells (the Margoloth fight for example).

Although I love the general PB-retro-charme of the game

reviewText:
I really tried to like this game. I lôike the thrre Gothic games and the frst Risen (the second one ws garbage) and I thought this one would be OK. It is not.

In some games, you arrive at a point where tyou don't give a rat's ♥♥♥ about the story anymore, you just want to finish for the sake of finishig. Here I had that moment after leaving the first island. The second island I went to felt empty - almost noone there and it was supposed to be a living town. I found a few locked chests, but one single frickin' lockpick. And the battle system is completely lousy. Your character takes ages between sword swings, so much that a few Scavengers (pretty much the weekest foe) can be hard to kill. A fencing duel against a human(oid) with a weapon is a matter of more luck than skill. And there is nothing really driving you to keep going.

Leave this one and play the first Risen or Gothic III. Much, much better choices than this.

reviewText:
A pretty good game for sure!  I got about 60 hours of fun with it using both DLCs.

On the plus side
Great exploration!  They don't limit you so don't be surprised when you finish a quest you didn't even know about yet.
Graphics are quite nice.  There's an enhanced" edition rumored but the stock graphics are really quite nice.
Good quests.  Organization of the quest log can be a bit dicey (was that an island quest or a crew quest??) but having so many quests that they can be a bit hard to track is a great problem to have.
A nice sprinkling of good humor.
Mostly bug-free.  There are a few bugs here and there but nothing that really hurt my fun.
Good autosave PLUS quick save PLUS named save system.  Why can't all games do this?
On the minus side
Manual level scaling (see below).
Too few monster types.
Sea battles start interesting but get tedious.  (Luckily

Have played an hour so far. I game the first two risen games a try but the first was dated and the second i just couldnt get into but this one actually has been quite good so far.

Gameplay: everything works but combat can feel a bit weird at times and there is no way to really choose who you use your ranged weapon on. its just who is currently attacking you but there is cool stuff like a spell that makes you a parot to overcome obstacles in game by flying which i like 7/10

Graphics: the environments geneally look very good and vibrant tho they cant compare to the witcher or crisis they usually look good but the character movements are kind of shoddy and the faces and hands look a bit off. but id give it a 7/10

Story: pretty simple character brought back to life through magic type story but the sidequests seem like they might be interesting as ive just encountered a pirate named booze who is very mad at his friend harry and thats better than the usual i need ten flowers
date:
you get them bro" 6/10

level design: this is where the game shines. i can already tell how much exploration is going to be available outside of the main quest 8/10


long stroy short if you find it on sale i think its worth a shot

7/10"

reviewText:
If you ever played (and liked) a game from famous Gothic series or its successor Risen series, play this by any means.

It offers the same great cocktail any Gothic fan likes: exploration, progression and unbeatable feel of adventure. No randomised or procedurally generated content that is the norm these days - every island is unique, enemies, treasures, NPcs and even grass and bushes are carefully placed where the authors wanted them to be to create an adventure you won't forget.

The only nitpick I have is the fact that the game becomes almost too easy after the middle when you start to steamroll everything. On the other hand, it may be good since not many people today will play a game as difficult as Gothic 2: Night of the Raven for example where you ought to conserve perma potions till the end and slaughter most of the monsters for experience with a starting sword. In Risen 3 it is still a good idea to keep the perma potions until you reach skill 70 (hint!), but the game should remain manageable even if you fail in character build up big time. In short, it will be a breeze for Gothic veterans and ok difficulty for newcomers (and you can always adjust difficulty in the options if the game feels too difficult or too easy).

Highly recommended, a nice adventure you'll keep fond memories of.

reviewText: I recently purchased Risen 3 - Titan Lords and the addon Fog Island.  After figuring out how to minimize the bobbing of the camera, I played for a while and was starting to enjoy the game.  Then this morning after only 68 minutes into the game, I went in and received an error message saying that to continue I must install downloadable content.  After checking out the web, I found that if I wanted to play the must purchase extra content.  Huh?  I thought I bought a complete and playable game.   How was I to know that at 10 hours or 20 hours, I would be required to purchase more downloadable content.  I might be nickled and dimed until my pocket book was dry.  Though the content wasn't expensive, I did not like this.  I got a refund under Steam's generous refund policy.  Sorry, but I can't recommend this game.\nMike

reviewText: Hands down, one of the worst games I've ever played. The combat and AI (enemies and friends) pretty much makes this game unplayable.  Combat consists of just rolling, rolling, rolling, attack, rolling, rolling, roll into a rock and get hit, rolling, rolling, attempt blocking, die. If you have multiple enemies on you, it's pretty much impossible solo. I don't know how the devs thought that this system was ok. I mean...REALLY?\n\nDO NOT BUY THIS GAME.

reviewText: Risen 3 is laughably bad. For a few minutes I thought it might be a parody game, a Sharknado of gaming where the developers were intentionally trying to make things as laughbaly awful as possible. Terrible voice acting, stilted animations, laggy and boring combat and a generally unprofessional polish and feel. The graphics are bizarre; the game came out in 2014 yet somehow looks much, much older. The environments are passable, but the character models are stilted and poorly put together.\n\nThe interaction with my companion"

reviewText:
Very fun game. I just started to play this game not to long ago and I am really enjoyying it so far.  Graphics are  pretty good considering the size of the game. Combat takes some practice, but very engaging. Money is hard to come by, but that is a good thing, I suppose.

Questing gets a little confusing as every time you talk to someone with a name, you get a quest. Soon, you have a book load of quests on different islands. Maybe I am doing something wrong. I should start doing them in order, but it is so much fun exploring.

If you are looking for a game with exploring and I mean really exploring, this game is for you.  There are things to pick up everywhere. Jump on roofs, find niches in rocks, rooms, behind buildings, laying around on the beach and you will pick up something.

You  have an unlimited storage with no weight restrictions. This can be a little overwhelming at times as you really don't know what to sell or keep.

Overall, I highly recommend this game.  Wait for it to go on sale and buy it!

I forgot one important feature.  You can save anywhere at anytime.
Thanks all

reviewText: This game is alright at best..... I'm a hardcore fan of RPG's and enjoy a game that challenges... however sadly after reading other reviews saying that this game just reqires tactics" and "doging" are just hogwash this game is extremely mediocre and lack though passion a sense of caring and depth. I say this game will hold your interest for about 30 hours. But those 30 hours are rarely memorable and fun. Most of this game is a grind and the combat is messy and repetitive. HOWEVER the most major gripe I have with this game is the "boss fights" they honestly feel like my 5 year old cousin has made them. They are unfun grinds that pit you againts an infinite amount of spawning minions of the boss and the boss itself is heaing constantly
date: so you fight off 5 of the minions that dont matter because they give you no XP and never go away and then you return to the boss to find it have full health and maximum power after trying to kill if for 30 minutes. It was stupid game design and poor production values resulting in a failed franchise that makes the player angry rather than reward hard work and time. PLEASE PLEASE VOTE WITH YOUR WALLET AND STAY AWAY FROM THIS ENTRY OF RISEN! Go play the First one for a much better game if you have money to spend on something not this. And if you HAVE toplay this game do yourself a service and pay no more than 8$ for it.\n"

reviewText:
First of all i have played and enjoyed risen 1, and played about 20mins of the demo for risen 2 (hated it, just couldnt get into it,) but risen 3 on the other hand is amazing. I highly reccommend this game to anyone who enjoys rpg's or open world games. I pre ordered this game because it looked quite promising and it highly exceeded my expectations.

There are tons of areas to explore. The game is broken up into islands, all which have a good variety of enviornments, enemies, people, ect. There are different factions which you choose to join in the game and each gives you a unique playstyle, and quests so there is need for replayability. The game is filled with tons of quests, and many which are quite enjoyable, not the typical oh go here and collect 10 tree roots and get a reward kind of quests. There is tons of dialoge in this game and the voice acting isnt perfect but its quite acceptable in my opinion, they throw in humor sometimes too which is great. This game has a really good atmosphere to it, someting which i enjoyed about risen 1. Soundtrack in this game is also superb.

A neat twist to this game as well, you use a ship to travel from island to island, and sometimes there are random encounters and you'll have to fight off enemy ships or sea monsters. The combat in the game is a little clunky, but it just took some time getting used to. Once you build your strength abit it becomes much more enjoyable, its just a little tough in the beginning.

I usually dont take the time to write reviews, but i am enjoying this game very much, and since its an rpg theyre automatically competing with the big companies that make skyrim, dragon age, ect. So im happy to voice my opinion of the game for others to see and hopefully they will give it a try.
voteText: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Its a good game for somebody who is in between a casual player and hard-core player, and has not a lot of time, but still wants a game that you could finish in more than one sitting.

As a first timer in the series, I did enjoy how stress free the quests are. Unlike other games, eg Skyrim, Fall-out, etc., I do not to have an extensive reasearch to just finish a quest in my liking. Other than that, many areas of the game could be imporved.

If you want to play this game, either wait for a sale, like 40% and above, to buy it. Didn't bought the game in steam, and didn't pay the total of $62 to get the game and its dlc. So its a good game, not in par with the ones that I have stated above, but still a good one.

reviewText:
I cannot recommend this game altough I enjoyed it. Let's start with what was good.

+ Graphics - It's quite beautiful to be honest. Althugh it's too vibrant and saturated.
+ Music - I cannot imagine wandering in a world of Risen without that smooth guitar tones.
+ Bones - His quotes are really hilarious.
+ Quests - This part is the main reason, why PB games (Gothic, Risen) are soo good. Quests are pleasant and noninvasive.
+ Astral Vision - it's great idea, but on the other hand it makes exploration much easier.

That's not much. Unfortunately, there's way more things, which went bad.

- It's basically Risen 2 with factions. Even the locations are a little similar. In PB games, armor was always rare but in one DLC you got better armor from start than you got by joining faction. Also - free maps, phew...
- Atmosphere - This is what hurts me the most. Risen 3 has good music and graphic so why it's not immersive? For me it's due to extremly dull and boring cities. I still have Khorinis (Gothic 2) or Harbor City (Risen) in my memories. Despite of beautiful graphic it actually harms atmosphere. Nights aren't dark enough and as I said it's oversaturated. Back in Risen I remember a night in the Bandit Camp with a torch in my hand and fear in my heart while slowly sneaking through nearby swamps. In Risen 3 I lighted up a torch just in order to take a good screenshot...
- Companions - They're extremly boring and shallow without any character development. Not to mention Patty who looks like a ♥♥♥♥ with too much makeup. Polly and Bones are the only exception.
- Difficulty - First playtrough, ultra difficulty, zero challenge. I sweeped all avalibe islands even before I joined a faction.  Shadowlord was surprisingly easy, just let companion to tank it. When I finally joined faction (Guardians) I expected to be even more powerfull. But when I found my attacks were AoE I prayed for quick end. I basically didn't need to improve my character at al, altought I still did.
- Story - They took a good story of first Risen, transformed it into medicore Risen 2 story, and dumpstered it in Risen 3. This is the last Risen according to PB and obviously they don't give a single ♥♥♥♥ about their original backstory which was good. Also, people like Patty, so let's make our main protagonist as her brother in order to not deal with a lovestory. There were two, maybe three good moments but they really should hire someone from Bioware.

reviewText: I feel like they aimed to make a worse game every time they made a Risen game.  Risen 1 was very good and wasn't fantastic but it wasn't garbage.  Risen 2 was really trashy but kept my attention and I was able to get through it and enjoy the story.  But this game.  Oh my god I have never had a worse combat experience ever.  Game says you can chain 3 hits.  No you can not at all.  2 hits fairly easily but the 3rd will always be interupted by an enemy attack and even power attacking enemy block will just cause them to hit you first or roll away instead.  Combat ends up being this really slow boring grind of slash roll slash roll.  Theres no real strat as you get frames when you roll even if the attack hits you.  It feels like it tried to be a budget darksouls combat system and ended up just being trash.  Story is meh.  Not much to say but pirates and feels like a recycled plot from the second game but much more watered down.  Only play if your fan of the games already otherwise the completely garbage combat system will upset you.

reviewText:
EDIT:

I've made a review before finishing the game, and now I'm going to review again.

This game isn't the best RPG I ever played, but I garantee you, it'll be one of the most funny and enjoyable since Skyrim.

+ Good story, but with some clichés
+ Great improvement in voice acting (still, the main character's is aweful) comparing to the previous games in the series
+Despite the game's engine being old, the shadow and lightning effect is one of the best out there, providing beautiful and colorful scenarios
+ Cool artwork
+ Most of the quests are original and they don't repeat a lot.
+ Tons of secret treasures and chambers to be discovered
+ It give's you that Gothic series feeling, which is really nice
+ Combat system is captivating...

-... if you get through the first hours frustration
- Soundtrack is just decent, it could be much better
- Face expressions are pratically nonexistent
- There could be more to loot in the maps
- The ship battles are cool, but it gets old real quick
- Some missions are just tedious
- Some bugs here and there
- IA is mediocre, companions get lost frequently and after some hours in the game, the enemies are just dead meat
-Dialogues are too lengthy
- If you played Risen 2, you'll recognize most of the scenarios, since they are basically the same

Final: If you can get through the frustration of the first hours, you will discover a magnificent and original RPG, that gives a perfect balance between a pirates and a common RPG theme. There's a discover here, the scenarios are incredibly rich, there's secrets everywhere, and the story is compelling. Of course, you can see that the budget wasn't very high: The combat system suffered great improvements, but it lacks some adjustments; the voice acting could be a lot better; the game engine is recycled (still, huge improvements!), some bugs are just really annoying. But still, this game is a must have in every RPG-lover collection. Specially the Gothic fans. Seriously, it's the first time in a decade that a game gives me a Gothic game feeling.

Final Score: 8/10

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I'm coming at this review from an action-rpg perspective, such as The Witcher III, Skyrim and Kingdoms of Amalur.

I've heard people say they like this game and even some people have defended the game's combat, but I can't seem to understand them when there are a plethora of games that have better-feeling combat systems. This review will be a breakdown of the combat system in this game. Bear in mind, I am playing the Witcher III, and yes I am comparing this to a game like that because I need a benchmark for what a good battle system feels like. Because that's the thing I'm not hearing often enough about this game... that the combat system may be likable but it feels far off the mark.

So, what I dislike out of the gate is the fact I have to unlearn all the best systems in the past. There are no real parry moves, blocking or dodging of any kind. Sure you can roll, but it's really hampered. In other games like Amalur and Witcher III, a roll is a dodge that puts you in a better position to combo. In this game it's more of a get-out-of-the-way move that ends up being a chore for how often you do it, and you can never align it correctly. Sure you can roll out to a better position for comboing and sure if you've gotten used to this system, you may even say it's just as good, but you have to realize you are getting used to a floaty and unrealistic fighting system. I'm just now getting the hang of it and I'm fighting the opponents in different ways than I prefer. It feels really cheap oftentimes to attack in certain ways in this game. The Witcher III seems to have a graceful sliding system with the dodge mechanic that can be used to great effect if timed correctly. But I find the timing in this game to be rather hard to figure out.

The next gripe I have is with the attacks. They feel very floaty and I cannot feel for where the tip of the sword is, this small concept is proving to be a huge nuisance. Games like Skyrim or The Witcher III have very decent positional relation with the blade. I can tell easily if an opponent is within range. Even more off putting, the character ice-skates to his opponent in the game, which is harder yet to control. Also I've noticed that while in mid ice-skate" the enemy can still attack you from the front. Which is odd since I'm coming right at it. Games like Amalur which does have a kind of skating system
date: at least feel satisfying for connecting with the opponent in rewarding ways.\n\nThe attacks also seem slow and the combos don't stack. If I hit the attack button and quickly move to 'parry' or block
recommended: it seems to cancel the move which is not what I'm used to. I was half hoping the attack continues and the character moves into a parry stance
hoursPlayed: much like other games with really nice animation. This subtly makes the fighting feel unnuanced and robotic.\n\nThere are patterns to most enemies you encounter
voteText: but they don't have a rhyme or reason. It's quite random how you handle even the most basic encounters. Rolling and attacking
helpfulPercent: waiting for them to do two attacks so you can get them with one attack. Waiting for them to charge an attack
votesHelpful: etc. It also doesn't help that your attacks at first don't seem to deal much damage. Basic encounters can be long winded if you focus too much on blocking and rolling and not dealing enough damage.\n\nGroups are hard to manage. The best solution is to attack randomly until they die off evenly
votesTotal: or getting lucky enough to isolate one of them. But in other games there are usually ways to cope with groups. In the Witcher for example
votesFunny: the character can parry and attack and dodge enemies coming in from the sides or behind and what's better is you can do that by timing it in that game. In this game
commentsCount: the character is acrobatically feable
column16: which makes it rather hard to do any impressive sword swashbuckling. If it isn't one of two states you can be in
column17: you'tre screwed. Even Assassins Creed games get this right. It also helps if enemies all don't attack at once but circle you until they are ready to leap. I know you might think that system is cheap
column18: but it certainly goes a long ways in creating a believable action game where the hero has to fight multiple enemies. But it mainly comes down to flank-parry recognization: The idea you can turn an opponents attack around when they arrive from the side.\n\nFinally

reviewText:
The best looking game in the series but the laziest and weakest overall.

Except for the visuals there really isn't anything that's improved since Risen 2 and much has gotten worse.

The Good:

I like the visuals, the enhanced edition really looks good.  The models, the colors, and the overall look and feel of the environments are well done.  There are are few small anomalies here and there but nothing horrible or overly distracting.  Weather effects could be a bit better, but it doens't really take away anything.

I like the magic.  While I haven't used all the systems if the others are similay to the way voodoo works then that's pretty good.  While magic isn't a very in depth process it's interesting and diverse enough to be fun to use.

I have always liked the quest system, where you can complete the goals of a quest even before you get assigned the quest.  So if you kill all the creatures in some corner and then come across a guy who gives you the quest to go kill the creatures in that corner, you can complete it right then and there.

Some minor (and major) rewards for exploring.  I like being able to look up at some rocks and ask What's up there?" and much of the time I am able to clime up there and find something there; a dead body
recommended:
or whatever.  Very rarely have I been disappointed from randomly exploring the areas.



The Bad

So mcuh of in this game is left over from the previous games.  Very little is completely new.  You'll interact with just about everyone you met before in the previous games
hoursPlayed: many of these meetings are forced and add absolutely noting to the plot. Especially the ones you meet in your very short stints into the underworld which are forced upon you at various times when you go to sleep.  Boring and a complete waste of time.\n\nCombat still sucks ♥♥♥.  You pretty much have the same moves you did in Risen 2 and most of the enemies still use the same tired old attack routines.  Save for a couple of the newer mini bosses and bosses every creature uses the same attack pattern that existed in previous game.  It truly boggles my mind that an alligator has teh exact same attack pattern as the wild beaked birds. Combat adds almost nothing new in installment.  Even my voodoo combat is the same as my melee combat save that it will hit multiple creatures rather than just one.  Not to mention even on hard this game is easy save for the random times the AI just goes ballistic and starts throwing up a stream of attacks there is no way you can defend against.  Also
voteText: some monsters
helpfulPercent: despite how powerful your armor is
votesHelpful: will kill in one hit if you fail to dodge.  Combat is an annoying chore instead of a fun activity.\n\nAuto saves:  Autosaves are nice
votesTotal: but they are very strangely activated.  Most are okay
votesFunny: but there are times where they should be used when they're not.  An autosave should activate right a fast travel and tehy aren't.  If you forget to save after a fast trave to your ship and then travel to another island and then get killed by something on the beach
commentsCount: when you reload you'll be way back on that other island.  Also
column16: I have encounterd puzzles where once you solve them you get ambushed and if you don't save and get killed you have to solve the puzzle again.  One took me 10 minutes to solve and I got ambushed
column17: die almost instantly
column18:
and had to redo the god damn puzzle.  That's a horrible flaw.  Autosave on complete puzzles is a must.

Vague quest resolution:  A few quests are completely vague in how they are supposed to be resolved.  One in particular I have done every single quest on the isle of mages and all I get is "I still have soem things to do before we can start" with absolutely no clue what I need to do or am waiting for.

Companions:  Kinda hand for combat
column19: though they're really slow to start fighting (I can fimish most foes before the companion even makes one attack) they are almost always in your way when you wanna loot the corpses.  You have to specifically make sure the corpse is highlighted because you companion will usually be right here in your face when trying to loot.  This is annoying as hell.\n\nThe underworld:  Often times when you sleep you're whisked away into a stint in the underworld which serves one of two purposes. column20:
but they always end abruptly as you collect one or two and then a creature appears and kicks you out of the underworld.

The Ugly

The main character is a complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  This guy is absolute o fun to play unless you want to be an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.  Even if you follow the "good" path everything that comes out of this guys mouth is pure garbage.  Even when you select the nice dialoge option the character sounds like he's ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off that he even has to talk to someone else.  He has set a new standard for me as most unlikable video game protagonist ever.


This game is a disjointed mess.  All of its parts do not equal up to its whole.  Most of its parts are average at best

reviewText:
Athough in the beginning I did not like that game very much, now, that I have played it for several dozens of hours, I must say it is a very good game.
Perhaps the characters do not look as well and as technologically-advanced as one could expect of a next-gen game (at least I personally hoped Risen would feature next-gen facial features' mapping etc.), but the foliage, the landscapes, creates - everything looks very, very good.

And the most important thing is that when you actually begin playing the game, gaining experience, mastering new skills, you suddently cannot leave the game for a minute. I personnaly just had to complete each and every island, do all the quests possible, find all secrets and more - and believe you me, if you want to do everything there is to do in this game, you are going to spend at least 60-80 hours doing so, and if you're not in a hurry - 100hrs in the game is achieveable.

I honestly recommend this game to all those, who loved Gothic 1&2 (and 3 too, why not:)) - this game, in my humble opinion, is worth the money spent on it.

And since there are many and many titles, that cost as much, and cannot get the player involved for more than half of the time, I have already spent in Risen 3, I would rate this game at 80-85/100. A very nice title and I really recommend it as a nice Gothic experience.

reviewText: Not a bad game. I'm only 21 hours in and i still have allot to do. So its not a 8-20 hour game. Learning Magic takes a bit of time, as you have to get to the Mage island and do the subquests so you can be a Guardian/Mage. But i have had allot of fun with the game. Was it worth 40 bills? I think its not bad for the price. Over all the game is really immersive and fun to play, the melee side of the game isn't bad but, once i got spells the game became more enjoyable. The crafting was interesting, as well as the health potions were booze. So i thought that was kind of comical. Overall give it two thumbs up. I had so many quests i was busy. Very well done game. Also the game does not support wide screen monitors. But there is a work around in the forums, so not bad.

reviewText:
Having put a lot of time and effort into the first two titles (and the Gothic trilogy, of course), I figured I'd review this final title.

The ability to sprint is a welcome improvement from the sluggish movement in the first two titles, with the second game's fast-travel making it more bearable than the first game.

I don't think the music keeps in line very well with the themes of the earlier games (risen 2 all the way back to the first Gothic title), though it has its moments. I found the interface clunkier than the second game's, which is very unfortunate.

The main character's (English) voice is terrible; I really wish this horrible voice was allotted to a minor character that dies off very early in the game rather than the one person you have to endure through its entirety. While the voices on the other characters are nice enough, with some, like Bones', improving a bit in my opinion, I find the characters less interesting than in the earlier games.

I thought the combat in Risen was too plain, I thought the combat in Risen 2 was *excellent*, and I think the combat in Risen 3 is...not very good, though not necessarily a step backward. I was hesitant to try Risen 2 after my pleasant experiences with the Gothic titles and the first Risen, but after getting it on sale I was extremely impressed and thought it kept the spirit of the earlier games alive. As a consequence, I approached Risen 3 with very high expectations, none of which were really met. I don't think anyone stands to *lose* from trying it, but I can't recommend it.

reviewText:
If you are looking for an action packed, gore-filled game...then look elsewhere. Piranha Bytes' games have never been about mindless slaughter, but rather deep and careful exploration of the rich environment, carefully crafted quests, interesting characters and total immersion. Risen 2 may have strayed away a bit from some of these factors, but I can confidently say that Risen 3 has certainly improved greatly over it, and the feeling and atmosphere of the game is much more reminiscent of the original Gothic games and the first Risen.

One of the biggest complaints of the previous game in the Risen series was the combat system. This time, however, not only is the magic system back, adding greater variety, but melee combat feels much more satisfying, and it's certainly NOT a left click fest - if you want to defeat a strong enemy, you must dodge, block, riposte and time your hits.

Risen 3: Titan Lords is a game for all the players who loved Piranha Bytes' classical works. Perhaps the plot isn't up to par with Gothic 1's, but nevertheless, as the final game in the series, it has certainly lived up to its promise to go back to the roots - the more observant fans will even notice some very pleasant surprises involving familiar characters from times gone by.

reviewText: Okey, so i've played for 24 hours and I have to say, the game is dammned good. With a few skills and more importantly magic, the combat does not feel half as bad, depending on the faction there are several nice combos to do with magic. i'm loving the demon hunters. Graphics look awsoome, especially distant structures and lightning. Shadows look awsome and very realistic. Story is as great as you can expect from such a developer, leveling is fairly balanced and not too hard. I mostly love the fact that you get magic with every faction, unlike prequals where you had to choose a specific one for it, while every faction still has it's own magic to make a difference between them. I also like how there are faction specific skills. Humor is grately present witch also gives the game even more charm. So in conclusion for anyone that likes a good story, rpg-s, adventures or open world games this is a must have. Great game.

reviewText:
PB came into this title promising that they'd returned to their roots and had learned from their past mistakes, but have they? Yes and no.

The bad:

-The story drags a bit in the middle. They do things to improve this and try to keep it interesting, but it's easy to do things in an order which can feel like a slog and not a fun progression of events.

-Companions are tanks. This isn't as much of a problem on the hardest difficulty, but on medium it feels like they are more powerful than you for far too long and are neigh unkillable. If you're spending glory on skills you don't have until you join a faction, like magic or voodoo, this is especially true.

-Voice acting is hit-and-miss. Sometimes your main character can sound like a badass that you'd never want to mess with, other times he has a mouth full of gravel for no reason. Also, there are too many times where you'll hear that the voice actors didn't have good direction and say lines with the wrong inflection.

-Combat can be clunky. I actually put this in both the good and the bad because they improved some aspects, but from friends I know who've played the game on a console the controls can be a pain without a mouse and keyboard. This is where you'll really feel the companions are tanks"
date: because you can often just roll circles around enemies while your friend rips them apart. Seeing enemies get stuck behind a fence or rock and glitch out during can also break immersion.\n\n-Day one DLC. This is more a knock on the publisher and not the developer
recommended:
but for ♥♥♥♥ sake stop making Devs do this ♥♥♥♥. It only hurts the customer.

The neutral:

-Reused areas. I put this in neutral because PB has done this before to great affect
hoursPlayed: like in Gothic II. Seeing how areas change over time is fun and they are disimillar enough that I didn't feel it detracted from my experience
voteText: but it annoys enough people that it can be a negative.\n\n-Ship combat under utilized. This was one of the most fun parts of the game
helpfulPercent:
but like Assassin's creed 3 it just leaves you wanting more.

The Good:

-Magic system is a blast. Anyone who played Risen 2 can tell you that the voodoo magic left a lot to be desired with a few cool tricks but damage spells that came much too late. Now you have three different schools of magic to play with (rune
votesHelpful: crystal
votesTotal: and voodoo) all with fun and unique spells. Instead of a mana pool that gives out over time you have different elements that you can wield like weapons at melee and range supplemented by timed spells with effects like fire rain or summoning. Enemies also have vulnerabilities to elements that you can discover with experimentation.\n\n-Exploration. This has always been a strongpoint of PB games and this iteration is no different. A bevy of secret caves
votesFunny: islands
commentsCount: and treasure to find will keep you wanting to see what is around every corner for hours if you're anything like me.\n\n-Arcane Vision. For anyone who likes collecting every ounce of junk as a metagame this upgradable ability highlights objects so you don't have to worry about missing anything and squinting at every corner. It reminds me of the wisp ability from Gothic II
column16: but much more efficient.\n\n-Huge number of interesting quests. Many may knock this game for having quite a few 'fetch' quests
column17:
but it's what you can do within these quests that lets them shine and wash away any tedium. Asked to hand out some crystals to your compatriates? Scam them instead and make them pay for the privelage.

Conclusion:

It's a solid 7/10 RPG

reviewText: The game has its ups and downs but over all it isa fun game. There is lots to do and it does not really hold your hand and explain things for crafting and that sort to you or maybe I just have not found the npc yet. First chest I had to pick it said something to the affect of dont hit the wrong tumbler or you have to start over... I spent way longer than I should trying to figure out what the ♥♥♥♥ I needed to do for the minigame. I then cleared my first real island of all the plants and mobs, wonder wtf do I do with all this stuff? I just wanna make a bottle of rum! Or how the ♥♥♥♥ do I sneak? When I lost my soul did I magically forget how to crouch and move slowly? I like that the game doesn't tell me everything I need to know, I rather figure that out on my own. The combat is probably my only real complaint and it is mainly you can't roll off things in combat. I have been on a rock many times about 1 inch off the ground and I go to dodge an enemy and stopped by an invisible wall. Would I rather it be like Elder Scroll where I can really steal anything that isn't nailed down and have hidden caves with bad guys in it for me to kill? Of course I would. Would I rather have the combat more hardcore as in DS? YES! But the game isn't from those devs and it is what it is so I have to ask myself do you have fun? are you even a little be curious to see what happens at the end? I do so I think the game is a success. I read some people saying the game isnt worth 50$ more like 30$ and I almost agree. The graphics, clunky combat is totes a 30$ game but the game has so many quests, places to explore, and frankly I have played to close to 33hrs and I still have 3 more islands and havent picked a faction... and the game seems like i havent even come to the climax of the game yet... I think it is worth the other 20$ for that alone.

reviewText:
I really, really wanted to write a positive review about this game. I've really enjoyed games by Piranha Bytes in the past, and Risen 1 was actually a really enjoyable game. I started but didn't finish Risen 2, because I stopped enjoying it. I was hoping that Risen 3 would have learned from the mistakes of Risen 2, and been better. I was wrong. Risen 3 is worse than Risen 2, and by a large margin.

Risen 3 has some good things. The world is lush and pretty. The theme, pirates and magic, can be a lot of fun. Okay, two good things.

It also has a lot of things that are not good, and in some cases very bad. The physical mechanics of the game are crap, frankly. You walk like you're on a flat plane that skates across the ground. There are invisi-walls all over the place. More specifically the fighting mechanics, are even worse. All the things that Assassin's Creed IV got right about fighting, such as the pace, the fluidity, and the using of different weapons, are all things that this game gets horribly, horribly wrong. You click to attack, and then there's a pause, and then there is a slow attack. There is no such thing as a fast attack. The enemies, however, do have a fast attack; and it interupts. Meaning there you are, slowly pulling your sword back for an attack, and 'whack' you get hit and have to restart the attack. I could continue on this subject, but there are so many other things wrong that I'm moving on.

This is supposed to be an open world style game. It is one, in a sense. You have the open world of the path, and the few trees on either side. But wait! What's that toward the end of a path? It's a temple complex! So you enter the temple complex, and then you have the open world of the corridor! Don't get me wrong, the world is open to you going back and forth within the path or corridor. I admit that I've only played the first area, so maybe the world becomes more open later on.

Let's talk about pop-in. Usually, pop-in is a draw distance issue where textures go from either blurry or just not there, to suddenly clear and apparant. In some horror games however, they used the sudden appearance of enemies as a scare tactic. As in, you would be walking along and suddenly BOO! an enemy jumps out at you. In this game you're walking along and enemies will suddenly pop up from the ground. It's not a slow, un-burying of an enemy. It's a quick 'look I can phase through solid matter' jump up. Not only that, but they can go from appearance to attacking instantly. Considering the time it takes for you to be able to attack, even if your reaction time is amazing, you're going to get hit multiple times before being able to land a blow. Also, this game is set on islands. Islands with rivers running across them. There is a lot of water. There are enemies that do the pop-up effect while under the water. The further problem here, is that a lot of the water has a 'foam' effect, making it opaque. That renders these popped-in enemies invisable. So then you get to fight invisiable fast-attacking enemies. I cannot, in any way, describe this as 'fun'.

There are more things wrong with this game, but honestly I think this review is long enough. So to sum-up: This game is filled with poor mechanics, has a terrible story line (sorry I didn't write a paragraph about this part), has poor voice acting and scripting (or this part), but occasionally looks pretty. On a scale of 1 to 10 I would give this game a 3. [3/10]

reviewText:
This game feels like it was originally a DLC for Risen#2 in which you play as Patty's brother that ended up getting turned into a full game.  The map is almost identical to Risen#2, gameplay mechanics, very similar.  Graphics, again, no major evolution.

The worst thing about this game though, is the horrendous decision, to move away from the nameless here we played in Risen#1 and Risen#2 and introduce a completely new protagonist, Patty's brother.  WTF ?  Whoever smart guy at game studio made that decision aught to be taken out the back and flogged.  Long-term fans of the franchise like me were looking forward to Patty and the Nameless hero finally getting together in Risen#3.  Totally unfinished plot arc from the first 2 games.

Now, to be clear I loved the Risen franchise, up until #3.  I have recommended the original Risen, and also Risen#2 multiple times.  How could the devs be so dumb as to completely change up the protagonist we came to know and love in the first 2 games ?  Not only that, the world is almost the same as that of Risen#2 with the addition of a couple of scorch marks and some fog.

I totally cannot recommend this game.  I am bored with it now, I already played Risen#2 and I dont want to play Risen#2.5 which is what this game really aught to have been called.  Game uninstalled, and not completed.

So, the major gripes about Risen#3 :

- Same maps as Risen#2, just with some minor changes
- Different protagonist from the one we spent 60+ hours with if we played the first 2 games
- Game feels cheap and definitely not as well done as first 2 games

So basically IMHO Risen#3 is a cheap piece of crap and a money-making scheme on the Risen name from the developers.  Avoid.

reviewText:
I purchased, installed and attempted to play Risen 3 - Titan Lords today.

Playing a game is as far as I'm concerned a way to enjoy yourself. Just finished four hours playing Risen 3, and it was not fun. The graphics are nice, and the audio is fine. My source of irritation was with the 'combat' system. My apologies for the single quotes, but that was what it felt like.

First my gaming background. I've played (and enjoyed) Morrowind, Oblivion, Skyrim, Kingdoms of Amalur, Fallout:New Vegas, Dishonored, Fable: The Lost Chapters, The Witcher. All on PC.  Each with a slightly varying combat system, showing that I can adjust to different systems.

Please remember that I'm giving my experience with the game; these are not criticisms, just reasons why someone who thinks and plays like myself may want to give this game a pass.

My expectation in playing any game where combat is involved is that the combat is straightforward. That is, the laws of physics apply (I press 'Hit', my character attempts to swing), not the laws of combos (you can only swing at the right time as decided by the game).  And this is my reason for writing this review: Risen 3's combat system is not straightforward as far as I can tell.

Here are the things I observed:
- in a number of instances (during combat) when I click the left mouse button to attack, my character just stands there.
- during combat, my character decides to sheath his sword (I believe I can say with confidence that I did not click the middle mouse button by mistake when this occurred).
- more that 50% of the time, a standard attack from any creature resulted in my character taking damage, even while parrying/blocking.
- my character would strike a creature, then perform a 180 degree pivot and strike the person behind me. I only clicked the left mouse button once. Force of habit with games like Kingdom of Amalur meant my left hand was firmly pressing the 'W' key to keep moving forward ... didn't work apparently.
- the creatures at level 1 are incredibly fast. I like a challenge, but the lapse in response time by my character just meant many cycles of: Kill a creature, save, get killed. restore, kill another creature, save, get killed ... you get the idea.
- in most of the games I mentioned above, there was always 'wiggle' room; you could choose which encounters you wanted, when you were prepared for them. In Risen 3, encounters are about every 50 feet, no getting around them. This would seem that the developers were more focused on combat than anything else. In the one quest where I was escorting Balbor, there were a minimum of 15 different creatures all within a 150 foot radius. (the distace is a guess, it's just to show it felt close) And when attempting to follow him away from the water source, you had no choice (not even sneaking worked, even though it is an available skill) but to engage the animals. I partially blame Balbor, as he went out of his way to 'pull' them towards me.

Altogether not enjoyable. I've read a few comments by some folks in the community here, and some have expressed the thought that this would be solved by 'training harder'. I believe that can be interpreted to mean 'learn how the combat system works and you'll be fine'. My response would be 'but I have'. I know how to attack by pressing the left mouse button. I know how to parry/block by pressing the right mouse button. However, the actions I see on the screen are not consistent with what I want my character to do.

Let me explain myself a bit, using Skyrim as an example (it's still one of my favorite games). If I meet an NPC whose skill level with his chosen weapon is higher than my skill level with my chosen weapon, it's quite likely I'll lose the battle. But I'll lose it because the NPC is better skilled than I am. I can still swing a sword at him, it just won't do as much damage due to my lower skill level. I can still fight and block, until he gets the better of me and overwhelms me. I don't mind losing to a superior foe, as long as I put up a good fight.

But when ALL of the creatures are superior foes, and my character is effectively incapacitated during combat, it's no longer a challenge, it's a chore. And perhaps some might think me lazy, but the 'click the attack button, wait two seconds then click it again, wait three seconds and then press the Ctrl key as you click the attack button again  to perform the Super/Ultra combo' formula doesn't mean that you've mastered the game as I see it. It means it's mastered you.

I read the description of the game, and viewed all of the videos available on Steam for Risen 3, spending a few days to think about purchasing it. I gave it a chance because it seemed like the character interactions would be interesting and I thought it was along the lines of other RPG games I enjoyed in the past. Except for the combat, unfortunately a crucial part of the game, it was. It would have been a great game to play otherwise.

reviewText:
Risen 3 - Titan Lords
You either love it or you hate it.
If you enjoyed the previous titles you will like this game - a lot.
If you did not enjoy them you will not enjoy this game either.

The advertisments in form of the the game trailers are kind of misleading.
There you are basically promised that you get a  Gothic " experience.
Instead you get a Risen 2 with slight improvements.



GRAPHICS

The graphics are solid but unimpressive
date: they look outdated but still fit the game in a strange way.\nThe game will probably run on less powerful machines as smooth as on high end rigs.\nSome animations look incredibly clunky and wooden ( like drawing your weapon )
recommended:
others look organic and fluent ( agitated animals ).


SOUND

The Music of the game is beautiful and immersive
hoursPlayed:
it has both a pirate and fantasy vibe.
The ambient sounds are well done as well and add to the immersion.
The Voice acting seems to be a matter of conflict to many people.
Personally I thought it was fine
voteText: the voice acting has the typical Gothic / Risen characteristics which I personally enjoyed.\nThe language is rude and direct most of the time
helpfulPercent: with its own kind of dark humor.\nLips of the characters are usually out of sync with what they are saying
votesHelpful:
but I just noticed that because I actively looked for it.


[b}COMBAT[/b]

Combat is a mixed bag.
At the beginning it is frustrating and feels unfair as well as clunky.
Every enemy you encounter appears to be able to attack twice or thrice as fast as you can
votesTotal: constantly interrupting your attacks.\nThis changes later
votesFunny: once you get a feel for the enemies attack patterns.\nThe majority of the enemies utilizes a combo of 3 attacks in a row. Which become quite predictable after a short while.\nThis is later mixed up with enemies that can block your attacks
commentsCount: instead of dodging it
column16: or throwing the occasional stone or fireball at you.\nLater in the game you are able to improve your combat skills significantly
column17: you will be able to learn to attack faster
column18: add more attacks to your combos
column19:
riposte and interrupt enemies attacks.

Combat feels harsh and unfair at first but quickly becomes menial as you progress in your skills.
This continues to the point where you are basically a demi-god
column20: an almost indestructible force of mayhem.\nSome people like it some hate it.\nI personally enjoyed it because it instills a feeling of gratification
column21: like you worked hard to get there and now you are able to enjoy the fruits of your labor.\n\nOne thing about combat however seems quite annoying

almost all types of enemies are able to knock you on your ♥♥♥.

COMBAT AT SEA

boots.
Depending on the faction youi will join you get access to 3 exclusive types of Armor.
As you progress in the ranks of your faction you will advance from light armor to medium to heavy.

Armors look good and characeristic for their faction.
You can also get some general pirate themed armor from vendors or as special rewards from quests.
These all look nice but are utterly inferior to your faction armor.
With the exception of something just labeled " Heavy Armor " that you can find on your adventures.
Which is slightly better than your tier 3 Faction armor.

If you own the Adventurer Garb DLC you get a set of armor that is slightly better than your first faction armor.
Which makes quite a bit of a difference at the start of the game.
The armor just looks kind of whacky.

There are various accessoirs to choose from
column35:
earrings and amulets.
Those basically boost your stats and allow you to specialize your skill sets.

Weapons
column36: there are plenty of weapons to be found.\nSwords
column38: sabres and fencing weapons.\nI personally could not see a big difference between the weapon types.\nYou get perks for each class
column39: and all seem to do the same amount of damage.\nThere are slight variations but they make no difference in actual combat.\nWether your weapon does 95
column41:
you still need at least 2-3 hits to kill an enemy in the end game.

So it just is a matter of taste.

There also is a Musket type of weapon
column42:
allowing you ranged combat.
If you choose to use this combat will change slightly but soon falls into the same patterns as meele combat.

Last but not least you are able to utilize dirty tricks
column43: which basically are secondary weapons.\nYou will be able to throw daggers
column44:
fire a pistol or crossbow in the heat of battle.

If you have enough ammunition this can change your combat style a bit.
However it is quite tedious to use in the beginning.
Without proper training your will miss a lot
column45: this has nothing to do with your personal skill however.\nIt is purely stat based
column46:
an enemy can stand point blank and you still will miss with your scatter pistol ( which is like a pumpgun in pistol form ).
There are only 2 components that matter : skill level with your desired dirty trick weapon and range.


CRAFTING

The game offers an extensive crafting system.
You can Craft new weapons
column47: repair broken legendary weapons which you can find in your adventures
column49: brew booze ( yay ) and alchemical tinktures.\nYou also can create your own spell-scrolls / rune stones.\nYou gather resources by picking them up ( herbs and so on )
column50: ripping them out of defeated enemies ( requires hunting perks )
column52:
or buying them at vendors.


OVERALL GAMEPLAY

The game plays smooth
column53: you can reach about everything you can see
column54:
there are few invisible walls that block you from reaching zones that you are not supposed to reach yet.

I only got stuck once in the environment but could rescue myself with the parrot spell.

Combat becomes boring fast
column55: since its very basic. The old Gothic Combat system is far superior.\n\nQuest / Quest logs are sometimes confusing
column56: leaving you wondering what to do next.\n\nThe game does not hold your hand much
column57:
which is nice.
You can get additional mini rewards by talking to people that had a part in a quest you completed
