reviewText: Don't be fooled by the overall positivity, this game in almost all of its aspects is atrocious.\n\nThe first and most standout aspect of this game should be the combat; fast paced, exciting, fluid, and interesting combat should be a staple for any game of this type to make up for the long sequences of talking and looting.  Unfortunetly, this game is none of that.  The combat is separated into light and heavy attacks that look no different from each other, (Don't even get me started on the hilariously terrible idea of heavy attack" in swordplay
date: but I'll spare you my historical rant).  Your light attacks feature a spinning flourish for every single attack except for one that leaves you completely open for counter attack from the VASTLY quicker and deadlier enemies that you face (even the pitifully tiny fish monsters at the start of the game).  Should you choose to string together attacks in a combo your strikes will become progressivly slower until the final strike where the enemy would sooner die from boredom while it waits for the attack. Dodgeing is neccissary but commically utilized
recommended: and the "parry" system is downright useless when compared to rolling around like an idiot with invincibility frames.  Secondary weapons are consumable and boring in excecution.\n\nBottom line for combat is that it's unintuitive
hoursPlayed: boring
voteText: and most importantly just not fun in any way.\n\nThen we have the story.  The plot takes after "video game trope A-4" in the fact that it does almost nothing new in its excecution.  Demon overloard was woken up from a nap and now he's cranky
helpfulPercent: as the player character only you can stop him because why not?  I will say that the distinction between reality and the spirit realm was entertaining for a momment before I realized it had no impact whatsoever on how I played the game.\n\nBottom line for plot is that it's only a background for tearing into new land for looting
votesHelpful: no real significance to how you play the game.\n\nSound track isn't noteworthy
votesTotal:
while it does serve as an adequate filler.

Animations are stiff and cringeworthy. Seems like they poured all of their budget into the spinny dance techniques the character employs in his swordplay.

The only reason I would ever have to want to play this game is the hear the protagonist swear at NPC's more.  It's actually really fun to  have a pirate as the protagonist because he has no obligation towards manners
votesFunny: which creates the  exceedingly rare vaguely pleasant momments in the game.\n\nFinal margin: the game is simply bad.  It's based around systems that are honestly not fun at all.  I bought this game when it was 75% off and only 8 or so Canadian Dollars
commentsCount: and I feel guilty for my idiocy.  I could have just bought a toy cutlass from the dollar store and had ten times the fun this sopping mess of a game gave me.  Please

reviewText: I think this is the worst game of the Risen trilogy. There is too much combat with the different monsters from the early beginning - the monsters are almost everywhere.  Also somehow it feels that the combat mechanism is much difficult to control than that of Risen and Risen 2 - parry doesn't seem to work as it should be in my mind. reviewText: Gothic was the first game I ever played on the computer growing up and I have followed this genre ever since.  Unfortunately I do not know if I will evr buy one of these games again.  I really like being able to fight mobs toe to toe and these games do not let you do that anymore.  All you will find yourself doing is letting you ally (thankfully you have one who follws youa round) beat stuff up for you while you roll in circles around your enemies.  Honestly it makes for very boring game play where you get to look at the fight while cartwheeling around and never actually get to take part.  The story is interesting and kind of fun to follow but the game play sucks.  So if you play games for story it isnt bad... If you play them for them for the whole experiance you should save your money for another RPG.\n\nI would like to note I had similar disappointments with Risen 2 and should have know better before I bought this.

reviewText:
This game is a gem and you wont find many others like it. It has so much heart and character. The world just feels so deliberately crafted. Everything in the game world is placed with a purpose. This design choice deviates from the random events and occurrences in modern games like Skyrim, but brings to the table a feeling that this world was crafted with care and attention to detail. This, among other things such as the loot, craftable materials, varied jungles, caves, beaches, fortresses and more make exploration a real treat! My favorite location is Calador, a volcanic island with a massive waterfront fortress and green bonfires dotting the coastline. It really is a sight to behold!

Ultimately, this game is all about getting lost in the vast world and forging your own destiny! It's about exploring and finding all of the secrets and content packed into the game! it's about side quests, and loot, and character progression, and choice! The choice to pick a direction, any direction, and be confident that there will be something new to discover right around the next corner. It's about all of these things... and while the game certainly isn't perfect, it's definitely a rare gem in a sea of mainstream rpgs that all try to do the same thing over and over.

In short, if you're a Gothic/Risen fan, you know what you're getting into, and this is some of PB's finest work. You may love it, you may hate it, but I urge anyone who's on the fence to give it a shot! I hope you can find as much enjoyment in this game as I have so far.

reviewText:
I'm a big fan of the Gothic series and saw this on sale so grabbed it
I haven't gotten that far but I am thoroughly disappointed and feel ripped off

tl;dr : it feels like a mediocre xbox action game
Movement is slow and choppy as hell. My fps is just fine but there is lag to the input and the movements are too large and clumsy to feel like anything but a clutz
Combat is ♥♥♥♥. Partly related to movement and partly mechanics and timing of the attack/combo/parry system. Input is laggy and actions take too much time to have any feeling of fun, it feels like i'm sending orders to a wooden puppet stuck in molasses. Movement and dodging is so slow you can't react to anything you just have to guess if maaaybe the guy is going to attack in 5 seconds so you have enough time to start the animation. The only viable technique seems to be standing around in parry until the enemy finishes their animation so you can start yours.
Maps are claustrophobic and feel fairly linear. Again, feels like an old mediocre xbox game that didn't have much memory to load bigger maps or display many polygons. You don't feel like you have much room to move around, and movement is so slow and clumsy it's a chore to run anywhere. The 'side' areas are just tiny branches with a few things on the ground to pick up off and then you are back on your one main path again.
Graphics aren't that great. I like the style but the graphics feel dated. I'm running with everything on the highest settings possible and it'd still get beat by games 5 years older than it. C'mon, my computer can handle a few more polygons or foliage that doesn't look like abstract art.
Bad ui/controls/ai - Controls are super simple.. again feels like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ console port. You pretty much just spam mouse clicks everywhere to do anything.. which includes picking up gold or talking to your annoying ai companion. Just from the start I've already gotten sick of trying to pick up gold or something and constantly going into the short 'talk' action with the companion. Her sass gets old reaaaal quick.
Horrible combat/non-combat modes - There are two basic modes.. combat where your controls are all for fighting, and non-combat for things like running around, interacting with the scene, looting and picking up stuff. And the animation to draw your weapon is laggy and slow as hell. What does this mean? You can either run around in non-combat mode so you can look for loot and stuff to interact with, and then when you get ambushed from nowhere on the tiny maps sit there getting ♥♥♥♥♥ until the monster gives you enough time to finish your draw weapon animation. OR, run around with your weapon drawn unable to loot anything. Awesome choices!


Pros: I don't really have any at the moment. I like the pirate/magic crossover. I haven't gotten far enough to experience many different skills so I'm really hoping those help provide a tiny bit of fun for the giant waste of money this has been so far.

reviewText:
I dont want to tell you a big story so here the pro and cons.


Pro:
- RPG With many options like you had in similar games from this developer.
- The Graphic Artist made a good job, the game looks good.


Cons
- Bad combat system, remember those boars in Gothic 3? I dont know how could they implement such monsters again. Enemy will jump in your back from a distance.
- Monsters everywhere! You cant even walk 3 meters without a fight, if you try to avoid it the enemy will simply rush you. yes they are faster and stronger than you.
-The difficulty is bad balanced. You can pick between easy medium and hard. Difference is just less enemy damage and less enemy hp. They will still charge you and knock you down, over and over again.
- The dialogs, it really feels like that the voice actors didnt do their job, but i actually know that many of them where in other games from this developer before. So i guess thats not their fault. My clue is that they simply didnt had have enough time to get into their roles.
- Inventory..... Didnt they learn enything? I mean come on.... One row, for all items. Scoll down scroll up.... Not even a search function.

Acutally all things that could be fixed. Game is fun at some points but the worst is the combat system.

reviewText:
Avoid this game.

Some people will claim I dont have sufficient time in the game to give it a negative review. But it does not take very long to know that the fundamental mechanics of a game are flawed beyond repair.

Voice acting is terrible. The first companion foisted on you is crass, annoying and being rid of her is a blessing. The second companion could not be a worse match for his voice actor if the developers had tried. Its really, really bad. And so is his acting.

The combat is...bad. I dont know why Block/Parry exists. Its useless against, well...everything. Literally, everything. A Chimp-sized monkey will break your block. On the first or second attack. Dodging is, well...time it right. Which is hard, since your character first has to throw his arms into the air theatrically in order to announce his dodge roll. And weapon strikes...I'm guessing the sword he is swinging weighs between 40 pounds and one metric ton, based on the speed with which he swings it.

Some people will claim has the 'usual quirks' of a Risen title. And this is true, if those quirks are poor production values, terrible voice actors, horrid combat, shoddy camera and game play that is nowhere near in alignment with the price they are charging for the game.

$50 wasted.

reviewText:
PB games are NOT for everyone, the stories won't blow you away, the graphics are usually not up to par with current tech, the camera usually sucks and animations are some of the worst you will come across. Yet there is alot I enjoy with the games PB has made (Gothic 1-3 and Risen 1-3). Risen 3 is here and in my opinion it is the best of the series, Magic is back, melee combat is improved (you still have to go to trainers and learn new moves, improvements,etc.. Some of the series long lasting issues rear there head such as what I mentioned above with the terrible animations and a story that could be alot better). Risen 3 won't win Game Of The Year awards and probably not many RPG of the year awards either with games like Divinity Original Sin, Wasteland, Dragon Age and Pillars of Eternity out or coming out this year, it does have a good amount of issues but for me the good outweighs the bad and overall is my favorite PB game since the wonderful Gothic 2.

The overall combat is a nice improvement from Risen 1/2, you have the option to put points into skills with glory points you have gotten (from doing missions and killing enemies) and also training with trainers in towns for new moves like Parry, Pickpocket,etc.. These improvements help big time for things like combat,etc... Hit a trainer up for Parry, Speed and what ever type of sword you use (Slash, Sword or another) and you will be kicking ♥♥♥ in no time. This game does not hold you're hand, it is a very nice challenge, although not quite as hard as Risen 2. Combat is not perfect though, there are still some issues but bringing Magic back and improving the Melee abit has gone a long way. Far from a flawless game but a nice step in the right direction for PB, hopefully they can improve even more in this department for the next game.

The start of the game is a bit slow and can also be very tough, especially for new players. You're character has not leveled up and doesn't have any moves really other than a normal and a heavy attack. Get past the first little bit and things start to pick up quickly. You have lots of trainers to pick from and also a bunch of factions to pick from so make sure to use them. These games don't hold you're hand and you will feel overwhelmed at the start, just make sure to visit trainers and save often and you should be good.

The graphics are improved from Risen 1 and Risen 2, but its still inconsistent. Some of the landscapes, character faces and colors look gorgeous, while other things like buildings up close and animations are laughable. Although for me I dont expect top of the line graphics or animations from PB games, they are much more than just fancy graphics or animations. Sure I would love a Risen game on a Witcher engine or something (speaking of witcher, the devs said they have taken inspiration from the old Gothic games also made by PB, for there upcoming open world game Witcher 3), but this is a smaller dev team and atleast for me animations and graphics are last on my list. Still there are some spots where I was in awe of some of the beauty in the game, come over a mountain at night with you're torch and you will witness a beautiful scene.

The leveling up is very good and you have many options with how you want you're character to go. Want to do some thief aspects? Put tons of points into the categories that support pickpocketing and locksmithy when you level up and also go to some trainers and improve that way to. Also depending on what faction you join you will have access to unique things and missions (I joined the mages, which I am liking alot, especially there island, looks like Risen 1/Gothic style.

The audio and music overall is pretty good, the soundtrack is very good that really kicks in when you are exploring these wonderful levels. The voice acting for the most part is good, it ranges from poor to fantastic, but most are good I will say. The game also has the usual PB humor which I love (Divinity Original Sin also had some good humor to), and the dialogue in general is well done (few cheesy parts but would it be a PB game without a little bit of comedy?).

One of my favorite aspects of PB games is the exploration and scavaging and Risen 3 does these with flying colors. Each island is different from the last and while some of them are frmo Risen 2, they look completely different, this is the game Risen 2 should have been imo. Also the characters are great and interesting once again, where ever I go in the game I always meet characters that I enjoy talking to, some are funny, some are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s and some are in the middle. In that sense the writing of the dialogue and characters is good but the writing of the story is not very good impressive.

It really comes down to what you think of PB games in general, yes it is an improvement over the first two games but it still has some of its long lasting issues that might throw some people off. But for me I am 30 hours in and having a blast, findng some new areas have me saying Just another hour Kozzy". Risen 3 has been fun as all get out so far
date: but I don't expect everyone to enjoy this game.\n\nThe level design is also very well made
recommended: each Island I want to explore EVERY INCH. This is something alot of open world rpg devs need to take note of from PB. Sure there is alot of things they can do better

reviewText: This game is absolute garbage in terms of balance, combat, and ease of play. And i don't mean it's hard for n00bs... I mean this game is neither fun, nor enjoyable, the combat is way too simple, way too rigid, has horrible animations, and trying to do any damage to any enemy is impossible when one attack takes 3 seconds to pull off and an enemy can counter in .05 seconds. Parrying is useless, combos are useless, and shooting enemies right in their face, can miss. You can't target an enemy, you can't lock the camera, enemies can circle around you faster than you can respond. They can stun lock you, and even PAST all this, the gameplay is boring and slow as hell. Absolute garbage. I will not keep this game, and i don't recommend you buy it at ANY price, let alone at full.

reviewText:
+

Various followers, with tons of dialog (their in-fight dialog is limited, but they all have different things to say when you're exlporing different parts of the world), and great voice acting.

Great graphic art style. NPCs as usual leave a little to be desired (repeated skins), but they have been getting better every game.

Lots of different areas to explore on each island. Think exploration in Risen 1 times ten.

Game length is pretty decent. First playthrough was about 35 hours, not including dlc.

Lots of quests ranging from simple fetch quests to posessing a Kila to convince various members into joining a war. Varied enough to keep it interesting.

Combat is flexible and allows a combination of melee/magic/ranged options.

Sea monsters and monkeys.

-

FIre/Ice/Shock glove felt kind of samey. I miss magic bullets.

Fleet/boat battles are pretty weak and last less time than the cutscenes setting them up.

Major boss battles are turned into a race against the enemies' regeneration.

ISN'T IT ABOUT TIME YOU INSPECTED YOUR CREW?

reviewText:
A great game, but be warned. Always be wary of what you put your attribute points in in these types of games. If you're hell bent on being the strongest sorcerer around, then you better wait and make sure that the points are being distributed in a way that makes that possible. If you played Risen 1 or any other games similar to these titles than you already know this.

Also, be sure when in melee combat to keep an eye on your enemy. Try to read their moves and don't just spam click. You'll just end up hurt very badly.

Great game and definitely worth trying out.

reviewText:
I understand some of the negative comments on here, Piranha Bytes games never have been for everyone. I personally wish that combat was back to the original Gothic 2/Risen mechanics where it is difficult but eventually very rewarding.
I love exploring the environments and finding a cave hidden behind the brush and having that sense of wonder and appreciating the open world. The world seems more alive to me than Skyrim for example.

I played the game using an Xbox controller for a while and that worked pretty well, every ability/feature is easily accessible once you figure things out.
Graphics are a little disappointing, especially compared to Risen 1 but are very serviceable.
Overall, a great open world experience with a lot of story content and different ways to build your character. I definitely had more of a Gothic 2/Risen 1 feeling with this one vs. Risen 2.

reviewText: I loved Riften 1, but hated Riften 2, alot.  I decided to give this game a shot, however.  From the start, this game hit me in the mouth with a useless tutorial and console tard feel.  This game is a Riften 2 clone, and even more so catered to XBOX.  The story continues the timeline of the previous game, and pretty much copies the combat and magic system of its predecessor.  Which are terrible in my opinion.  The graphics and stability are much improved over Riften 2, however.  Which is a huge bonus because Riften 2 ran like crap on my NVidia 750TI on low resolution and low graphic settings.  This game runs on medium graphics and 1080p with no problem on my rig.  Even with the improved graphics, I found myself looking at identical user interfaces, level up system, and item system of Riften 2.  This, like the second Riften, is a Pirates of the Carribean, mash buttons until enemies die, waste of time.

reviewText:
***Updated*** I was asked to be less vague about the combat issues.

Maybe worth $20-$30, graphics and animations are sub par. Not terrible, but nothing special to look at even on max settings.

Combat is clunky and boring, I'm one for diffuiculty, but this is just frustrating.

The game is unclear to areas you should be going too. Dailogue is so bad an uninteresting, they try to spice it up with curse words.


It's not about them holding my hand, I went to the begining island after the intro chapter. I fooled around with getting some new gear at the shop and upgrading some skills. Even with these upgrades I would be 2-3 shot by an enemy.

You get a light attack, a medium attack, a cheap shot (your pistol), a parry and a dodge.

Light attack- everything is faster than you, the chance of attacking and not getting hit at least a few times is slim. Wouldn't be a problem if I didn't die in a couple of hits.
(Yes there are potions, but excessive prices and the amount of damage you take eats up your money fairly quickly)

Heavy attack- needs to charge and is slow, 75% of the time the monster just jumps away from you and you miss.

Cheap Shot- This is kind of cool, but damage is weak and you only have a finite amount of ammo or throwing knifes.

Parry- this is useless most of the time, even an enemies light attack can break your guard and since most enemies double attack you get hit anyway. A parry is supposed to break the momentum of enemies opening them for an attack. This is a crappy block function at best.

Dodge- My least favorite mechanic, your recovery time almost always leads to you getting hit by a follow up attack or another enemy.

You end up just blocking and dodging waiting for your companion to kill things. I don't need to be the god of war, but I don't appreciate being a punching bag either.

The real draw back to the dialogue is the horrible animations, making it almost unbearable to sit through even a 30 second engagement.

I'm sure the game gets better, but almost 2 hours in and I can't even stand to look at it anymore. Reminds me of two worlds, if you remember what that was like I would steer clear of this title.

In short I would not recomend buying this until it goes on sale and only if you are an older style rpg fan, or you really enjoy the series.

reviewText:
The Death of Nostalgia
I think the nostalgia force might be a bit too strong with this one, young padiwan.

I myself am exempt from such forces - the first time I played Gothic 1 and 2 notr was Xmas 2011. Make no mistake, I get it. I get why they are such great games. Rewarding combat, memorable soundtrack, brilliant world design etc. but for me Gothic 3 Community Patched with Alternative AI and Balancing trumps the first two, and so does Risen 1.

Risen 1's combat is probably the best combat in any similar RPG. The fact that it is possible (though very difficult) to beat the hardest enemies and NPCs with just your starting hero and a wooden stick, is a testament to its greatness. Memorising the enemy's tendencies and combat behaviour is very rewarding, and does not make the game too tedious later on even, as I doubt people will always remember the AI patterns perfectly and perfectly counter them.

Dungeons, baby. Dungeons. Brilliantly designed, extremely rewarding dungeons. Of course not too challenging, but you were always under the illusion that you were doing something fairly clever when levitating across lava to morph into a snail to use telekinesis on a lever. The illusion of being a gaming genius and treasure hunter, tomb raider.

The voice acting is brilliant too - Lena Headey as Patty was sublime and I wanted to have sex with her animated body. I couldn't have been the only one.

Also, memorable music from none other than KaiRo seals the deal.

I could go on about Risen 1 and how underrated that game truly is, but alas we need to deal not only with the hits of Piranha Bytes, but also with the misses. In comes Risen 2.

...

What were they thinking? How...on earth could they have destroyed the combat so utterly. So profoundly. In the beginning there was no dodge either so to occassionally back away you resorted to this very awkward bunnyhopping. Eventually you realised how OP firearms were and just said ♥♥♥♥ it, let this game be over and done with. Moments of brilliance were seen with the rare use of Voodoo magic to complete some quests, and the beautiful world design. But the voiceacting was atrocious, in addition to the animations, music was forgettable and there were severe vegetation morphing issues (granted fixed by the community later on).

I was very very disappointed.

In comes Risen 3. Combat still not as good as Risen 1, or even indeed the older Gothics, but it is passable. Music is almost memorable. World design is PB at its finest yet again, with so many levels intricately, hand-designed, with loot sparingly thrown into nooks and crannies waiting to be discovered. But the point is that it is good *enough*, it scratches that Gothic itch. The combat, though a lot more forgiving, will still punish you if you are lulled into a false sense of security due to your stats and weapons and magic. The graphics are gorgeous, especially when tweaked, looks better than many dx11 games, though art design plays an important part in this.

What was my point? Enjoy Risen 3 for what it is - it is not Gothic 5, it is not the nameless hero (we know his name is Steelbeard after all), it is not surrounded by KaiRo's music, it is cross platform therefore dumbed down for console peasants, it is Piranha Bytes giving us the best they can whilst trying to earn a living (PC sales are usually a fraction of console sales), it is fun.

Oh, and remove those rosetinted nostalgia glasses once in a while and smell the coffee. It's time to move past decade old games.

reviewText:
The combat system is laughable, its honestly kind of amusing to watch my character slide 10 feet across the ground when I attack just because what I had targetted was that far away.  Combat in general is really clunky, and attacking is extremely slow.  The old combat system Risen 1, and the Gothic games had was significantly better (should give you an idea if you didn't even like those) - I can't imagine why it was changed to what it is.

The voice acting...wow, that's all I can say, its THAT bad.

This game might have been good about 5-6 years ago, but the standard that has been set by basically every RPG to come out since then makes it just look really bad.  Its like they just pushed it through because they needed the money or something, I know this company knows how to make quality games, but they've been on a downhill streak for a while now and this is the last game I will be buying from them unless they pull off something truly incredible if they make another game.  If you REALLY need a new game to play go ahead and buy this like I did, but you will be disappointed.  Honestly its sad to see how far this company has fallen, I dont know anyone who liked Risen 2 and this game really isnt any better.

reviewText:
Risen 1 was not that good of a game. There were few objectives other than just wondering around and not dying. The landscape didn't really change. The quests were repetitive.  And you played 99% of the game by yourself with no help from NPCs.

Risen 2 made huge strides.  Suddenly you had objectives and travelling companions.  The NPCs were unique and interesting. I saw many of the elements that made KOTR, DAO Baldurs Gate and even Mass Effect great:  The concept of having a ship/stronghold and seeking out and finding NPCs to form a crew/party capable of taking on some monumental task.  In the process you visit different lands that showcase very different environments, keeping the game from getting boring.  At the end of the day, I can say that I would replay Risen 2 a second time, and that says a lot for a game.

So when I saw Risen 3, I bought it hoping for something at least as good and hopefully better than Risen 2. Sadly I was disappointed.  You are no longer playing as the same nameless protagonist that you played in Risen 1 and 2.  Instead you are playing as the brother of the protagonists love interest.  And instead of being educated and well spoken, like someone who could just as easily be a mage or a pirate, the protagonist is a typical pirate thug. One of the games themes is overcoming your thuggish nature...

You still have a ship. You still have to gather NPCs and you still get to visit different lands, but it is not fun playing a jerk. I figured there would be a reason why they forced this on me. A plot twist or something special about being related to Steelbeard that was key to the plot.  But it never happens. At the end of the game, I said to myself, There is no reason I could not have been the protagonist from Risen 1 and 2".

Regardless of the plot twists or other RPG elements they incorporate
date: this is one choice they take away from you is simply unforgivable. And since the love interest from game 2 is your sister
recommended: there is zero romance and flirting. An element that made most of the other big hit titles I mentioned so successful.\n\nSo no
hoursPlayed: I can't recommend this to people. Even if it was free
voteText: you are looking at wasting 40+ hours of your life that you will never get back."

reviewText:
**UPDATE** Apparently this bug only affects CPU's with more than 8 virtual cores, not 4 like I originally reported. There is a workaround detailed in that forum but it involves disabling some of your cores and rebooting the machine. You would need a further reboot to re-enable them.

Official comment from the publisher is that they are all out at some show this week so probably wont be able to help for a while. Hope they are having fun.

reviewText:
Initial experience: Won't launch, won't run... Restarted Steam 3 times, as is the protocol for games that don't launch, and still having issues. Revalidated files, 3 failed, downloaded 1.4GB worth of data. Tried to launch, opens and stays at 1,708kb and does nothing. Forcefully exiting via Task Manager still takes time to close.. Validated again, all successful. Left open for 10 minutes, no change.

Requesting refund from Steam because it won't launch, it won't run, I meet, and exceed, the recommended requirements, and I'm sick of broken Risen games.

Note: Refund request has been sent and is pending; I'd advise others that have issues with the game ( not starting, false advertising ie editing screenshots out of game to give them a better look / feel, etc.. ie fraud ) to do the same because publishers shouldn't be able to get away with this crap.

Uninstalled, not that it really matters because it didn't run either way.

reviewText:
Good:

- Return of three factions increases replayability.
- Diverse and effective spells/skills, many of which are unique to each faction.
- Characters and dialogue still have the old PB charm.
- Islands are large and interesting to explore.
- Expanded combat mechanics.
- You can turn into a parrot.
- You can talk to a parrot.
- Your parrot has his own questline.
- You can still deploy monkeys.
- Treasure hunting is still fun.
- DLC is way more substantial and compelling than Risen 2's.

Bad:
- Enemies only attack one at a time, making groups of enemies far less threatening than they used to be.
- Morality system encourages metagaming rather than making choices you genuinely believe in.
- Patty looks like a stripper.
- Chani is more white.
- You play as a new protagonist with a silly voice.
- Combat still has the old PB jank.
- Skill checks rarely offer alternative quest solutions.
- Naval boss battles are annoying.
- Lots of recycled content from Risen 2.
- Lockpicking minigames are still tedious (though this is true of minigames in general).

Conclusion: If you enjoyed the previous Risen games, you will very likely enjoy Risen 3. If you didn't enjoy them, Risen 3 won't change your mind.

reviewText:
As I haven't played Risen and Risen 2 before purchasing the game I did not really know what to expect, but as an RPG fan I quite enjoyed the game.

Starting with the visuals, I must say they are absolutely stunning. If you like taking beautiful screenshots, Risen 3 is definitely for you!

About the story line: good but not great. There are plenty of side quests to choose from though.

I really enjoyed having companions throughout the quests, they were useful and some of them had an awesome sense of humour. You simply cannot get enough of Bones' remarks.

There are some pretty cool skills as well, like the Monkey. You can actually train a monkey to steal for you.

Mini games are a good source of extra coins, you can choose knife-throwing, arm-wrestling and drinking.

Sea battles are also very enjoyable.

I have played over 50 hrs without buying the DLCs, but I definitely could have played another 50.

reviewText:
One of the best RPGs in recent years. Honestly I'm not sure to which game should I compare it, each Piranha Bytes game is its own experience, and I love them for that.

I loved all games in Gothic series and I love all games in Risen series. From the Risen series, I would say that Risen 3 is probably the best one of them, even comparable to the golden Gothic 2.

The story of this game is solid, it is not the best, not the worst. I've been quite used to bad stereotype-like stories in RPGs (especially open world ones), like TES series, Two Worlds series, or Dragon Age series (in case of more linear ones). Each of these games suffer from black-and-white storyline (from the named ones I consider the plot one of the better ones).

The gameplay is typical for Piranha Bytes games. The combat system is something different, and very good (unless you just left-click all day long, which is a bad way to play this game and it can ruin your experience). It is better than in TES games, way better compared to Dragon Age series, but a lot worse compared to Dark Messiah of Might and Magic.
In this game you can actually dodge hits (which is very common in medeival fencing schools), but well, don't expect realistic fight simulator. But it is action enough, you won't get bored. Plus, guns are very good addition into the game.

Dialogue lines are well done, audio for them is also quite good. As for the quests, there is a whole lot of them, but I'd like more impact on game in general, and longer side quest lines. Music is one of the best, it perfectly suits the game.

Visuals are also very good, very nice fire particles, water splashes and particle effects in general. The authors did quite a job on light and shadows, each single island is in a bit different stylized art set and it works perfectly. The graphics quality can compete with any other AAA game.

Of course there are few things that look bad. One of them is, that after performing major actions to close gates to underworld, the islands look unchanged. For me, if green grass would return to that areas it would be perfect. I would see that I did some major impact on game world and it would made me even more happy.
Second thing is, I don't really see further lore connection with Risen series, yes it is in the same world, there are some of the characters that were in previous games, but the lore connection is weak. I'm comparing mainly to Gothic 1 - Gothic 2 games here, where the lore connection between those game was really strong and good.

Anyways, this game is worth it. I know it seems average, it isn't. Don't believe metacritic, as some fans of older Piranha Bytes games are downvoting, without even playing it, sadly...

reviewText: I think this game is brilliant :) It's got a Fable/Skyrim/Assassins Creed feel to it and personally I'm loving the combat system. I read a lot of reviews saying it was a Con and not a Pro and that scared me a bit but since it was half off I bought it anyway, and I couldn't be happier with it. The combat system is just a timing based system which requires that you read your opponent when battling them. I think that's cool and realistic really. You can riposte others attacks (turn their attack around on them) even to large monsters like golems n stuff which I think is cool, they're coming in with some massive smash attack and ur just like, NOPE *slap*. Great game. Sure I'm only 30 hours in but I think it's lovely. I'm currently a fire wizard dressed up all cool like, runnin around like prince Zuco, burning like 3-4 enemies at once, raining fire down upon my enemies! >:D and when fire doesn't work, LIGHTNING!! Anyway, if you're up for a fun single player RPG, this is a good pick.\n\nMy only Con: I wish games like these could be Co-op. (Divinity: OS and Dying light for example, also great games that are Co-op.)

reviewText:
Recomended mostly for the rock-solid fans of Gothic / Risen series.

Piranha bytes classics. People blame it for not developing with this gen RPG´s. No way, this is no Skyrim when you are born a hero, this is no Assasin´s creed where you are born with skills to fight 10 enemies at once and crush them. You can reach such status in this game, but it takes time.

Simply said you have to EARN your glory step by step, making it a hard work, but a rewarding one, offering a challenge on every difficulty, making the victories against every monsters count early on in the game.

reviewText:
So...

What can i say about this game?

It's different, it's not a normal rpg, or better a what we were accostumed in a modern RPG.

The combat is challenging at first, probably too much for some people, but the quests are good, and you really feel good when you start to get better itens and when you increase your skills. It's like you start as a homeless man and ends as a bilionaire. Yeah, at the end of the game you barelly lose health and deal a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of damage, it's nice to feel like that.

Still , what more you have in this game? Nice quests, sometimes very interesting ones, very nice maps, and you are very rewarded when you explore, and theres loads of place to explore in this game. Also is nice to play a pirate rpg.

What is not so nice or downright bad? Well, i like a nice story, and this aspect of the game is quite bad, the plot is bad... the protagonist is quite uninteresting, also the combat, it's good and bad at the same time, the enemies can stun lock you eating away your health crazily fast.

So... if you still reading this, you probably is a bit confused, it's a love or hate game, i hated some parts, still i think it's worth playing, it's nice to not be a viking , or a medieval warrior sometimes, and you'll be rewarded by getting good at the combat of this game. I had the same experience with Risen 2, and it feels weird, but also nice, and don't give up, it's much more hardcore than most games nowadays. I don't want to be an elitist, but having to earn something after working hard for it feel pretty damn good, and sometimes those old school games are right.

tl/dr: just buy it in a sale and try, you'll learn a different kind of gaming.

reviewText:
As I haven't played Risen and Risen 2 before purchasing the game I did not really know what to expect, but as an RPG fan I quite enjoyed the game.

Starting with the visuals, I must say they are absolutely stunning. If you like taking beautiful screenshots, Risen 3 is definitely for you!

About the story line: good but not great. There are plenty of side quests to choose from though.

I really enjoyed having companions throughout the quests, they were useful and some of them had an awesome sense of humour. You simply cannot get enough of Bones' remarks.

There are some pretty cool skills as well, like the Monkey. You can actually train a monkey to steal for you.

Mini games are a good source of extra coins, you can choose knife-throwing, arm-wrestling and drinking.

Sea battles are also very enjoyable.

I have played over 50 hrs without buying the DLCs, but I definitely could have played another 50.

reviewText:
PLUS:
Music.  Spot on. Genre leading in most instances.
Graphics:  I played the Enhanced Edition.  Graphics were well done with the various environments.
Quest / fetch:  If you like that sort of game, it’s done really well here.
World is detailed and intricate and rewards the player for exploring

MINUS:
Horribad dialog.  Not voice acting, dialog.  Unfortunately, this can impede your immersion in the game.  Seems like such an easy area they could have addressed.
Quest / fetch:  If you don’t like that sort of game, then Risen isn’t for you.
Graphics.  Shouldn’t be possible to run up a tree then fall off and die.  Minor glitches.

AVERAGE:
Voice Acting.  I didn’t find the actual voices an issue, but as mentioned the script was painful at times.

Acquiring items/loot:  First third of the game I didn’t like it, but as I played I appreciated the fact I had to actually “look” for items, instead of the usual acquiring by merely walking over them.  However, the drawback is I found myself constantly clicking for fear of missing something.  I liked that they didn’t dumb down exploring and finding items, but at the same time Important items can be easily overlooked.  As such, expect to find things occasionally in areas you’ve already combed over.

Combat.  I hated it a first… until I figured it out, then it was okay.  Yes, I had moments of aggravation and/or camera issues, but it was the exception not the norm.  There are those that hate Risen combat but I’m not among them.

CONCLUSION:
If you’re the type of gamer who appreciates well-designed areas to explore--and likes getting rewarded for exploring with additional quests and loot, then Risen 3 is most likely right for you.  The Risen series seems to be a love it or hate if affair.  For me, I think Risen does just enough keep me playing each new installment, and number 3 is no exception.   It wouldn’t be RPG GOTY but it would garner a nomination and maybe even make runner up.  Piranha Bytes knows how to build beautiful worlds and design quests, now if only they were just as good when it came to creating stories and English dialog translation.

This review is from playing the PC version Enhanced Edition with the 3 DLC.  I recommend this game @ 75% off and get all the DLC.  It’s cheap now, and makes the game more complete.

Non-spoiler tips:
Pay close attention to the map, the topography sometimes shows clues while exploring, Don’t forget to look up occasionally.
Get monkey trainer and listen for other monkeys!
You may wish to choose a difficulty above normal otherwise you’ll have tons of spells and items to assist you that you’ll never need to use.  If you’ve ever played a Risen or Gothic game in the past, then strongly consider playing on Hard.  I would consider normal to be too easy for seasoned players.
I read a few steam guides “what players needs to know” before playing and I’m glad I did.  I didn’t see them as spoilers but rather information that helped me get the most immersion from the game.  YMMV.

reviewText:
Titan Lords is my first game of the series, a game that took a little bit of play through before I really started to enjoy it.  At first glance the game swallowed me with its active environment.  You have the moving oceans, moving trees and grass, animals/vermin/creatures and colorful settings.  While the graphics of the environment was very good in my opinion, the character models did not feel on the same level. Titan Lords gave me a chance to play as a pirate.  With this comes the accent, sea monsters, ship battles and a lot of booty.  (The loot because as far as I know no other booty was obtainable.)

The games main characters voice annoyed me in every dialog.  Titan Lords is an easy game to play.  The combat felt over simplified.  Most of the beginning combat consists of parry/dodge and clicking one button to swing the weapon.  You do have a secondary weapon which is a ranged weapon.  From early on one of your goals is to join a faction.  This basically outlines what type of weapons and magic you will be learning.

Titan Lords have several quests for you to check out.  By end game with all of my skills even though the game is easy, I felt like my character went from some lame pirate to the ultimate badass.  I had a lot of fun gathering alliances to overcome the shadow.  Get this game on sale if you love rpgs.

reviewText:
Overall the game is ok, fairly long playing time with good RPG elements.

Positive:
+  Graphically it is pretty good, with latest patch they've improved texture resolutions. FPS does drop when everything is maxed out.
+ Story is fine. At least I didn't forget what I was supposed to do, when playing this game only 1-2 times a week
+ Minigames. Although simple, some of them are pretty fun to play.
+ Exploration. The game always encourages you to look for something special that is hidden near by. It is a very rewarding experience
+ Map design, overall pretty good and with a nice variety.

Negative:
- Combat. The most frustrating combat experience ever. I couldn't find any other game where combat experience was that bad. Controls have a lot of delay, some keys don't register so you have to mash the buttons multiple times to make sure it will. The overall dodge mechanic is just annoying and doesn't make the combat fun in any way. In fact, while you are dodging you are complete invulnerable to damage ? Batman Arkham series have shown what a good fun and fluit combat should be like, take notice Piranha Bytes !
- AI. I don't even know if there is an AI in this game. Pretty much all the enemies just charge straight towards you, and go into attack/dodge cycle. Funny thing almost every single monster in the game behaves pretty much the same way, shouldn't there be a better variation of enemy AI, maybe ? Companions pretty much the same thing, while they do follow you, sometimes they just get stuck and become missing, or they go and run away from you, just to hit a monster. And why enemy AI always targets me first ? The fact that I have companions doesn't seem to matter to them.
- Glitchy and buggy, for some reason the game kept crashing on me, I occasionally get stuck in the walls, enemies don't care and just go through them. Many other minor issues as well.
- Difficulty spikes. In the beginning when you are going with melee, you are going to be destroyed a lot. In the end when you go with magic you are going to destroy everything so easily that game becomes extremely easy. Shouldn't there be a different difficulty curve, like easy in the beginning and harder in the end instead ?

reviewText: The combat in this game feels a little ... incomplete. Early game, after I had gotten over the mistake of spam-clicking attacks, I found enemys who guarded (like skeletons or goblins) impossible to manage, I had little time to distance myself for a power attack, and I ran out of ammunition quickly, after obtaining the riposte skill they became more tolarable.\nThe true source of my discomfort with the combat would be battles with multiple creatures (3+) Whenever I entered larger battles I would constantly get angry as my companion would just stay back circling around an enemy occasionly taking a swing, I would get inturupted during swings, the auto-lock was infuriating switching to another foe whenever I repositioned myself and my dodge roll would not move me away from the battle, always getting stuck on foes or small ledges, making it worthless in any closed-in or rocky area.\nThankfully the exploring of the landscape at the interacting of NPC's leaves a nice cooldown between combat.

Still , what more you have in this game? Nice quests, sometimes very interesting ones, very nice maps, and you are very rewarded when you explore, and theres loads of place to explore in this game. Also is nice to play a pirate rpg.

What is not so nice or downright bad? Well, i like a nice story, and this aspect of the game is quite bad, the plot is bad... the protagonist is quite uninteresting, also the combat, it's good and bad at the same time, the enemies can stun lock you eating away your health crazily fast.

So... if you still reading this, you probably is a bit confused, it's a love or hate game, i hated some parts, still i think it's worth playing, it's nice to not be a viking , or a medieval warrior sometimes, and you'll be rewarded by getting good at the combat of this game. I had the same experience with Risen 2, and it feels weird, but also nice, and don't give up, it's much more hardcore than most games nowadays. I don't want to be an elitist, but having to earn something after working hard for it feel pretty damn good, and sometimes those old school games are right.

tl/dr: just buy it in a sale and try, you'll learn a different kind of gaming.

reviewText:
Having actually enjoyed Gothic 3, and then Risen 1 and 2, I was quite surprised by how tedious I found this game, to the point where I stopped playing and unistalled it after about 10 hours. I thought for sure it would be an improvement over the previous two Risen games, or at least as good.  How long should you play a game that is boring and frustrating before throwing in the towel?

Since I played a 30 hour game for about 10 hours, take that into consideration when reading this. I was not able to finish, nor would I ever want to. But I paid for it and did not really get my money worth.

The first Risen game was pretty straight forward, with a simple plot and simple combat with a small yet interesting island to explore. Risen 2 gave you a pirate ship and a crew and added some more complexity. I guess Risen 3 had to get more complicated, giving you too much to do, too many ways to do it, and too many places to go. The combat was sloppy in the first two games, but you were able to endure it and it didn't really get in the way of progress. In this game, the combat should have been cleaned up, but instead it is still clunky and it now gets in the way of progress. The low level enemies surround you and overwhelm you with interupting attacks.

After 10 hours, I still felt like a weakling. The game starts off by taking all of your abilities away from you and leaving you with a crappy raft. You have to really work to get it back and it felt like a chore. I never did get my ship back, and I didn't want to grind my life away to get it. I never felt any sense of improvement from gaining experience and abilities. I basically felt like a helpless idiot wandering around an island getting killed by every single enemy I would encounter, doing fetch quests for the locals with little payoff. The game really is a chore. It should pay you to play it.

First, this is actually a pretty fun game with good level design, character development choices, varied quests and decent visials. they even finally got over their ridiculous need for niche super twitch combat.

But, and with this company there is always a but, it totally fails in progression/scaling because, frankly, there isn't any. In a vain effort to keep both open world" and no "bethesda style monster scaling" they made a game where after you complete a third of it

reviewText:
Big ♥♥♥♥ing Adventure! Yip yip!

As usual, PB deliver a breathtaking world full of delight and wonder. Plenty of quests, plenty to discover. Bar some fairly silly path finding issues where you companions sometimes decide to detour for miles, and some annoy repetitive speeches by your companions, this is truly an epic game and I enjoyed pretty much every last minute.

I have spent a huge amount of time in this game, and I still seem to have missed the odd quest judging from my achivement list, but I've done hundreds more.

Environments are varied and look great, quests are nicely done and generally not repetitive, audio is awesome, story isn't too bad either. Hopefully there'll be a Risen 4 in due course, although perhaps they could shift the location now. Pirates are old hat.

reviewText:
Overall the game is ok, fairly long playing time with good RPG elements.

Positive:
+  Graphically it is pretty good, with latest patch they've improved texture resolutions. FPS does drop when everything is maxed out.
+ Story is fine. At least I didn't forget what I was supposed to do, when playing this game only 1-2 times a week
+ Minigames. Although simple, some of them are pretty fun to play.
+ Exploration. The game always encourages you to look for something special that is hidden near by. It is a very rewarding experience
+ Map design, overall pretty good and with a nice variety.

Negative:
- Combat. The most frustrating combat experience ever. I couldn't find any other game where combat experience was that bad. Controls have a lot of delay, some keys don't register so you have to mash the buttons multiple times to make sure it will. The overall dodge mechanic is just annoying and doesn't make the combat fun in any way. In fact, while you are dodging you are complete invulnerable to damage ? Batman Arkham series have shown what a good fun and fluit combat should be like, take notice Piranha Bytes !
- AI. I don't even know if there is an AI in this game. Pretty much all the enemies just charge straight towards you, and go into attack/dodge cycle. Funny thing almost every single monster in the game behaves pretty much the same way, shouldn't there be a better variation of enemy AI, maybe ? Companions pretty much the same thing, while they do follow you, sometimes they just get stuck and become missing, or they go and run away from you, just to hit a monster. And why enemy AI always targets me first ? The fact that I have companions doesn't seem to matter to them.
- Glitchy and buggy, for some reason the game kept crashing on me, I occasionally get stuck in the walls, enemies don't care and just go through them. Many other minor issues as well.
- Difficulty spikes. In the beginning when you are going with melee, you are going to be destroyed a lot. In the end when you go with magic you are going to destroy everything so easily that game becomes extremely easy. Shouldn't there be a different difficulty curve, like easy in the beginning and harder in the end instead ?

reviewText:
This game is a wonderfully retro rpg that I truly appreciate still having baldur's gate 1 & 2 and other simarly retro games.  I purchased this game recently and I am really enjoying it.  I am not the type to disregard the possible fun and exciting game play simply because the graphics aren't up to snuff by todays or even the standards of 5 years ago.  To be honest I think the games today are focused way too much on graphical appearance and feel and not enough on story and plot development, or character development.  A good backstory can`t be overlooked simply because a game requires a quad-core i7 processor.

The UI is well done in my opinion and has just about everything one could hope for, and the companions or crew don`t require any micro managing.  I think the idea of massing a crew for a big ship is a splendid plot device though i`m slightly disappointed in only having one companion at a time.

I thoroughly recommend this game to anyone looking for a change from current rpg game types, and most definitely for old time gamers such as myself who appreciate games like this and still play the oldies but goodies.

reviewText:
PLUS:
Music.  Spot on. Genre leading in most instances.
Graphics:  I played the Enhanced Edition.  Graphics were well done with the various environments.
Quest / fetch:  If you like that sort of game, it’s done really well here.
World is detailed and intricate and rewards the player for exploring

MINUS:
Horribad dialog.  Not voice acting, dialog.  Unfortunately, this can impede your immersion in the game.  Seems like such an easy area they could have addressed.
Quest / fetch:  If you don’t like that sort of game, then Risen isn’t for you.
Graphics.  Shouldn’t be possible to run up a tree then fall off and die.  Minor glitches.

AVERAGE:
Voice Acting.  I didn’t find the actual voices an issue, but as mentioned the script was painful at times.

Acquiring items/loot:  First third of the game I didn’t like it, but as I played I appreciated the fact I had to actually “look” for items, instead of the usual acquiring by merely walking over them.  However, the drawback is I found myself constantly clicking for fear of missing something.  I liked that they didn’t dumb down exploring and finding items, but at the same time Important items can be easily overlooked.  As such, expect to find things occasionally in areas you’ve already combed over.

Combat.  I hated it a first… until I figured it out, then it was okay.  Yes, I had moments of aggravation and/or camera issues, but it was the exception not the norm.  There are those that hate Risen combat but I’m not among them.

CONCLUSION:
If you’re the type of gamer who appreciates well-designed areas to explore--and likes getting rewarded for exploring with additional quests and loot, then Risen 3 is most likely right for you.  The Risen series seems to be a love it or hate if affair.  For me, I think Risen does just enough keep me playing each new installment, and number 3 is no exception.   It wouldn’t be RPG GOTY but it would garner a nomination and maybe even make runner up.  Piranha Bytes knows how to build beautiful worlds and design quests, now if only they were just as good when it came to creating stories and English dialog translation.

This review is from playing the PC version Enhanced Edition with the 3 DLC.  I recommend this game @ 75% off and get all the DLC.  It’s cheap now, and makes the game more complete.

Non-spoiler tips:
Pay close attention to the map, the topography sometimes shows clues while exploring, Don’t forget to look up occasionally.
Get monkey trainer and listen for other monkeys!
You may wish to choose a difficulty above normal otherwise you’ll have tons of spells and items to assist you that you’ll never need to use.  If you’ve ever played a Risen or Gothic game in the past, then strongly consider playing on Hard.  I would consider normal to be too easy for seasoned players.
I read a few steam guides “what players needs to know” before playing and I’m glad I did.  I didn’t see them as spoilers but rather information that helped me get the most immersion from the game.  YMMV.

reviewText:
This game is a interesting play, its hard as hell early game untill a tipping point half way through where after spending most of your money and points on one subject only you finally feel like you can handle yourself. the graphics are acceptable the story is interesting with some twists and turns, but there is issues ohh so many funny little issues.

Good:

Graphics: nice fps with not many drops on my old machine

Story: Many twists and turns you never really know whats going to happen

Side Quests: there is lots of side quests, i mean a lot most feel somewhat fedex but there are a few that are interesting
Choices: the game offers you a lot of choices and there is some fun out comes depending on what you choose, but dont be fooled that these things will change the game too much, they wont

BAD THINGS

Controls: mouse and keyboard can be a pain in the ♥♥♥♥, if the camera angle is in the wrong place you can endup attacking in the totally wrong direction and messing up a kill

Camera: as stated above is messed up at times where it can affect your combat

Combat: evil as hell early on, as in its totally unfair against you the individual, you find yourself bouncing around more than hitting anything early on

Length: the game is not that long, but what it offers is a interesting story just a shame its not that long and feels like it cuts out too short

Overall i would say yes to this game, but only when you can get it on the cheap, its not worth paying the full price, it has a few great momments and later on you do feel bad ♥♥♥ in the game, strange thing is you have to learn everything from countering in fights to actually learning stealth and pickpocketing. dont expect this game to give you a easy start but if you can get past that you will have fun

reviewText:
Fun game. Good game world. It is basically the same world as Risen 2. The story is pretty decent, the combat is fine, and the quests aren't repetitive. Considering RPGs, the quests are pretty unique and never felt stale. It took me 30 hours to play through doing almost all of the side quests, so it is a nice size.

There would be decent replay value if you wanted to try a mage, a swordsman, or a rifleman. The different factions offer replay value too. I don't think the game world is compelling enough to warrant a second go at the story, but I can see some reasons one might.

I'd recommend it mainly because I heard a lot of negativity surrounding it, and I found it to be solid. It's not a great game, but it is a good game. Well worth your money if you have played others in the series.

reviewText: I played the first Risen game on a whim after a Steam Sale and have thoroughly enjoyed all three of them.  Yes, they're somewhat campy and are nothing to write home about for the combat system, but the world it creates and the stories behind it rival almost any RPG.  Risen 3 makes a nice combination of the first two to crate what I think is the best game in the series so far.  Graphics are solid, voiceovers are comically approrpriate, and character customization is the best it's been.  8/10.

reviewText: I've played all 3 Risen games and this is a decent addition, maybe not as good as 2 but some people may like it more, it's sort of a blend of Risen 1+2. If you are a fan of the Risen or Gothic series (or have patience to skill up before complaining about the combat mechanics) it's definitely worth checking out, especially if you catch it on sale. Story in this one isn't the best IMO but still a good game and good RPG

reviewText: Probably the most polished game in the series, I had no real issues while playing it and the combat seemed to work far better than the first two Risens, or any other deep silver game I've played(I've played most of them).\n\nI'm not sure I would have liked this game without playing the first two, but I have. If your into openworld RPG's its not an elder scrolls game but it kept mme entertained for 40 some hours
